    <title>Guerrilla History</title>

    <itunes:summary><![CDATA[Guerrilla History is the podcast that acts as a reconnaissance report of global history for the activist left, and aims to use the lessons of history to analyze the present.


Your hosts are educators Henry Hakamaki and Professor Adnan Husain, historian and Director of the School of Religion at Queens University.


Follow us on social media!  Our podcast can be found on twitter at https://twitter.com/guerrilla_pod, and can be supported on patreon at https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory.  Your contributions will make the show possible to continue and succeed!

Follow the hosts, Henry can be found on twitter at https://twitter.com/huck1995.  Adnan can be followed on twitter at https://twitter.com/adnanahusain, and also runs The Majlis Podcast, which can be found at https://anchor.fm/msgp-queens, and the Muslim Societies-Global Perspectives group at Queens University, https://www.facebook.com/MSGPQU/.   The other shows of the Revolutionary Left Radio family can be found at revolutionaryleftradio.com.  

Thanks to Ryan Hakamaki, who designed and created the podcast's artwork, and Kevin MacLeod, who creates royalty-free music.]]></itunes:summary>

    <description><![CDATA[Guerrilla History is the podcast that acts as a reconnaissance report of global history for the activist left, and aims to use the lessons of history to analyze the present.


Your hosts are educators Henry Hakamaki and Professor Adnan Husain, historian and Director of the School of Religion at Queens University.


Follow us on social media!  Our podcast can be found on twitter at https://twitter.com/guerrilla_pod, and can be supported on patreon at https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory.  Your contributions will make the show possible to continue and succeed!

Follow the hosts, Henry can be found on twitter at https://twitter.com/huck1995.  Adnan can be followed on twitter at https://twitter.com/adnanahusain, and also runs The Majlis Podcast, which can be found at https://anchor.fm/msgp-queens, and the Muslim Societies-Global Perspectives group at Queens University, https://www.facebook.com/MSGPQU/.   The other shows of the Revolutionary Left Radio family can be found at revolutionaryleftradio.com.  

Thanks to Ryan Hakamaki, who designed and created the podcast's artwork, and Kevin MacLeod, who creates royalty-free music.]]></description>

    <item>
      <title>West African Women's Development (Part 1) w/ Takiyah Harper-Shipman [REMASTERED]</title>
      <itunes:title>West African Women&#39;s Development (Part 1) w/ Takiyah Harper-Shipman [REMASTERED]</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 21 Nov 2025 14:31:07 +0000</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[e32bd07d-7be7-4b6c-ba6e-5fa1138b3fe9]]></guid>
      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/west-african-womens-development-part-1-w-takiyah-harper-shipman-remastered]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<p><em>This is a fully remastered episode, which originally came out in April 2022</em></p> <p>In this episode of Guerrilla History, we bring on the fantastic Africana studies scholar, Professor Takiyah Harper-Shipman, to talk about West African women's development, Sankara, AFRICOM, and more!  Due to time constraints, this episode will act as an introduction to these topics for our next conversation with Professor Harper-Shipman, which will take place soon and will be a longer, more in-depth discussion.  We really enjoyed the conversation, and are already looking forward to diving into the minutiae with the Professor very soon!</p> <p>Takiyah Harper-Shipman is an Assistant Professor in the Africana Studies Department at Davidson College.  Her courses include Africana political economy, gender and development in sub-Saharan Africa, African feminisms, international development: theory and praxis, and research methods in Africana Studies.  Her book <em>Rethinking Ownership of Development in Africa</em> is available from Routledge: <a href= "https://www.routledge.com/Rethinking-Ownership-of-Development-in-Africa/Harper-Shipman/p/book/9780367787813">https://www.routledge.com/Rethinking-Ownership-of-Development-in-Africa/Harper-Shipman/p/book/9780367787813</a>.  We also highly recommend checking out her chapter La Santé Avant Tout: Health Before Everything in the excellent <em>A Certain Amount of Madness</em><br /> <em>The Life, Politics and Legacies of Thomas Sankara</em> <a href= "https://www.plutobooks.com/9780745337579/a-certain-amount-of-madness/">https://www.plutobooks.com/9780745337579/a-certain-amount-of-madness/</a>.  </p> <p>Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a> </p>]]></description>
      
      <content:encoded><![CDATA[<p><em>This is a fully remastered episode, which originally came out in April 2022</em></p> <p>In this episode of Guerrilla History, we bring on the fantastic Africana studies scholar, Professor Takiyah Harper-Shipman, to talk about West African women's development, Sankara, AFRICOM, and more! Due to time constraints, this episode will act as an introduction to these topics for our next conversation with Professor Harper-Shipman, which will take place soon and will be a longer, more in-depth discussion. We really enjoyed the conversation, and are already looking forward to diving into the minutiae with the Professor very soon!</p> <p>Takiyah Harper-Shipman is an Assistant Professor in the Africana Studies Department at Davidson College. Her courses include Africana political economy, gender and development in sub-Saharan Africa, African feminisms, international development: theory and praxis, and research methods in Africana Studies. Her book <em>Rethinking Ownership of Development in Africa</em> is available from Routledge: <a href= "https://www.routledge.com/Rethinking-Ownership-of-Development-in-Africa/Harper-Shipman/p/book/9780367787813">https://www.routledge.com/Rethinking-Ownership-of-Development-in-Africa/Harper-Shipman/p/book/9780367787813</a>. We also highly recommend checking out her chapter La Santé Avant Tout: Health Before Everything in the excellent <em>A Certain Amount of Madness</em> <em>The Life, Politics and Legacies of Thomas Sankara</em> <a href= "https://www.plutobooks.com/9780745337579/a-certain-amount-of-madness/">https://www.plutobooks.com/9780745337579/a-certain-amount-of-madness/</a>. </p> <p>Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a> </p>]]></content:encoded>

    <item>
      <title>Precolonial Nigeria w/ Max Siollun (AR&amp;D Ep.11)</title>
      <itunes:title>Precolonial Nigeria w/ Max Siollun (AR&amp;amp;D Ep.11)</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 14 Nov 2025 13:39:03 +0000</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[132b3740-00f0-4c38-ae41-0343bff96706]]></guid>
      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/precolonial-nigeria-w-max-siollun-ard-ep11]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<p><span dir="auto">In this continuation of our African Revolutions and Decolonization series, we bring you another fascinating episode focused on precolonial Nigeria - the people's there, their history, the political systems, political economy, international relations, and more.  We are fortunate to be joined by the person who wrote the book on this topic, Max Siollun, whose <a href= "https://www.plutobooks.com/product/the-forgotten-era/">The Forgotten Era: Nigeria Before British Rule</a> served as the major resource in creating this episode.  We highly recommend checking out his book, from Pluto Press, and stay tuned for a future discussion with Max on post-colonial Nigeria!</span></p> <p><strong>Max Siollun</strong> is a historian. He has written several acclaimed books on Nigeria's history, including <em>What Britain Did to Nigeria: A Short History of Conquest and Rule</em>, which was shortlisted in <em>BBC History Magazine</em>'s 2021 Books of the Year, and the focus of today's episode: <span dir= "auto"><a href= "https://www.plutobooks.com/product/the-forgotten-era/">The Forgotten Era: Nigeria Before British Rule</a>.  Follow him on twitter <a href= "https://x.com/maxsiollun">@maxsiollun</a>.</span></p> <p>Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a> </p>]]></description>
      
      <content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>In this continuation of our African Revolutions and Decolonization series, we bring you another fascinating episode focused on precolonial Nigeria - the people's there, their history, the political systems, political economy, international relations, and more. We are fortunate to be joined by the person who wrote the book on this topic, Max Siollun, whose <a href= "https://www.plutobooks.com/product/the-forgotten-era/">The Forgotten Era: Nigeria Before British Rule</a> served as the major resource in creating this episode. We highly recommend checking out his book, from Pluto Press, and stay tuned for a future discussion with Max on post-colonial Nigeria!</p> <p>Max Siollun is a historian. He has written several acclaimed books on Nigeria's history, including <em>What Britain Did to Nigeria: A Short History of Conquest and Rule</em>, which was shortlisted in <em>BBC History Magazine</em>'s 2021 Books of the Year, and the focus of today's episode: <a href= "https://www.plutobooks.com/product/the-forgotten-era/">The Forgotten Era: Nigeria Before British Rule</a>. Follow him on twitter <a href= "https://x.com/maxsiollun">@maxsiollun</a>.</p> <p>Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a> </p>]]></content:encoded>

    <item>
      <title>The Life and Times of Svetlana Grigorevna Ter-Minasova [From the Archives]</title>
      <itunes:title>The Life and Times of Svetlana Grigorevna Ter-Minasova [From the Archives]</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 07 Nov 2025 15:36:04 +0000</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[78212270-999a-497d-afb6-53509de1c119]]></guid>
      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/the-life-and-times-of-svetlana-grigorevna-ter-minasova-from-the-archives]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<p data-pm-slice="1 1 []">A very unusual episode, where returning guest-panelist Safine Hakamaki (Née Ashirova) co-hosts an interview with Henry of the esteemed Svetlana Grivorevna Ter-Minasova.  In this episode, Henry and Safie discuss the life of Professor Ter-Minasova, from her early childhood during WWII up through the present, where she continues to work as the Founding President of the Faculty of Foreign Languages and Area Studies at Moscow State University!  During this oral-autobiography, we learn why she credits Joseph Stalin with saving her life, what it was like growing up during WWII and the immediate aftermath, and her career as the "Mother" of Soviet (and subsequently Russian) foreign language education.  We're sure you'll enjoy!</p> <p>Svetlana Grigorevna Ter-Minasova is the founder and President of the Faculty of Foreign Languages and Area Studies at Lomonosov Moscow State University, and retains a position as Professor Emeritus at the university.  She has been Chairperson of the Foreign Languages Teaching Council (part of the Ministry of Education) since 1987.  Among many other credits, she also has been the Founding President of both National Association of Applied Linguistics and National Association of Teachers of English.  Her book "Notes by a Soviet Dinosaur",  came out in 2015, and has been excerpted in East-West Review.</p> <p>Safie Hakamaki is a Russian linguist and foreign language educator.  You can follow her telegram channel <a href= "https://t.me/amusing_musings">@amusing_musings</a>.</p> <p>Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a> </p>]]></description>
      
      <content:encoded><![CDATA[<p data-pm-slice="1 1 []">A very unusual episode, where returning guest-panelist Safine Hakamaki (Née Ashirova) co-hosts an interview with Henry of the esteemed Svetlana Grivorevna Ter-Minasova. In this episode, Henry and Safie discuss the life of Professor Ter-Minasova, from her early childhood during WWII up through the present, where she continues to work as the Founding President of the Faculty of Foreign Languages and Area Studies at Moscow State University! During this oral-autobiography, we learn why she credits Joseph Stalin with saving her life, what it was like growing up during WWII and the immediate aftermath, and her career as the "Mother" of Soviet (and subsequently Russian) foreign language education. We're sure you'll enjoy!</p> <p>Svetlana Grigorevna Ter-Minasova is the founder and President of the Faculty of Foreign Languages and Area Studies at Lomonosov Moscow State University, and retains a position as Professor Emeritus at the university. She has been Chairperson of the Foreign Languages Teaching Council (part of the Ministry of Education) since 1987. Among many other credits, she also has been the Founding President of both National Association of Applied Linguistics and National Association of Teachers of English. Her book "Notes by a Soviet Dinosaur", came out in 2015, and has been excerpted in East-West Review.</p> <p>Safie Hakamaki is a Russian linguist and foreign language educator. You can follow her telegram channel <a href= "https://t.me/amusing_musings">@amusing_musings</a>.</p> <p>Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a> </p>]]></content:encoded>

    <item>
      <title>Mining the Congo w/ Josaphat Musamba, Germain Ngoie Tshibambe, &amp; Ben Radley  (AR&amp;D Ep.10)</title>
      <itunes:title>Mining the Congo w/ Josaphat Musamba, Germain Ngoie Tshibambe, &amp;amp; Ben Radley  (AR&amp;amp;D Ep.10)</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 31 Oct 2025 12:22:07 +0000</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[212093bc-5329-4eb8-bda4-e85c78ef3310]]></guid>
      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/mining-the-congo-w-josaphat-musamba-germain-ngoie-tshibambe-ben-radley-ard-ep10]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<div dir="auto"><span dir="auto">With this episode of Guerrilla History, we bring you another fascinating episode in our series African Revolutions and Decolonization.  This time, a big episode on mining in Congo - extraction, exploitation, environmental and economic impacts, as well as the history, regional variations, and the difference between industrial mining and artisanal mining in Congo.  For this, we are lucky to be joined by Ben Radley as a guest host, and two excellent guests from the Congo -   Josaphat Musamba and Germain Ngoie Tshibambe.  Given their academic work on this, plus Josaphat's actual experience as a miner himself, we could not ask for a better group to unpack this!  Share widely to help others understand this remarkably pivotal industry.  Also be sure to check out our two previous episodes from the series on the Congo (<a href= "https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/the-congo-from-colonization-through-lumumba-mobutu-w-georges-nzongola-ntalaja-ard-ep-5">The First</a>, and <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/the-situation-in-congo-from-mobutu-to-m23-rebels-today-w-georges-nzongola-ntalaja-ard-ep-6"> The Second</a>).  Lastly, check out <a href="cegemi.com">the Centre of Expertise on Mining Governance</a>.</span></div> <div dir="auto"> </div> <div dir="auto"><strong>Josaphat Musamba</strong> is a Congolese researcher, and is a Ph.D. student at Ghent University. Check out Josaphat's twitter <a href= "https://x.com/josaphatmusamba?lang=en">@MusambaJosaphat</a> and his <a href= "https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Josaphat-Musamba-2">ResearchGate profile</a>.</div> <div dir="auto"> </div> <div dir="auto"><strong>Germain Ngoie Tshibambe</strong> is a full professor at the <a class="GI370e" href= "https://www.google.com/search?q=University+of+Lubumbashi&rlz=1C5CHFA_enDE766DE766&oq=lubumbashi+professor+germain&gs_lcrp=EgZjaHJvbWUyBggAEEUYOTIHCAEQIRigATIHCAIQIRigATIHCAMQIRiPAtIBCDgxMTFqMGo0qAIAsAIB&sourceid=chrome&ie=UTF-8&mstk=AUtExfDuxQLjK9mjkluGB0SLTvOPWNfDWdE-49s7nFGdEm7XPQ4b1SB0iELeAOCE3jxEcaKwgKkdQ4hCFA0A7IbbUihUuo6WGywLoRuYgXxB1oCYgrwOuLdACf2Bt1FBcIDvnIB9oJ6yRAcX64280_ssK2KByd30uJnEU1TeVta94eKpqWg&csui=3&ved=2ahUKEwjejIqis86QAxVbFxAIHbiZDloQgK4QegQIARAD" data-wiz-uids="azF2Qb_e" data-ved= "2ahUKEwjejIqis86QAxVbFxAIHbiZDloQgK4QegQIARAD" data-hveid="CAEQAw" data-processed="true">University of Lubumbashi</a> in the Democratic Republic of Congo, where he teaches international relations and is the Head Advisor of the Rector's Cabinet. Check out his <a href= "https://lugeology.academia.edu/GermainNgoieTshibambe/CurriculumVitae"> Academia page</a> and <a href= "https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Germain-Ngoie">ResearchGate profile</a>.</div> <div dir="auto"> </div> <div dir="auto"><strong>Ben Radley</strong> is is a Lecturer in International Development at the University of Bath, is author of <a href= "https://global.oup.com/academic/product/disrupted-development-in-the-congo-9780192849052"> Disrupted Development in the Congo: The Fragile Foundations of the African Mining Consensus</a>, and is an editor of the <a href= "roape.net">Review of African Political Economy (ROAPE)</a>. Follow him on twitter <a href="twitter.com/RadleyBen">@RadleyBen</a> and check out <a href="benradley.com">his website</a>.</div> <p>Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a> </p>]]></description>
      
      <content:encoded><![CDATA[With this episode of Guerrilla History, we bring you another fascinating episode in our series African Revolutions and Decolonization. This time, a big episode on mining in Congo - extraction, exploitation, environmental and economic impacts, as well as the history, regional variations, and the difference between industrial mining and artisanal mining in Congo. For this, we are lucky to be joined by Ben Radley as a guest host, and two excellent guests from the Congo - Josaphat Musamba and Germain Ngoie Tshibambe. Given their academic work on this, plus Josaphat's actual experience as a miner himself, we could not ask for a better group to unpack this! Share widely to help others understand this remarkably pivotal industry. Also be sure to check out our two previous episodes from the series on the Congo (<a href= "https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/the-congo-from-colonization-through-lumumba-mobutu-w-georges-nzongola-ntalaja-ard-ep-5">The First</a>, and <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/the-situation-in-congo-from-mobutu-to-m23-rebels-today-w-georges-nzongola-ntalaja-ard-ep-6"> The Second</a>). Lastly, check out <a href="cegemi.com">the Centre of Expertise on Mining Governance</a>. Josaphat Musamba is a Congolese researcher, and is a Ph.D. student at Ghent University. Check out Josaphat's twitter <a href= "https://x.com/josaphatmusamba?lang=en">@MusambaJosaphat</a> and his <a href= "https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Josaphat-Musamba-2">ResearchGate profile</a>. Germain Ngoie Tshibambe is a full professor at the <a class="GI370e" href= "https://www.google.com/search?q=University+of+Lubumbashi&rlz=1C5CHFA_enDE766DE766&oq=lubumbashi+professor+germain&gs_lcrp=EgZjaHJvbWUyBggAEEUYOTIHCAEQIRigATIHCAIQIRigATIHCAMQIRiPAtIBCDgxMTFqMGo0qAIAsAIB&sourceid=chrome&ie=UTF-8&mstk=AUtExfDuxQLjK9mjkluGB0SLTvOPWNfDWdE-49s7nFGdEm7XPQ4b1SB0iELeAOCE3jxEcaKwgKkdQ4hCFA0A7IbbUihUuo6WGywLoRuYgXxB1oCYgrwOuLdACf2Bt1FBcIDvnIB9oJ6yRAcX64280_ssK2KByd30uJnEU1TeVta94eKpqWg&csui=3&ved=2ahUKEwjejIqis86QAxVbFxAIHbiZDloQgK4QegQIARAD" data-wiz-uids="azF2Qb_e" data-ved= "2ahUKEwjejIqis86QAxVbFxAIHbiZDloQgK4QegQIARAD" data-hveid="CAEQAw" data-processed="true">University of Lubumbashi</a> in the Democratic Republic of Congo, where he teaches international relations and is the Head Advisor of the Rector's Cabinet. Check out his <a href= "https://lugeology.academia.edu/GermainNgoieTshibambe/CurriculumVitae"> Academia page</a> and <a href= "https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Germain-Ngoie">ResearchGate profile</a>. Ben Radley is is a Lecturer in International Development at the University of Bath, is author of <a href= "https://global.oup.com/academic/product/disrupted-development-in-the-congo-9780192849052"> Disrupted Development in the Congo: The Fragile Foundations of the African Mining Consensus</a>, and is an editor of the <a href= "roape.net">Review of African Political Economy (ROAPE)</a>. Follow him on twitter <a href="twitter.com/RadleyBen">@RadleyBen</a> and check out <a href="benradley.com">his website</a>. <p>Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a> </p>]]></content:encoded>

      <title>A Football Manifesto w/ Robert E. Wilson</title>

      <description><![CDATA[<p>In this episode of Guerrilla History, we have an extensive and fascinating conversation on football with Robert Wilson! This was a great conversation, not only if you are a fan of the sport.  We highly recommend you also check out the interview Robert did <a href= "https://revolutionaryleftradio.libsyn.com/socializing-sports-reclaiming-the-beautiful-game-from-capital-empire"> on Rev Left Radio</a>.</p> <p>Be sure to also check out our past episodes on football, each of which featured Alexander Aviña: <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/football-palestine-copa-amrica-the-euros-w-alex-avia"> <strong>Football!       <title>Drone Strikes, the CIA, &amp; Nobel "Peace" Prizes - Alex Aviña + Michael Fox on the Imperialist War on Venezuela</title>
      <itunes:title>Drone Strikes, the CIA, &amp;amp; Nobel &quot;Peace&quot; Prizes - Alex Aviña + Michael Fox on the Imperialist War on Venezuela</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 17 Oct 2025 15:40:05 +0000</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[f8de4c3f-2981-4e26-a170-fe9a3d322ea0]]></guid>
      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/drone-strikes-the-cia-nobel-peace-prizes-alex-avia-michael-fox-on-the-imperialist-war-on-venezuela]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<p>In this episode of Guerrilla History, we are joined by two fan favorites of the show - Alexander Aviña and Michael Fox!  Here, we discuss the escalating imperialist war that is being waged on Venezuela.  With such a rapidly evolving situation, you will want to make sure that you listen to this to know the background!</p> <p>Also, be sure to check out the past episodes Alex and Michael have been on the show for.  Alex has appeared on:  <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/dogmatism-and-reading-history-w-alexander-avia"> <em>Dogmatism and Reading History</em></a>, <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/football-palestine-copa-amrica-the-euros-w-alex-avia"> <strong>Football! Palestine, Copa América, & the Euros</strong></a>, <em><a href= "https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/israel-and-its-role-in-latin-america-w-alexander-avia"> "Israel" and Its Role in Latin America</a></em>, <strong><a href= "https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/the-mexican-dirty-war-a-war-to-the-death-w-alexander-avia-benjamin-t-smith-0"> The Mexican Dirty War: A War to the Death</a></strong>, <em><a href="https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/the-world-cup-sport-politics-history-and-propaganda-w-alexander-avia"> The World Cup: Sport, Politics, History, and Propaganda</a></em>, <strong><a href= "https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/coups-oil-and-oil-nationalization-supplement-w-alexander-avia-brandon-wolfe-hunnicutt"> Coups, Oil, and Oil Nationalization</a></strong>, <em><a href= "https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/intelligence-briefing-the-beautiful-game-w-alexander-avin"> Intelligence Briefing: The Beautiful Game</a></em>, and <strong><a href= "https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/alex-avia">Cold War Latin America</a></strong> (that's a LOT of hours of material for you!)</p> <p>Michael has also been on several episodes: <em><a href= "https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/stories-of-resistance-brazil-update-w-michael-fox"> Stories of Resistance + Brazil Update</a></em>, <strong><a href= "https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/american-imperialisms-shadow-on-latin-america-w-michael-fox"> American Imperialism's Shadow on Latin America</a></strong>, and <em><a href= "https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/the-rise-of-fascism-bolsonaro-the-brazilian-elections-w-michael-fox-dispatch"> The Rise of Fascism, Bolsonaro, & the Brazilian Elections</a></em></p> <p><strong>Alexander Aviña</strong> is associate professor of Latin American history at Arizona State University and author of <em>Specters of Revolution: Peasant Guerrillas in the Cold War Mexican Countryside</em>. Alex's website is available at <a href= "https://alexanderavina.com/">alexanderavina.com</a>, and he can be followed on twitter <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/twitter.com/Alexander_Avina">@Alexander_Avina</a></p> <div class="page" title="Page 12"> <div class="layoutArea"> <div class="column"> <div class="page" title="Page 14"> <div class="layoutArea"> <div class="column"> <p><strong>Michael Fox</strong> is a Brazil-based journalist, contributor to The World, former Editor of NACLA, and the host of the podcast series <a href= "https://therealnews.com/under-the-shadow">Under the Shadow</a> and  <a href= "https://therealnews.com/brazil-on-fire">Brazil on Fire</a>, and now also <a href= "https://therealnews.com/stories-of-resistance">Stories of Resistance</a>. Michael can be followed on Twitter <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/twitter.com/mfox_us">@mfox_us</a>, you can support his project on his <a href= "https://www.patreon.com/mfox">patreon</a> and follow his band <a href= "https://open.spotify.com/artist/0nexDyQCZI89JH8zsYu5wa">Monte Perdido</a>.</p> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> <p>Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a> </p> <p>We also have a (free!) <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.substack.com/p/guerrilla-history-newsletter-1"> newsletter</a> you can sign up for, and please note that <a href= "https://www.youtube.com/@Guerrilla_History">Guerrilla History now is uploading on YouTube</a> as well, so do us a favor, subscribe to the show and share some links from there so we can get helped out in the algorithms!!</p>]]></description>

    <item>
      <title>Remembering Anticolonial Algiers: Panthers &amp; Pan-African Revolutionaries w/Elaine Mokhtefi</title>
      <itunes:title>Remembering Anticolonial Algiers: Panthers &amp;amp; Pan-African Revolutionaries w/Elaine Mokhtefi</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Mon, 13 Oct 2025 18:36:46 +0000</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[63b80b02-701a-47b9-ae3c-fafbecfa6c75]]></guid>
      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/remembering-anticolonial-algiers-panthers-pan-african-revolutionaries-welaine-mokhtefi]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<p>In this collaboration between Guerrilla History and the Adnan Husain Show, Adnan has a wonderful conversation with a remarkable radical activist, Elaine Mokhtefi, as part of our ongoing series of interviews with living historical revolutionaries. Elaine Mokhtefi is author of "Algiers, Third World Capital: Freedom fighters, Revolutionaries, Black Panthers." This fascinating discussion retraces Elaine's early political engagement with the FLN mission to the UN, her decision to move to Algeria to help build the postcolonial nation after liberation from France, her experiences as a translator and journalist covering the transnational movements for liberation across the Global South, and work with the Black Panthers exiled in Algiers. She danced with Fanon, met radical third world leaders, and struggled for a better world. Now in her 90's, she remains an inspiring and committed activist. A lot to learn in this conversation!</p> <p>Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a> </p> <p>We also have a (free!) <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.substack.com/p/guerrilla-history-newsletter-1"> newsletter</a> you can sign up for, and please note that <a href= "https://www.youtube.com/@Guerrilla_History">Guerrilla History now is uploading on YouTube</a> as well, so do us a favor, subscribe to the show and share some links from there so we can get helped out in the algorithms!!</p> <p class="p1">Adnan Husain Show on YT and audio podcast and they can support <a href="patreon.com/adnanhusain"><span class= "s1">patreon.com/adnanhusain</span></a> and <a href= "buymeacoffee.com/adnanhusain"><span class= "s1">buymeacoffee.com/adnanhusain</span></a></p>]]></description>
      
      <content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>In this collaboration between Guerrilla History and the Adnan Husain Show, Adnan has a wonderful conversation with a remarkable radical activist, Elaine Mokhtefi, as part of our ongoing series of interviews with living historical revolutionaries. Elaine Mokhtefi is author of "Algiers, Third World Capital: Freedom fighters, Revolutionaries, Black Panthers." This fascinating discussion retraces Elaine's early political engagement with the FLN mission to the UN, her decision to move to Algeria to help build the postcolonial nation after liberation from France, her experiences as a translator and journalist covering the transnational movements for liberation across the Global South, and work with the Black Panthers exiled in Algiers. She danced with Fanon, met radical third world leaders, and struggled for a better world. Now in her 90's, she remains an inspiring and committed activist. A lot to learn in this conversation!</p> <p>Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a> </p> <p>We also have a (free!) <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.substack.com/p/guerrilla-history-newsletter-1"> newsletter</a> you can sign up for, and please note that <a href= "https://www.youtube.com/@Guerrilla_History">Guerrilla History now is uploading on YouTube</a> as well, so do us a favor, subscribe to the show and share some links from there so we can get helped out in the algorithms!!</p> <p class="p1">Adnan Husain Show on YT and audio podcast and they can support <a href="patreon.com/adnanhusain">patreon.com/adnanhusain</a> and <a href= "buymeacoffee.com/adnanhusain">buymeacoffee.com/adnanhusain</a></p>]]></content:encoded>

    <item>
      <title>Subverting Syria: Dark Histories of US Empire w/ Patrick Higgins</title>
      <itunes:title>Subverting Syria: Dark Histories of US Empire w/ Patrick Higgins</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Sat, 20 Sep 2025 07:49:13 +0000</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[6c194580-d84a-4fad-99a8-3ef88d16fae1]]></guid>
      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/subverting-syria-dark-histories-of-us-empire-w-patrick-higgins]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<p>This episode is a release of our sister program The Adnan Husain Show.</p> <hr /> <p>Adnan discusses a crucial history of US subversion of Syria's sovereignty even before the conclusion of WW2 starting with interference and covert operations by the OSS precursor to the CIA and then through the entire Cold War with Dr. Patrick Higgins, a Middle East historian, co-editor of Liberated Texts and member of the Anti-Imperialist Scholars Collective. His article "Gunning for Damascus: The US War on the Syrian Arab Republic" is mandatory reading and the state of the field on this dark history. <a href= "https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/19436149.2023.2199487?scroll=top&needAccess=true#abstractart">https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/19436149.2023.2199487?scroll=top&needAccess=true#abstractart</a></p> <p class="MsoNormal">Support the show on Patreon if you can (and get early access to episodes)! <br /> www.patreon.com/adnanhusain <br /> Or make a one-time donation to the show and Buy Me a Coffee: https://buymeacoffee.com/adnanhusain<br /> Like, subscribe, share! <br /> Also available in video on YouTube: <br /> https://youtube.com/@adnanhusainshow<br /> X: @adnanahusain<br /> Substack: adnanahusain.substack.com <br /> <a href="https://www.adnanhusain.org/">www.adnanhusain.org</a></p>]]></description>
      
      <content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>This episode is a release of our sister program The Adnan Husain Show.</p> <p>Adnan discusses a crucial history of US subversion of Syria's sovereignty even before the conclusion of WW2 starting with interference and covert operations by the OSS precursor to the CIA and then through the entire Cold War with Dr. Patrick Higgins, a Middle East historian, co-editor of Liberated Texts and member of the Anti-Imperialist Scholars Collective. His article "Gunning for Damascus: The US War on the Syrian Arab Republic" is mandatory reading and the state of the field on this dark history. <a href= "https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/19436149.2023.2199487?scroll=top&needAccess=true#abstractart">https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/19436149.2023.2199487?scroll=top&needAccess=true#abstractart</a></p> <p class="MsoNormal">Support the show on Patreon if you can (and get early access to episodes)! www.patreon.com/adnanhusain Or make a one-time donation to the show and Buy Me a Coffee: https://buymeacoffee.com/adnanhusain Like, subscribe, share! Also available in video on YouTube: https://youtube.com/@adnanhusainshow X: @adnanahusain Substack: adnanahusain.substack.com <a href="https://www.adnanhusain.org/">www.adnanhusain.org</a></p>]]></content:encoded>
      
      
      <enclosure url="https://traffic.libsyn.com/secure/guerrillahistory/higgins.mp3?dest-id=2463146" length="75113291" type="audio/mpeg" />
      <itunes:duration>01:18:00</itunes:duration>
      <itunes:explicit>true</itunes:explicit>
      
      <itunes:keywords />
      
      <itunes:season>6</itunes:season>
      
      
      <itunes:episode>38</itunes:episode>

      <title>The Future of Resistance w/ Ali Kadri</title>
      <itunes:title>The Future of Resistance w/ Ali Kadri</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 12 Sep 2025 10:34:09 +0000</pubDate>

      <description><![CDATA[<p>In this episode of Guerrilla History, Ali Kadri is back for another installment of our new mini-series with him!  This time, a fascinating discussion on The Future of Resistance.  If you missed our previous episode with him, <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/surplus-populations-and-the-political-economy-of-waste-w-ali-kadri"> Surplus Populations and the Political Economy of Waste</a>, be sure to check that out!  Also, stay tuned for more installments of this series!</p> <div class="page" title="Page 12"> <div class="layoutArea"> <div class="column"> <div class="page" title="Page 14"> <div class="layoutArea"> <div class="column"> <p><strong>Ali Kadri</strong> is an esteemed Professor at various institutions around the world, as well as the author of many important books including <em>Arab Development Denied: Dynamics of Accumulation by Wars of Encroachment</em>, <em><span role="heading" aria-level="4">The Accumulation of Waste: A Political Economy of Systemic Destruction, </span></em><span role="heading" aria-level= "4">and <em>The Unmaking of Arab Socialism.  </em></span></p> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> <p>Help support       <title>Stories of Resistance + Brazil Update w/ Michael Fox</title>
      <itunes:title>Stories of Resistance + Brazil Update w/ Michael Fox</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 05 Sep 2025 06:23:11 +0000</pubDate>

      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/stories-of-resistance-brazil-update-w-michael-fox]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<p>In this episode of Guerrilla History, we are joined by returning guest Michael Fox (whom you may remember from our episodes <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/the-rise-of-fascism-bolsonaro-the-brazilian-elections-w-michael-fox-dispatch"> The Rise of Fascism, Bolsonaro, & the Brazilian Elections</a> and  <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/american-imperialisms-shadow-on-latin-america-w-michael-fox"> American Imperialism's Shadow on Latin America w/ Michael Fox</a>) to discuss his fantastic new series <a href= "https://therealnews.com/stories-of-resistance">Stories of Resistance</a>, a collaboration with The Real News Network and provides short surveys of resistance throughout history and in the contemporary world.  Be sure to check this one out!</p> <div class="page" title="Page 12"> <div class="layoutArea"> <div class="column"> <div class="page" title="Page 14"> <div class="layoutArea"> <div class="column"> <p><strong>Michael Fox</strong> is a Brazil-based journalist, contributor to The World, former Editor of NACLA, and the host of the podcast series <a href= "https://therealnews.com/under-the-shadow">Under the Shadow</a> and  <a href= "https://therealnews.com/brazil-on-fire">Brazil on Fire</a>, and now also <a href= "https://therealnews.com/stories-of-resistance">Stories of Resistance</a>. Michael can be followed on Twitter <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/twitter.com/mfox_us">@mfox_us</a>, you can support his project on his <a href= "https://www.patreon.com/mfox">patreon</a> and follow his band <a href= "https://open.spotify.com/artist/0nexDyQCZI89JH8zsYu5wa">Monte Perdido</a>.</p> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> <p>Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a> </p> <p>We also have a (free!) <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.substack.com/p/guerrilla-history-newsletter-1"> newsletter</a> you can sign up for, and please note that <a href= "https://www.youtube.com/@Guerrilla_History">Guerrilla History now is uploading on YouTube</a> as well, so do us a favor, subscribe to the show and share some links from there so we can get helped out in the algorithms!!</p> <p>*As mentioned, you will be able to find <a href= "https://www.youtube.com/@TsarsandCommissars">Tsars and Commissars: From Rus to Modern Russia on YouTube</a>.</p>]]></description>

      <title>Surplus Populations and the Political Economy of Waste w/ Ali Kadri</title>
      <itunes:title>Surplus Populations and the Political Economy of Waste w/ Ali Kadri</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 29 Aug 2025 08:12:46 +0000</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[4d756982-66b0-49d5-a797-56ced9df1a45]]></guid>
      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/surplus-populations-and-the-political-economy-of-waste-w-ali-kadri]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<p>In this episode of Guerrilla History, we kick off a brilliant new mini-series with our friend, Dr. Ali Kadri!  Here, we discuss surplus populations and the political economy of waste.  We always hear terrific things about our conversations with Ali, and we are sure you will similarly love this one.  Be sure to stay tuned for the next installment of this mini-series, which will be on The Future of Resistance!</p> <div class="page" title="Page 12"> <div class="layoutArea"> <div class="column"> <div class="page" title="Page 14"> <div class="layoutArea"> <div class="column"> <p><strong>Ali Kadri</strong> is an esteemed Professor at various institutions around the world, as well as the author of many important books including <em>Arab Development Denied: Dynamics of Accumulation by Wars of Encroachment</em>, <em><span role="heading" aria-level="4">The Accumulation of Waste: A Political Economy of Systemic Destruction, </span></em><span role="heading" aria-level= "4">and <em>The Unmaking of Arab Socialism.  </em></span></p> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> <p>Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a> </p> <p>We also have a (free!) <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.substack.com/p/guerrilla-history-newsletter-1"> newsletter</a> you can sign up for, and please note that <a href= "https://www.youtube.com/@Guerrilla_History">Guerrilla History now is uploading on YouTube</a> as well, so do us a favor, subscribe to the show and share some links from there so we can get helped out in the algorithms!!</p> <p>*As mentioned, you will be able to find <a href= "https://www.youtube.com/@TsarsandCommissars">Tsars and Commissars: From Rus to Modern Russia on YouTube</a>.</p>]]></description>
      
      <content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>In this episode of Guerrilla History, we kick off a brilliant new mini-series with our friend, Dr. Ali Kadri! Here, we discuss surplus populations and the political economy of waste. We always hear terrific things about our conversations with Ali, and we are sure you will similarly love this one. Be sure to stay tuned for the next installment of this mini-series, which will be on The Future of Resistance!</p> <p>Ali Kadri is an esteemed Professor at various institutions around the world, as well as the author of many important books including <em>Arab Development Denied: Dynamics of Accumulation by Wars of Encroachment</em>, <em>The Accumulation of Waste: A Political Economy of Systemic Destruction, </em>and <em>The Unmaking of Arab Socialism. </em></p> <p>Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a> </p> <p>We also have a (free!) <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.substack.com/p/guerrilla-history-newsletter-1"> newsletter</a> you can sign up for, and please note that <a href= "https://www.youtube.com/@Guerrilla_History">Guerrilla History now is uploading on YouTube</a> as well, so do us a favor, subscribe to the show and share some links from there so we can get helped out in the algorithms!!</p> <p>*As mentioned, you will be able to find <a href= "https://www.youtube.com/@TsarsandCommissars">Tsars and Commissars: From Rus to Modern Russia on YouTube</a>.</p>]]></content:encoded>

    <item>
      <title>National Liberation Struggles &amp; the Agrarian Question w/ Max Ajl [REMASTERED]</title>
      <itunes:title>National Liberation Struggles &amp;amp; the Agrarian Question w/ Max Ajl [REMASTERED]</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 22 Aug 2025 07:21:03 +0000</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[7dbe3eee-556c-41b0-adfe-353ae0923892]]></guid>
      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/national-liberation-struggles-the-agrarian-question-w-max-ajl-remastered]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<p>In this episode of Guerrilla History, we bring on a good comrade of ours, Max Ajl (much overdue, we might add)!  Here, we get a primer on the agrarian question and discuss its importance to national liberation struggles globally!  Max is the perfect guest for this conversation, and we know you'll get a lot out of it.</p> <p>Max Ajl is is an associated researcher with the Tunisian Observatory for Food Sovereignty and the Environment, a researcher on decolonization, post-colonial planning, Arab dependency theory and food sovereignty at Ghent University, and the author of the outstanding <a href= "https://www.plutobooks.com/9780745341750/a-peoples-green-new-deal/">A People's Green New Deal</a>.  You can follow Max on twitter <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/twitter.com/maxajl">@maxajl</a>. </p> <p>Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a> </p>]]></description>
      
      <content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>In this episode of Guerrilla History, we bring on a good comrade of ours, Max Ajl (much overdue, we might add)! Here, we get a primer on the agrarian question and discuss its importance to national liberation struggles globally! Max is the perfect guest for this conversation, and we know you'll get a lot out of it.</p> <p>Max Ajl is is an associated researcher with the Tunisian Observatory for Food Sovereignty and the Environment, a researcher on decolonization, post-colonial planning, Arab dependency theory and food sovereignty at Ghent University, and the author of the outstanding <a href= "https://www.plutobooks.com/9780745341750/a-peoples-green-new-deal/">A People's Green New Deal</a>. You can follow Max on twitter <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/twitter.com/maxajl">@maxajl</a>. </p> <p>Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a> </p>]]></content:encoded>

    <item>
      <title>Yemen's History of Resisting Empire w/Isa Blumi, P. 1 [Adnan Husain Show]</title>
      <itunes:title>Yemen&#39;s History of Resisting Empire w/Isa Blumi, P. 1 [Adnan Husain Show]</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 15 Aug 2025 14:34:26 +0000</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[2934899d-2228-44b7-8f44-9bd415e8076b]]></guid>
      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/yemens-history-of-resisting-empire-wisa-blumi-p-1-adnan-husain-show]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<p>This week, we bring you an episode from our sister program The Adnan Husain Show.  Enjoy!</p> <hr /> <p class="MsoNormal">In this first part of a two part series, Adnan has an epic conversation with Dr. Isa Blumi, historian and Professor of Turkish and Middle Eastern Studies at Stockholm University, about Yemen's modern history of resisting colonialism geopolitically and global capitalism. Author of <em>Destroying Yemen: What Chaos in Arabia Tells Us about the World</em>, Dr. Blumi masterfully analyzes and integrates the geographic, social, economic, cultural, political and religious dimensions of Yemen's distinctive historical experience. If you want to understand why Ansarullah as a popular movement has taken leadership of active solidarity with the people of Gaza in confronting ZioAmerican empire, this episode will be indispensable.</p> <p class="MsoNormal">To consult more of Dr. Isa Blumi's recent work on Yemen and the Gulf region:</p> <p class="MsoNormal">Blumi, Isa. <em>Destroying Yemen: What chaos in Arabia tells us about the world</em>. Univ of California Press, 2018.</p> <p class="MsoNormal">Blumi, Isa. <em>Chaos in Yemen: Societal collapse and the new authoritarianism</em>. Routledge, 2010.</p> <table class="MsoNormalTable" border="0" width="438" cellspacing= "0" cellpadding="0"> <tbody> <tr> <td valign="top"> <p class="MsoNormal">Blumi, Isa. "The Gulf Cooperation Council (GCC)." In <em>Government and Politics of the Contemporary Middle East</em>, pp. 545-652. Routledge, 2023.</p> </td> </tr> <tr> <td valign="top"> </td> </tr> </tbody> </table> <p class="MsoNormal">Blumi, Isa, and Jaafar Alloul. "Guest-Editors' Introduction: Re-Worlding the Gulf: Anomaly as Geopolitical Function." <em>Middle East Critique</em> 34, no. 2 (2025): 181-202.</p> <p class="MsoNormal">Blumi, Isa. "Imperial Equivocations Britain's Temperamental Mobilization of the Caliphate, 1912-1924." <em>Rivista italiana di storia internazionale</em> 4, no. 1 (2021): 149-173.</p> <table class="MsoNormalTable" border="0" width="438" cellspacing= "0" cellpadding="0"> <tbody> <tr> <td valign="top"> <p class="MsoNormal">Blumi, Isa. "Iraqi ties to Yemen's demise: Complicating the 'Arab Cold War'in South Arabia." <em>Journal of Contemporary Iraq & the Arab World</em> 16, no. 3 (2022): 235-254.</p> </td> </tr> </tbody> </table> <p class="MsoNormal">Support the show on Patreon if you can (and get early access to episodes)! <br /> <a href= "https://www.patreon.com/adnanhusain">www.patreon.com/adnanhusain</a> </p> <p class="MsoNormal"><br /> Or make a one-time donation to the show and Buy Me a Coffee: <a href= "https://buymeacoffee.com/adnanhusain">https://buymeacoffee.com/adnanhusain</a></p> <p class="MsoNormal"><br /> Like, subscribe, share! <br /> Also available in video on YouTube: <br /> <a href= "https://youtube.com/@adnanhusainshow">https://youtube.com/@adnanhusainshow</a></p> <p class="MsoNormal">X: @adnanahusain</p> <p class="MsoNormal">Substack: adnanahusain.substack.com</p> <p class="MsoNormal">www.adnanhusain.org</p>]]></description>
      
      <content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>This week, we bring you an episode from our sister program The Adnan Husain Show. Enjoy!</p> <p class="MsoNormal">In this first part of a two part series, Adnan has an epic conversation with Dr. Isa Blumi, historian and Professor of Turkish and Middle Eastern Studies at Stockholm University, about Yemen's modern history of resisting colonialism geopolitically and global capitalism. Author of <em>Destroying Yemen: What Chaos in Arabia Tells Us about the World</em>, Dr. Blumi masterfully analyzes and integrates the geographic, social, economic, cultural, political and religious dimensions of Yemen's distinctive historical experience. If you want to understand why Ansarullah as a popular movement has taken leadership of active solidarity with the people of Gaza in confronting ZioAmerican empire, this episode will be indispensable.</p> <p class="MsoNormal">To consult more of Dr. Isa Blumi's recent work on Yemen and the Gulf region:</p> <p class="MsoNormal">Blumi, Isa. <em>Destroying Yemen: What chaos in Arabia tells us about the world</em>. Univ of California Press, 2018.</p> <p class="MsoNormal">Blumi, Isa. <em>Chaos in Yemen: Societal collapse and the new authoritarianism</em>. Routledge, 2010.</p> <p class="MsoNormal">Blumi, Isa. "The Gulf Cooperation Council (GCC)." In <em>Government and Politics of the Contemporary Middle East</em>, pp. 545-652. Routledge, 2023.</p> <p class="MsoNormal">Blumi, Isa, and Jaafar Alloul. "Iraqi ties to Yemen's demise: Complicating the 'Arab Cold War'in South Arabia." <em>Journal of Contemporary Iraq & the Arab World</em> 16, no. 3 (2022): 235-254.</p> <p class="MsoNormal">Support the show on Patreon if you can (and get early access to episodes)! <a href= "https://www.patreon.com/adnanhusain">www.patreon.com/adnanhusain</a> </p> <p class="MsoNormal"> Or make a one-time donation to the show and Buy Me a Coffee: <a href= "https://buymeacoffee.com/adnanhusain">https://buymeacoffee.com/adnanhusain</a></p> <p class="MsoNormal"> Like, subscribe, share!     <item>
      <title>The History of Modern Yemen &amp; the Struggle Against Zionist Imperialism w/ Shireen Al-Adeimi &amp; Rune "Aldanmarki" Agerhus [Re-Release]</title>
      <itunes:title>The History of Modern Yemen &amp;amp; the Struggle Against Zionist Imperialism w/ Shireen Al-Adeimi &amp;amp; Rune &quot;Aldanmarki&quot; Agerhus</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 08 Aug 2025 13:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[9e0030b0-a911-4ad2-8a4e-f54480662356]]></guid>
      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/the-history-of-modern-yemen-the-struggle-against-zionist-imperialism-w-shireen-al-adeimi-rune-aldanmarki-agerhus-re-release]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<p>In this blockbuster episode of Guerrilla History (originally released Mar 1, 2024), we bring on two outstanding guests to discuss the modern history of Yemen, as well as their ongoing struggle against Zionist imperialism and opposition to the genocide in Gaza.   Shireen and Rune bring fantastic insight and analysis, making this complicated history accessible and utilizable for individuals in our movement against imperialism in all forms, and Zionist imperialism specifically at this moment.  Be sure to take in all that our guests say, and share this episode with comrades you believe would similarly benefit!</p> <p><strong>Shireen Al-Adeimi </strong>is an assistant professor of language and literacy at Michigan State University, and is an expert on the war and humanitarian crisis in her country of birth, Yemen. She writes for <a href= "https://inthesetimes.com/authors/shireen-al-adeimi">In These Times</a> and <a href= "https://responsiblestatecraft.org/author/shireenaladeimi/">Responsible Statecraft</a>, and speaks and writes frequently on Yemen for media globally.  You can follow her on twitter <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/twitter.com/shireen818">@shireen818</a>, and help support the <a href= "https://yemenfoundation.org/">Yemen Relief & Reconstruction Foundation</a>.</p> <p><strong>Rune Agerhus </strong>Political Commentator & Member of the International Commission for Solidarity with Yemen (ICSY).  He is the founder of <a href= "https://twitter.com/HamraBooks">Hamra Books</a>, which Iskra Books and Guerrilla History have just <a href= "https://x.com/guerrilla_pod/status/1760336754081480908?s=46">announced a partnership with in order to release materials from the socialist People's Democratic Republic of Yemen</a>. You can follow him on twitter <a href= "https://twitter.com/Aldanmarki">@Aldanmarki</a>.</p> <p>Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a> </p> <p>We also have a (free!) <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.substack.com/p/guerrilla-history-newsletter-1"> newsletter</a> you can sign up for, and please note that <a href= "https://www.youtube.com/@Guerrilla_History">Guerrilla History now is uploading on YouTube</a> as well, so do us a favor, subscribe to the show and share some links from there so we can get helped out in the algorithms!</p>]]></description>
      
      <content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>In this blockbuster episode of Guerrilla History (originally released Mar 1, 2024), we bring on two outstanding guests to discuss the modern history of Yemen, as well as their ongoing struggle against Zionist imperialism and opposition to the genocide in Gaza. Shireen and Rune bring fantastic insight and analysis, making this complicated history accessible and utilizable for individuals in our movement against imperialism in all forms, and Zionist imperialism specifically at this moment.       <title>Coups, Oil, the CIA, and Arab Nationalism in Iraq w/ Brandon Wolfe-Hunnicutt [REMASTERED]</title>
      <itunes:title>Coups, Oil, the CIA, and Arab Nationalism in Iraq w/ Brandon Wolfe-Hunnicutt [REMASTERED]</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 01 Aug 2025 13:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[b980bac9-2aae-4bb5-9222-7bbc71ccaebc]]></guid>
      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/-coups-oil-the-cia-and-arab-nationalism-in-iraq-w-brandon-wolfe-hunnicutt-remastered]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<p>In this fascinating remastered episode (originally released Jul 8, 2022), we talk with Professor Brandon Wolfe-Hunnicutt about the numerous coups of Iraq from 1953-1968 (and the CIA/State Department role in these) amidst the background of rising Arab nationalist politics and pushes by several groups for nationalization of Iraqi oil.  A fantastic discussion based off of Brandon's equally fabulous book <em>The Paranoid Style in American Diplomacy: Oil and Arab Nationalism in Iraq</em>!</p> <p>Brandon Wolfe-Hunnicutt is a historian at California State University, Stanislas.  You can (and should!) get <em>The Paranoid Style in American Diplomacy: Oil and Arab Nationalism in Iraq</em> from Stanford University Press <a href= "https://www.sup.org/books/title/?id=26330">https://www.sup.org/books/title/?id=26330</a> </p> <p>Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a> </p> <p>We also have a (free!) <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.substack.com/p/guerrilla-history-newsletter-1"> newsletter</a> you can sign up for, and please note that <a href= "https://www.youtube.com/@Guerrilla_History">Guerrilla History now is uploading on YouTube</a> as well, so do us a favor, subscribe to the show and share some links from there so we can get helped out in the algorithms!</p>]]></description>

      <title>Women in Nepal's Civil War w/ Hisila Yami [REMASTERED]</title>
      <itunes:title>Women in Nepal&#39;s Civil War w/ Hisila Yami [REMASTERED]</itunes:title>

    <item>
      <title>Lawfare and Imperialism w/ Nina Farnia</title>
      <itunes:title>Lawfare and Imperialism w/ Nina Farnia</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 11 Jul 2025 08:18:37 +0000</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[b811185d-d896-47ac-930e-5404fbe0e291]]></guid>
      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/lawfare-and-imperialism-w-nina-farnia]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<p>In this episode of Guerrilla History, we bring back fan favorite Ali Kadri to discuss a very important topic - Sanctions as Genocide!  Long time listeners will remember that we previously had a series on Sanctions As War, and this episode is a great accompaniment to those past conversations.  Similarly, this goes very well with our other conversations with Ali (<a href= "https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/lebanon-vs-zioimperialism-w-ali-kadri-rania-khalek">Lebanon vs. Zioimperialism</a> and <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/palestine-war-occupation-and-proletarianization-w-ali-kadri"> Palestine - War, Occupation, and Proletarianization</a>).  We will be really excited to also have Ali back several more times for an upcoming mini-series!</p> <div class="page" title="Page 12"> <div class="layoutArea"> <div class="column"> <div class="page" title="Page 14"> <div class="layoutArea"> <div class="column"> <p><strong>Nina Farnia</strong> is a legal historian, focusing on the role of modern imperialism in U.S. law and politics<span role= "heading" aria-level="4"><em>.  </em>Her forthcoming book <em>Imperialism and Resistance </em>will be coming out next year from Stanford University Press, so stay tuned for that!  You can find more of her work on her <a href= "https://www.albanylaw.edu/faculty/faculty-directory/nina-farnia">Albany Law webpage</a>, and you can follow her on twitter <a href= "twitter.com/NinaFarnia">@NinaFarnia</a>.</span></p> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> <p>Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a> </p> <p>We also have a (free!) <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.substack.com/p/guerrilla-history-newsletter-1"> newsletter</a> you can sign up for, and please note that <a href= "https://www.youtube.com/@Guerrilla_History">Guerrilla History now is uploading on YouTube</a> as well, so do us a favor, subscribe to the show and share some links from there so we can get helped out in the algorithms!!</p>]]></description>
      
      <content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>In this episode of Guerrilla History, we bring back fan favorite Ali Kadri to discuss a very important topic - Sanctions as Genocide! Long time listeners will remember that we previously had a series on Sanctions As War, and this episode is a great accompaniment to those past conversations. Similarly, this goes very well with our other conversations with Ali (<a href= "https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/lebanon-vs-zioimperialism-w-ali-kadri-rania-khalek">Lebanon vs. Zioimperialism</a> and <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/palestine-war-occupation-and-proletarianization-w-ali-kadri"> Palestine - War, Occupation, and Proletarianization</a>). We will be really excited to also have Ali back several more times for an upcoming mini-series!</p> <p>Nina Farnia is a legal historian, focusing on the role of modern imperialism in U.S. law and politics<em>. </em>Her forthcoming book <em>Imperialism and Resistance </em>will be coming out next year from Stanford University Press, so stay tuned for that! You can find more of her work on her <a href= "https://www.albanylaw.edu/faculty/faculty-directory/nina-farnia">Albany Law webpage</a>, and you can follow her on twitter <a href= "twitter.com/NinaFarnia">@NinaFarnia</a>.</p> <p>Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a> </p> <p>We also have a (free!) <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.substack.com/p/guerrilla-history-newsletter-1"> newsletter</a> you can sign up for, and please note that <a href= "https://www.youtube.com/@Guerrilla_History">Guerrilla History now is uploading on YouTube</a> as well, so do us a favor, subscribe to the show and share some links from there so we can get helped out in the algorithms!!</p>]]></content:encoded>

    <item>
      <title>Histories of Resistance in LA from 60's to Today w/ Gerald Horne</title>
      <itunes:title>Histories of Resistance in LA from 60&#39;s to Today w/ Gerald Horne</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 04 Jul 2025 05:43:19 +0000</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[9db18691-08be-4b94-8b7c-7462ffeb5d17]]></guid>
      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/histories-of-resistance-in-la-from-60s-to-today-w-gerald-horne]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<p>In this episode, we present a crossover of Guerrilla History and the Adnan Husain Show.  Here, Dr. Gerald Horne joins Adnan and Henry to discuss his recent book, Armed Struggle?: Panthers and Communists, black Nationalists and Liberals in Southern California, Through the Sixties and Seventies. As ever, Professor Horne connects the histories of organizing and resistance against racial capitalism to the contemporary situation, including the LA uprisings against ICE raids and developments against neocolonialism and imperialism in West Asia. A wide-ranging conversation with the inimitable Dr. Horne ranged across the histories of class politics, struggles against racism, and geopolitics to consider the prospects for resistance locally and internationally in contemporary movements for justice.</p> <div class="page" title="Page 12"> <div class="layoutArea"> <div class="column"> <div class="page" title="Page 14"> <div class="layoutArea"> <div class="column"> <p><strong>Gerald Horne</strong> is the John J. and Rebecca Moores Chair of History and African American Studies at the University of Houston.  His research interests are unbelievably varied, encompassing biographies of W.E.B. Du Bois and Paul Robeson, to The Haitian Revolution, to Hollywood in the '30s-'50s, to Jazz and Justice.  Be sure to check out his bibliography, you're certain to find something that interests you!</p> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> <p>Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a> </p> <p>We also have a (free!) <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.substack.com/p/guerrilla-history-newsletter-1"> newsletter</a> you can sign up for, and please note that <a href= "https://www.youtube.com/@Guerrilla_History">Guerrilla History now is uploading on YouTube</a> as well, so do us a favor, subscribe to the show and share some links from there so we can get helped out in the algorithms!!</p> <p>*As mentioned, you will be able to find <a href= "https://www.youtube.com/@TsarsandCommissars">Tsars and Commissars: From Rus to Modern Russia soon on YouTube</a>.</p>]]></description>
      
      <content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>In this episode, we present a crossover of Guerrilla History and the Adnan Husain Show. Here, Dr. Gerald Horne joins Adnan and Henry to discuss his recent book, Armed Struggle?: Panthers and Communists, black Nationalists and Liberals in Southern California, Through the Sixties and Seventies. As ever, Professor Horne connects the histories of organizing and resistance against racial capitalism to the contemporary situation, including the LA uprisings against ICE raids and developments against neocolonialism and imperialism in West Asia. A wide-ranging conversation with the inimitable Dr. Horne ranged across the histories of class politics, struggles against racism, and geopolitics to consider the prospects for resistance locally and internationally in contemporary movements for justice.</p> <p>Gerald Horne is the John J. and Rebecca Moores Chair of History and African American Studies at the University of Houston. His research interests are unbelievably varied, encompassing biographies of W.E.B. Du Bois and Paul Robeson, to The Haitian Revolution, to Hollywood in the '30s-'50s, to Jazz and Justice. Be sure to check out his bibliography, you're certain to find something that interests you!</p> <p>Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a> </p> <p>We also have a (free!) <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.substack.com/p/guerrilla-history-newsletter-1"> newsletter</a> you can sign up for, and please note that <a href= "https://www.youtube.com/@Guerrilla_History">Guerrilla History now is uploading on YouTube</a> as well, so do us a favor, subscribe to the show and share some links from there so we can get helped out in the algorithms!!</p> <p>*As mentioned, you will be able to find <a href= "https://www.youtube.com/@TsarsandCommissars">Tsars and Commissars: From Rus to Modern Russia soon on YouTube</a>.</p>]]></content:encoded>

      <title>Sanctions as Genocide w/ Ali Kadri</title>
      <itunes:title>Sanctions as Genocide w/ Ali Kadri</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 27 Jun 2025 09:50:29 +0000</pubDate>

      <description><![CDATA[<p>In this episode of Guerrilla History, we bring back fan favorite Ali Kadri to discuss a very important topic - Sanctions as Genocide!  Long time listeners will remember that we previously had a series on Sanctions As War, and this episode is a great accompaniment to those past conversations.  Similarly, this goes very well with our other conversations with Ali (<a href= "https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/lebanon-vs-zioimperialism-w-ali-kadri-rania-khalek">Lebanon vs. Zioimperialism</a> and <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/palestine-war-occupation-and-proletarianization-w-ali-kadri"> Palestine -       <content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>In this episode of Guerrilla History, we bring back fan favorite Ali Kadri to discuss a very important topic - Sanctions as Genocide!       <title>Palestine 1492 w/ Linda Quiquivix</title>
      <itunes:title>Palestine 1492 w/ Linda Quiquivix</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 20 Jun 2025 14:52:17 +0000</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[17586061-38eb-4b0a-8c97-cbd3d558d411]]></guid>
      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/palestine-1492-w-linda-quiquivix]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<p>In this great episode of Guerrilla History, we have a discussion with Linda Quiquivix about her study and book <a href= "https://wildoxbooks.org/books/palestine-1492/">Palestine 1492: A Report Back</a>, which is a study of 500 years of the struggle for life in words, maps, and images in the seven cardinal directions in Mayan philosophy and in the spiral that is time.  This was such an interesting conversation, and one which we think you will find really useful!</p> <div class="page" title="Page 12"> <div class="layoutArea"> <div class="column"> <div class="page" title="Page 14"> <div class="layoutArea"> <div class="column"> <p><strong>Linda Quiquivix</strong> is a geographer and popular educator of Maya-Mam roots raised by Palestinians, Zapatistas, Panthers, and jaguars. Learn more about her work at <a href= "https://www.quiqui.org/" target="_blank" rel= "noreferrer noopener">quiqui.org</a>.</p> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> <p>Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a> </p> <p>We also have a (free!) <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.substack.com/p/guerrilla-history-newsletter-1"> newsletter</a> you can sign up for, and please note that <a href= "https://www.youtube.com/@Guerrilla_History">Guerrilla History now is uploading on YouTube</a> as well, so do us a favor, subscribe to the show and share some links from there so we can get helped out in the algorithms!!</p> <p>*As mentioned, you will be able to find <a href= "https://www.youtube.com/@TsarsandCommissars">Tsars and Commissars: From Rus to Modern Russia soon on YouTube</a>.</p>]]></description>
      
      <content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>In this great episode of Guerrilla History, we have a discussion with Linda Quiquivix about her study and book <a href= "https://wildoxbooks.org/books/palestine-1492/">Palestine 1492: A Report Back</a>, which is a study of 500 years of the struggle for life in words, maps, and images in the seven cardinal directions in Mayan philosophy and in the spiral that is time.       <description><![CDATA[<p>This remastered episode of Guerrilla History was a continuation of our Sanctions As War miniseries.  In this fascinating episode, we had a discussion with Professor Muhammad Sahimi on the history and the impacts of sanctions on Iran, which is both an immensely enlightening and heartbreaking conversation.  This episode is particularly timely given the current situation in Iran.  Be sure to also stay turned for our analysis on the situation in Iran, coming soon!</p> <div class="page" title="Page 12"> <div class="layoutArea"> <div class="column"> <div class="page" title="Page 14"> <div class="layoutArea"> <div class="column"> <p><strong>Muhammad Sahimi</strong> is a Professor at the University of Southern California, where he analyses Iran's political development, its nuclear program, and its foreign policy. From 2008 to 2012 he was the lead political analyst at Frontline/Tehran Bureau website.</p> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> <p>Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a> </p> <p>We also have a (free!) <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.substack.com/p/guerrilla-history-newsletter-1">newsletter</a> you can sign up for, and please note that <a href= "https://www.youtube.com/@Guerrilla_History">Guerrilla History now is uploading on YouTube</a> as well, so do us a favor, subscribe to the show and share some links from there so we can get helped out in the algorithms!!</p> <p>*As mentioned in the intro, you will be able to find <a href= "https://www.youtube.com/@TsarsandCommissars">Tsars and Commissars: From Rus to Modern Russia soon on YouTube</a>.</p>]]></description>

    <item>
      <title>The Adnan Husain Show: The Longue Durée: Palestine in World History</title>
      <itunes:title>The Adnan Husain Show: The Longue Durée: Palestine in World History</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 06 Jun 2025 05:29:50 +0000</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[909431f7-199b-4c42-867c-4f7c00abe7b4]]></guid>
      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/the-adnan-husain-show-the-longue-dure-palestine-in-world-history]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<p>For the next two weeks, we will be introducing (or reintroducing) our new sister shows.  This week, we will be presenting Part 1 of a 7 part series on <a href= "https://www.youtube.com/@adnanhusainshow">The Adnan Husain Show</a> titled Palestine and the World.  Next week, we will present the introduction of a new 25 part series that Henry is cohosting with a Russian historian on Russian history titled Tsars and Commissars: From Rus to Modern Russia.  Be sure to subscribe to Adnan's show and to stay tuned for Tsars and Commissars updates from Henry on twitter (<a href= "twitter.com/huck1995">@Huck1995</a>).</p> <p>Also, please note that <a href= "https://www.youtube.com/@Guerrilla_History">Guerrilla History now is uploading on YouTube</a> as well, so do us a favor, subscribe to the show and share some links from there so we can get helped out in the algorithms!</p> <hr /> <p>Part 1 of Palestine and the World: History in a Time of Genocide (Denial) examines the premodern paradigms of Latin Christendom's relationship to Jews and Muslims, Judaism and Islam, over centuries since the time of the Crusades and the establishment of the Latin Crusader Kingdom of Jerusalem. Dr. Ariel Salzmann and Adnan discuss a Mediterranean history from the medieval crusades to the "Reconquista" in Iberia into the early modern period and reflect on the transformation in the Latin West from religious difference between Christian and non-Christian as predominant to the elaboration of new ethno-racial forms of exclusion in the shared roots of antisemitism, Islamophobia and other forms of racism.</p>]]></description>
      
      <content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>For the next two weeks, we will be introducing (or reintroducing) our new sister shows. This week, we will be presenting Part 1 of a 7 part series on <a href= "https://www.youtube.com/@adnanhusainshow">The Adnan Husain Show</a> titled Palestine and the World. Next week, we will present the introduction of a new 25 part series that Henry is cohosting with a Russian historian on Russian history titled Tsars and Commissars: From Rus to Modern Russia. Be sure to subscribe to Adnan's show and to stay tuned for Tsars and Commissars updates from Henry on twitter (<a href= "twitter.com/huck1995">@Huck1995</a>).</p> <p>Also, please note that <a href= "https://www.youtube.com/@Guerrilla_History">Guerrilla History now is uploading on YouTube</a> as well, so do us a favor, subscribe to the show and share some links from there so we can get helped out in the algorithms!</p> <p>Part 1 of Palestine and the World: History in a Time of Genocide (Denial) examines the premodern paradigms of Latin Christendom's relationship to Jews and Muslims, Judaism and Islam, over centuries since the time of the Crusades and the establishment of the Latin Crusader Kingdom of Jerusalem. Dr. Ariel Salzmann and Adnan discuss a Mediterranean history from the medieval crusades to the "Reconquista" in Iberia into the early modern period and reflect on the transformation in the Latin West from religious difference between Christian and non-Christian as predominant to the elaboration of new ethno-racial forms of exclusion in the shared roots of antisemitism, Islamophobia and other forms of racism.</p>]]></content:encoded>
