    <item>
      <title>Apartheid (AR&amp;D Ep. 9)</title>
      <itunes:title>Apartheid (AR&amp;amp;D Ep. 9)</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 30 May 2025 11:10:31 +0000</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[45584812-d28f-4251-9bd1-7f5733d5d612]]></guid>
      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/apartheid-ard-ep-9]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<div dir="auto"><span dir="auto">The following episode of our African Revolutions and Decolonization series is a massive one, two former episodes on Apartheid edited together into a giant conversation.  Information on each of the episodes below:</span></div> <div dir="auto"> <p>The first is a crossover episode that we had done in collaboration with our sister podcast RevLeft Radio, we brought on Ashley Fataar to provide a primer into Apartheid in the South African context, and where we also began to explore some of the parallels to the apartheid that the settler-colonial state of Israel is enforcing in occupied Palestine today. </p> <p><strong>Ashley Fataar</strong> is a long time socialist activist and writer based in South Africa.  If you would like to get in touch with Ashley, you can reach him via email at <a href= "mailto:ash.fataar@gmail.com">ash.fataar@gmail.com</a>.  </p> <p>After that, we have the 2023 Revolutionary Guerrilla Menace get-together, also known as the <em>Rev Left Family Annual Collab</em> (<a href= "https://revolutionaryleftradio.libsyn.com/">Rev Left</a>+<a href= "https://redmenace.libsyn.com/">Red Menace</a>+<a href= "https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/">Guerrilla History</a>), where Alyson, Henry, Adnan, and Breht sat down for a deep dive on South African Apartheid. Together they discussed its euro-colonialist origins, explained the significance of the Boer Wars, defined and explicated the origins of apartheid, explored the political economy of apartheid and how brutal racism shaped it, examined the multi-faceted indigenous resistance to apartheid, analyzed the end of formal apartheid as well as its ongoing legacy in post-apartheid South Africa, and tried to extract important lessons from this history to apply to the ongoing struggle in Palestine.</p> </div> <div dir="auto"> </div> <div dir="auto"><span dir="auto">Subscribe to our Substack (free!) to keep up to date with what we are doing.  With so many episodes coming in this series (and beyond), you won't want to miss anything, so get the updates straight to your inbox.  <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/guerrillahistory.substack.com"> guerrillahistory.substack.com</a></span></div> <p>Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a> </p>]]></description>
      
      <content:encoded><![CDATA[The following episode of our African Revolutions and Decolonization series is a massive one, two former episodes on Apartheid edited together into a giant conversation. Information on each of the episodes below: <p>The first is a crossover episode that we had done in collaboration with our sister podcast RevLeft Radio, we brought on Ashley Fataar to provide a primer into Apartheid in the South African context, and where we also began to explore some of the parallels to the apartheid that the settler-colonial state of Israel is enforcing in occupied Palestine today. </p> <p>Ashley Fataar is a long time socialist activist and writer based in South Africa. If you would like to get in touch with Ashley, you can reach him via email at <a href= "mailto:ash.fataar@gmail.com">ash.fataar@gmail.com</a>. </p> <p>After that, we have the 2023 Revolutionary Guerrilla Menace get-together, also known as the <em>Rev Left Family Annual Collab</em> (<a href= "https://revolutionaryleftradio.libsyn.com/">Rev Left</a>+<a href= "https://redmenace.libsyn.com/">Red Menace</a>+<a href= "https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/">Guerrilla History</a>), where Alyson, Henry, Adnan, and Breht sat down for a deep dive on South African Apartheid. Together they discussed its euro-colonialist origins, explained the significance of the Boer Wars, defined and explicated the origins of apartheid, explored the political economy of apartheid and how brutal racism shaped it, examined the multi-faceted indigenous resistance to apartheid, analyzed the end of formal apartheid as well as its ongoing legacy in post-apartheid South Africa, and tried to extract important lessons from this history to apply to the ongoing struggle in Palestine.</p> Subscribe to our Substack (free!) to keep up to date with what we are doing. With so many episodes coming in this series (and beyond), you won't want to miss anything, so get the updates straight to your inbox. <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/guerrillahistory.substack.com"> guerrillahistory.substack.com</a> <p>Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a> </p>]]></content:encoded>

    <item>
      <title>NATO's Campaign Against Yugoslavia, &amp; Relevance to Today w/ Kit Klarenberg &amp; Nemanja Lukić</title>
      <itunes:title>NATO&#39;s Campaign Against Yugoslavia, &amp;amp; Relevance to Today w/ Kit Klarenberg &amp;amp; Nemanja Lukić</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 23 May 2025 07:58:37 +0000</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[d3caec71-4eec-4ca0-80e1-6c2a01c2621b]]></guid>
      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/natos-campaign-against-yugoslavia-relevance-to-today-w-kit-klarenberg-nemanja-luki-0]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<p>In this fascinating episode of Guerrilla History, we bring on Kit Klarenberg of The Grayzone to discuss the NATO campaign against Yugoslavia, its relevance to today, <a href= "https://www.kitklarenberg.com/p/collapsing-empire-the-delusion-of">and the delusion of US air power</a>!  We are also lucky to be joined by Nemanja Lukić as a guest host for this episode.  In addition to being a keen analyst (<a href= "https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/archiving-arghiri-emmanuels-works-w-the-arghiri-emmanuel-association">and former guest of Guerrilla History</a>), Nemanja personally lived through the bombing campaign.  This is a terrific discussion with plenty of history, analysis, and connections being drawn between this event of the past and the ongoing genocide in Gaza.  This is an important one, you won't want to miss a minute!</p> <p><strong>Kit Klarenberg</strong> is an investigative journalist and the UK Lead at The Grayzone.  He also runs his personal site <a href="https://www.kitklarenberg.com/">Global Delinquents</a> and can be found on twitter <a href= "twitter.com/KitKlarenberg">@KitKlarenberg</a>.</p> <p><strong>Nemanja Lukić </strong>is a Yugoslav anti-imperialist activist who runs the <a href= "https://anti-imperialist.net/">Anti-Imperialist Network website</a>. You can also follow Anti-Imp Net on twitter <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/twitter.com/antiimpnet">@antiimpnet</a>.  Additionally, you should check out the article that Nemanja mentioned that he coauthored with our friend (<a href= "https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/tricontinentals-early-1967-71-socio-ecological-dimensions-w-alejandro-pedregal">and former guest</a>) Alejandro Pedregal here.</p> <p>Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a> </p>]]></description>

      <title>Time with the Red Army Faction w/ Margrit Schiller [REMASTERED]</title>
      <itunes:title>Time with the Red Army Faction w/ Margrit Schiller [REMASTERED]</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 09 May 2025 08:27:25 +0000</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[04e5dabc-5fab-482b-8fc8-ff8fbbcc367f]]></guid>
      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/time-with-the-red-army-faction-w-margrit-schiller-remastered-0]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<p>In this remastered episode of Guerrilla History (originally released in June 2022), we bring on a very special guest, Margrit Schiller!  Margrit was associated early on with the Red Army Faction, before being imprisoned and tortured by the West German state, being forced into exile in Cuba and Uruguay, and then having to move back to Germany more or less against her will.  A fascinating life story from someone just as committed to the struggle as ever!</p> <p><strong>Margrit Schiller</strong> is author of <em>Remembering the Armed Struggle: My Time with the Red Army Faction.</em>  We highly recommend picking yourself up a copy from PM Press (<a href= "https://pmpress.org/index.php?l=product_detail&p=1195">https://pmpress.org/index.php?l=product_detail&p=1195</a>).  Margrit's struggles within and against this system continue, and grabbing a copy of her book is a good way to help while we are still forced to operate within capitalism.</p> <p>Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a> </p>]]></description>
      
      <content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>In this remastered episode of Guerrilla History (originally released in June 2022), we bring on a very special guest, Margrit Schiller! Margrit was associated early on with the Red Army Faction, before being imprisoned and tortured by the West German state, being forced into exile in Cuba and Uruguay, and then having to move back to Germany more or less against her will. A fascinating life story from someone just as committed to the struggle as ever!</p> <p>Margrit Schiller is author of <em>Remembering the Armed Struggle: My Time with the Red Army Faction.</em> We highly recommend picking yourself up a copy from PM Press (<a href= "https://pmpress.org/index.php?l=product_detail&p=1195">https://pmpress.org/index.php?l=product_detail&p=1195</a>).       <content:encoded><![CDATA[With this episode of Guerrilla History, we bring you another fascinating case study in our series African Revolutions and Decolonization. This time, a contemporary struggle - the struggle against Africa's last absolute monarchy - Swaziland. We are fortunate to be joined by guest host Ruehl Muller, senior lecturer/associate professor at the Institute of Creativity and Innovation at Xiamen University in China, who has been in contact with the CPS for quite some time. We are also joined by guest Bafanabakhe Sacolo of the Communist Party of Swaziland. A brilliant discussion, and one which you will certainly want to listen to, as our next episode in the AR&D series is on cultural revolution in Swaziland! Also subscribe to our Substack (free!) to keep up to date with what we are doing. With so many episodes coming in this series (and beyond), you won't want to miss anything, so get the updates straight to your inbox. <a href= "guerrillahistory.substack.com">guerrillahistory.substack.com</a> Bafanabakhe Sacolo is National Organizing Secretary<em> </em>of the Communist Party of Swaziland. You can keep up to date with the CPS by following them <a href="https://www.facebook.com/CPSwaziland/">on Facebook</a>, <a href="https://twitter.com/CPSwaziland">on Twitter</a>, or by checking out <a href= "https://communistpartyofswaziland.wordpress.com/">their website</a>. Ruehl Muller is senior lecturer/associate professor at the Institute of Creativity and Innovation at Xiamen University in China, and the editor of the fantastic <a href= "https://www.iskrabooks.org/building-a-peoples-art">Building a People's Art: Selected Works of Trường Chinh and Tố Hữu</a> (buy a physical copy or download the free PDF from <a href= "iskrabooks.org">Iskra Books</a>). <p>Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a> </p>]]></content:encoded>

    <item>
      <title>Indigenous Methodologies w/ Sardana Nikolaeva &amp; Masha Kardashevskaya</title>
      <itunes:title>Indigenous Methodologies w/ Sardana Nikolaeva &amp;amp; Masha Kardashevskaya</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 25 Apr 2025 08:23:56 +0000</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[d8e620bb-40c4-4106-9279-edfd01876b45]]></guid>
      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/indigenous-methodologies-w-sardana-nikolaeva-masha-kardashevskaya]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<div dir="auto"><span dir="auto"><span dir="auto">In this episode of Guerrilla History, we have two fantastic guests, and a continuation of our sporadic Sources and Methods series of episodes!  This time, we bring back Dr. Sardana Nikolaeva (whom you will remember from our recent e<span style= "font-size: 12pt;">pisode</span></span></span> <span style= "font-size: 12pt;"><a class="read_more" href= "https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/indigenous-diamonds-of-russias-sakha-republic-w-sardana-nikolaeva" data-iframe-id="embed_35889835">Indigenous Diamonds of Russia's Sakha Republic</a>), and bring on Dr. Masha Kardashevskaya for the first time.  They discuss the work they are doing on indigenous methodologies, which is based off of their studies of indigenous populations in Russia's Sakha Republic, in Indonesia, and in Canada. A really fascinating conversation, and much to learn, we hope you find it useful!</span></div> <p><strong>Sardana Nikolaeva</strong> is a post-doctoral fellow at the University of Toronto, where she is an indigenous anthropologist studying indigeneity, indigenous methodologies, extractivism, and more.  She cowrote the wonderful paper we discussed in our previous episode with her, which you should read here: <a href= "https://www.ziibiinglab.org/indigenous-diamonds">https://www.ziibiinglab.org/indigenous-diamonds</a></p> <p><strong>Masha Kardashevskaya</strong> is a scholar of peace and conflict studies who has been studying indigenous groups across multiple continents. While Masha doesn't use social media, she and Sardana are starting a podcast imminently, which we will share the information about on our various social media platforms when it is up, so stay tuned!</p> <div dir="auto">Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a> </div>]]></description>

      <title>The Egyptian Revolution &amp; Nasser's Era w/ Ahmad Shokr (AR&amp;D Ep. 7)</title>
      <itunes:title>The Egyptian Revolution &amp;amp; Nasser&#39;s Era w/ Ahmad Shokr (AR&amp;amp;D Ep. 7)</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 18 Apr 2025 04:09:53 +0000</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[cbb405a3-be9b-4eea-975d-87d4f139d42d]]></guid>
      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/the-egyptian-revolution-nassers-era-w-ahmad-shokr-ard-ep-7]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<div dir="auto"><span dir="auto">With this episode of Guerrilla History, we roll into our next case study in our series African Revolutions and Decolonization</span><span dir="auto">.  Here, we turn our focus to Egypt, and particularly the 23 July Revolution in 1952 and the rise of Nasser.  However, to tell this story, we turn back to the pre-colonial era, discuss the British colonial period, and the post-independence monarchy before getting to the Free Officers Movement.  A LOT of history covered here, and a really fascinating conversation with the terrific <a href= "twitter.com/ahmadshokr">Prof. Ahmad Shokr</a>!  We're sure you'll learn a lot here, and be sure to stay tuned for the next episode of our AR&D series, which is a deep examination of Nasserism both domestically and regionally!</span></div> <div dir="auto"> </div> <div dir="auto"><span dir="auto">Also subscribe to our Substack (free!) to keep up to date with what we are doing.  With so many episodes coming in this series (and beyond), you won't want to miss anything, so get the updates straight to your inbox.  <a href= "guerrillahistory.substack.com">guerrillahistory.substack.com</a></span></div> <div dir="auto"> </div> <div dir="auto"><strong>Ahmad Shokr</strong> is a professor at Swarthmore College, and is a historian of the modern Middle East who researches (among other things) the history of capitalism, empire, and decolonization.  He is author of the soon-to-be-released  <a href= "https://www.sup.org/books/harvests-liberation" target="_blank" rel="noopener" data-saferedirecturl= "https://www.google.com/url?q=https://www.sup.org/books/harvests-liberation&source=gmail&ust=1736431003204000&usg=AOvVaw2HR_MPOyzgidPMHpzneexQ"><em>Harvests of Liberation: Cotton, Capitalism, and the End of Empire in Egypt</em></a> (out in May).  Follow him on twitter to keep up with his work <a href= "twitter.com/ahmadshokr">@ahmadshokr</a></div> <p>Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a> </p>]]></description>
      
      <content:encoded><![CDATA[With this episode of Guerrilla History, we roll into our next case study in our series African Revolutions and Decolonization.     <item>
      <title>Media Narratives &amp; Hegemonic Discourses w/ Greg Shupak &amp; Stuart Davis</title>
      <itunes:title>Media Narratives &amp;amp; Hegemonic Discourses w/ Greg Shupak &amp;amp; Stuart Davis</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 11 Apr 2025 09:49:02 +0000</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[f3332b28-7830-4bda-a4e4-01b6784e66cd]]></guid>
      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/media-narratives-hegemonic-discourses-w-greg-shupak-stuart-davis]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<div dir="auto"><span dir="auto">In this episode of Guerrilla History, we bring back two outstanding guests, Stuart Davis (whom you will remember from our episode <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/sanctions-as-war-w-immanuel-ness-stuart-davis"> Sanctions As War</a> (alongside Manny Ness)), and Greg Shupak (whom you will remember from our episode <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/the-history-and-impact-of-sanctions-on-syria-w-greg-shupak">The History and Impact of Sanctions on Syria</a>).  Here, we discuss a topic that each of them has done a lot of work on - media narratives and hegemonic discourses.  This is an incredibly important conversation, and a very interesting discussion as well.  As we say in the episode, this is one that is perfect for sharing with friends and family members who may not already be highly tuned in to political affairs, but who understand that the media may be manipulating them!</span></div> <p><strong>Greg Shupak</strong> is a professor of English and Media Studies and is the author of the book,<em> <a href= "https://www.orbooks.com/catalog/wrong-story-greg-shupak/">The Wrong Story: Palestine, Israel, and the Media</a></em>.  You can follow him on twitter <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/twitter.com/GregShupak">@GregShupak</a>, and you should definitely check out the writing he does at <a href= "https://electronicintifada.net/people/greg-shupak">Electronic Intifada</a>.</p> <p><strong>Stuart Davis</strong> is an Assistant Professor of Communication Studies at Baruch College, the City University of New York he focuses on digital media advocacy, protest politics, and digital media and public health, particularly in the Latin American context. You can find more of Stuart's work on his <a href= "https://www.baruch.cuny.edu/profiles/faculty/Stuart-Davis">faculty page</a>, or on his <a href= "https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=E42WTFEAAAAJ&hl=en">Google Scholar page</a>. Additionally, pick up <a href= "https://www.haymarketbooks.org/books/2024-sanctions-as-war">Sanctions As War</a>, the outstanding book he coedited alongside Manny Ness.</p> <div dir="auto">Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a> </div>]]></description>

      <title>The Situation in Congo - From Mobutu to M23 Rebels Today w/ Georges Nzongola-Ntalaja (AR&amp;D Ep. 6)</title>
      <itunes:title>The Situation in Congo - From Mobutu to M23 Rebels Today w/ Georges Nzongola-Ntalaja (AR&amp;amp;D Ep. 6)</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 04 Apr 2025 08:20:27 +0000</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[12186144-a501-4dde-b049-8efa3bccc2b7]]></guid>
      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/the-situation-in-congo-from-mobutu-to-m23-rebels-today-w-georges-nzongola-ntalaja-ard-ep-6]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<div dir="auto"><span dir="auto"><span dir="auto">With this episode of Guerrilla History, were follow up on our last episode of African Revolutions and Decolonization with another discussion with Prof. Georges Nzongola-Ntalaja, who joined us last time for </span></span><span style="font-size: 12pt;"><a class= "read_more" href= "https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/the-congo-from-colonization-through-lumumba-mobutu-w-georges-nzongola-ntalaja-ard-ep-5" data-iframe-id="embed_35802365">The Congo - From Colonization Through Lumumba & Mobutu</a></span><span dir="auto">.  Here, we pick up where we left off, with Mobutu's regime, and come to the present.  Particular focus is given to the situation in eastern Congo with the 23 rebels today and their foreign backers.  This is an extremely important conversation, so be sure to share this series with comrades!  We are still in the very early phases of the planned ~40 parts, so it is a great time for them to start listening in as well!</span></div> <div dir="auto"> </div> <div dir="auto"><span dir="auto">Also subscribe to our Substack (free!) to keep up to date with what we are doing.  With so many episodes coming in this series (and beyond), you won't want to miss anything, so get the updates straight to your inbox.  <a href= "guerrillahistory.substack.com">guerrillahistory.substack.com</a></span></div> <div dir="auto"> </div> <div dir="auto"><strong>Georges Nzongola-Ntalaja</strong> is Professor Emeritus of African and Afro-American Studies at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, and previously served as the DRC's Permanent Representative to the United Nations.  Additionally, he is the author of numerous brilliant books, including <a class="external text" href= "https://www.ohioswallow.com/9780821421253/patrice-lumumba/"><em>Patrice Lumumba</em></a> and <a class="external text" href= "https://www.bloomsbury.com/us/congo-from-leopold-to-kabila-9781780329390/"> <em>The Congo from Leopold to Kabila: A People's History</em></a></div> <p>Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a> </p>]]></description>

    <item>
      <title>Indigenous Diamonds of Russia's Sakha Republic w/ Sardana Nikolaeva</title>
      <itunes:title>Indigenous Diamonds of Russia&#39;s Sakha Republic w/ Sardana Nikolaeva</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 28 Mar 2025 09:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[249ad07b-7a5d-4892-bd79-9a03645433e9]]></guid>
      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/indigenous-diamonds-of-russias-sakha-republic-w-sardana-nikolaeva]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<div dir="auto"><span dir="auto"><span dir="auto">In this episode of Guerrilla History, we bring on Dr. Sardana Nikolaeva to discuss her brilliant study</span></span> <a href= "https://www.ziibiinglab.org/indigenous-diamonds">Indigenous Diamonds: Extractivism and Indigenous Politics in the Diamond Province of Russia</a>.  We go over Sakha and the Sakha people, the history of diamond extraction in Sakha, and then went over the politics of indigeneity in Russia, how these diamonds were branded as "indigenous", and how sanctions on Russia impact the indigenous Sakha people.  With so much in this conversation, you are sure to learn a lot, and we hope you will help by sharing this with your comrades!</div> <div dir="auto"> </div> <div dir="auto"><strong>Sardana Nikolaeva</strong> is a post-doctoral fellow at the University of Toronto, where she is an indigenous anthropologist studying indigeneity, indigenous methodologies, extractivism, and more.  She cowrote the wonderful paper we discussed today, which you should read here: <a href= "https://www.ziibiinglab.org/indigenous-diamonds">https://www.ziibiinglab.org/indigenous-diamonds</a></div> <div dir="auto"> </div> <div dir="auto">Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a> </div>]]></description>
      
      <content:encoded><![CDATA[In this episode of Guerrilla History, we bring on Dr. Sardana Nikolaeva to discuss her brilliant study <a href= "https://www.ziibiinglab.org/indigenous-diamonds">Indigenous Diamonds: Extractivism and Indigenous Politics in the Diamond Province of Russia</a>. We go over Sakha and the Sakha people, the history of diamond extraction in Sakha, and then went over the politics of indigeneity in Russia, how these diamonds were branded as "indigenous", and how sanctions on Russia impact the indigenous Sakha people. With so much in this conversation, you are sure to learn a lot, and we hope you will help by sharing this with your comrades! Sardana Nikolaeva is a post-doctoral fellow at the University of Toronto, where she is an indigenous anthropologist studying indigeneity, indigenous methodologies, extractivism, and more. She cowrote the wonderful paper we discussed today, which you should read here: <a href= "https://www.ziibiinglab.org/indigenous-diamonds">https://www.ziibiinglab.org/indigenous-diamonds</a> Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a>]]></content:encoded>
      
      
      <enclosure url="https://traffic.libsyn.com/secure/guerrillahistory/indigenous-diamonds.mp3?dest-id=2463146" length="51412016" type="audio/mpeg" />
      <itunes:duration>01:39:56</itunes:duration>
      <itunes:explicit>false</itunes:explicit>
      
      <itunes:keywords />

    <item>
      <title>The Congo - From Colonization Through Lumumba &amp; Mobutu w/ Georges Nzongola-Ntalaja (AR&amp;D Ep. 5)</title>
      <itunes:title>The Congo - From Colonization Through Lumumba &amp;amp; Mobutu w/ Georges Nzongola-Ntalaja</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 21 Mar 2025 04:20:38 +0000</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[3b8aa7d3-a994-40bd-bd8c-b3df9734e301]]></guid>
      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/the-congo-from-colonization-through-lumumba-mobutu-w-georges-nzongola-ntalaja-ard-ep-5]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<div dir="auto"><span dir="auto">With this episode of Guerrilla History, were continuing our series on African Revolutions and Decolonization with an outstanding case study on the Congo, looking at the process of colonization, how decolonization unfolded, Lumumba's short time as Prime Minister, and the transition to the Mobutu regime.  We really could not ask for a much better guest than Prof. Georges Nzongola-Ntalaja, who not only is one of the foremost experts in not only this history, but also served as a diplomat for the DRC.  We're also fortunate that the professor will be rejoining us for the next installment of the series, a dispatch on what is going on in the Eastern Congo and the roots of the ongoing conflict there.  Be sure to share this series with comrades, we are still in the very early phases of the planned ~40 parts, so it is a great time for them to start listening in as well!</span></div> <div dir="auto"> </div> <div dir="auto"><span dir="auto">Also subscribe to our Substack (free!) to keep up to date with what we are doing.  With so many episodes coming in this series (and beyond), you won't want to miss anything, so get the updates straight to your inbox.  <a href= "guerrillahistory.substack.com">guerrillahistory.substack.com</a></span></div> <div dir="auto"> </div> <div dir="auto"><strong>Georges Nzongola-Ntalaja</strong> is Professor Emeritus of African and Afro-American Studies at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, and previously served as the DRC's Permanent Representative to the United Nations.  Additionally, he is the author of numerous brilliant books, including <a class="external text" href= "https://www.ohioswallow.com/9780821421253/patrice-lumumba/"><em>Patrice Lumumba</em></a> and <a class="external text" href= "https://www.bloomsbury.com/us/congo-from-leopold-to-kabila-9781780329390/"> <em>The Congo from Leopold to Kabila: A People's History</em></a></div> <p>Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a> </p>]]></description>
      
      <content:encoded><![CDATA[With this episode of Guerrilla History, were continuing our series on African Revolutions and Decolonization with an outstanding case study on the Congo, looking at the process of colonization, how decolonization unfolded, Lumumba's short time as Prime Minister, and the transition to the Mobutu regime. We really could not ask for a much better guest than Prof. Georges Nzongola-Ntalaja, who not only is one of the foremost experts in not only this history, but also served as a diplomat for the DRC. We're also fortunate that the professor will be rejoining us for the next installment of the series, a dispatch on what is going on in the Eastern Congo and the roots of the ongoing conflict there. Be sure to share this series with comrades, we are still in the very early phases of the planned ~40 parts, so it is a great time for them to start listening in as well! Also subscribe to our Substack (free!) to keep up to date with what we are doing. With so many episodes coming in this series (and beyond), you won't want to miss anything, so get the updates straight to your inbox. <a href= "guerrillahistory.substack.com">guerrillahistory.substack.com</a> Georges Nzongola-Ntalaja is Professor Emeritus of African and Afro-American Studies at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, and previously served as the DRC's Permanent Representative to the United Nations. Additionally, he is the author of numerous brilliant books, including <a class="external text" href= "https://www.ohioswallow.com/9780821421253/patrice-lumumba/"><em>Patrice Lumumba</em></a> and <a class="external text" href= "https://www.bloomsbury.com/us/congo-from-leopold-to-kabila-9781780329390/"> <em>The Congo from Leopold to Kabila: A People's History</em></a> <p>Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a> </p>]]></content:encoded>

    <item>
      <title>Revolutionary Papers w/ Mahish Ahmad, Koni Benson, &amp; Sara Kazmi</title>
      <itunes:title>Revolutionary Papers w/ Mahish Ahmad, Koni Benson, &amp;amp; Sara Kazmi</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 14 Mar 2025 06:45:39 +0000</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[2c02f2dd-3b0c-45c1-974a-51c3447f5ba8]]></guid>
      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/revolutionary-papers-w-mahish-ahmad-koni-benson-sara-kazmi]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<div dir="auto"><span dir="auto">In this episode of Guerrilla History, we discuss a wonderful resource for revolutionary scholars and activists - <a href= "https://revolutionarypapers.org/">Revolutionary Papers</a>.  Revolutionary Papers is a transnational research collaboration exploring 20th century periodicals of <em>Left</em>, <em>anti-imperial</em> and <em>anti-colonial</em> critical production, and in this discussion, we talk about the goals of the project, the intended audience, and forms that this project has taken.  You'll want to be sure to check out their fantastic work!</span></div> <div dir="auto"><span dir="auto">Some additional resources for you are <a href="https://sarrc.org.pk">the South Asian Research & Resource Center</a>, as well as <a href= "https://www.jamhoor.org">https://www.jamhoor.org</a> which is a Left media platform focusing on South Asia and its diasporas.</span></div> <div dir="auto"> </div> <div dir="auto"><strong><span dir="auto">Koni Benson</span></strong> is a historian at the University of the Western Cape. Her research focuses on collective interventions in histories of contested development and the mobilization, demobilization, and remobilization of struggle history in southern Africa's past and present.  You can find her Revolutionary Papers <a href= "https://revolutionarypapers.org/person-organisation/koni-benson/">page here</a>.</div> <div dir="auto"> </div> <div dir="auto"><strong>Sara Kazmi</strong> is a scholar, translator, and protest singer, a professor of Literature and Culture of the Global South whose research looks at poetry and drama from 1970s Punjab, in particular focusing on the re-working of oral, folk genres as a literary mode for subverting the bordering logics of the Indian and Pakistani state, and for critiquing the boundaries drawn by caste, patriarchy and institutional religion in the region.  Follow her <a href= "https://www.google.com/url?sa=t&source=web&rct=j&opi=89978449&url=https://www.instagram.com/mein.beqaid/%3Fhl%3Den&ved=2ahUKEwixzpSspNCLAxU5AhAIHdRDHdMQFnoECBkQAQ&usg=AOvVaw3osvA_bVfQ_mWg6hk7f4Uc"> on instagram</a> and find her Revolutionary Papers <a href= "https://revolutionarypapers.org/person-organisation/sara-kazmi/">page here</a>.</div> <div dir="auto"> </div> <div dir="auto"><strong>Mahvish Ahmad</strong> is an educator, scholar and organiser. She is an Assistant Professor of Human Rights and Politics at the Department of Sociology, London School of Economics, where she studies state violence and the intellectual and political labour of movements targeted in repression. Follow her on twitter <a href= "twitter.com/mahvishahmad">@mahvishahmad</a> and find her Revolutionary Papers <a href= "https://revolutionarypapers.org/person-organisation/mahvish-ahmad/"> page here</a>.</div> <p>Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a> </p>]]></description>
      
      <content:encoded><![CDATA[In this episode of Guerrilla History, we discuss a wonderful resource for revolutionary scholars and activists - <a href= "https://revolutionarypapers.org/">Revolutionary Papers</a>. Revolutionary Papers is a transnational research collaboration exploring 20th century periodicals of <em>Left</em>, <em>anti-imperial</em> and <em>anti-colonial</em> critical production, and in this discussion, we talk about the goals of the project, the intended audience, and forms that this project has taken. You'll want to be sure to check out their fantastic work! Some additional resources for you are <a href="https://sarrc.org.pk">the South Asian Research & Resource Center</a>, as well as <a href= "https://www.jamhoor.org">https://www.jamhoor.org</a> which is a Left media platform focusing on South Asia and its diasporas. Koni Benson is a historian at the University of the Western Cape. Her research focuses on collective interventions in histories of contested development and the mobilization, demobilization, and remobilization of struggle history in southern Africa's past and present. You can find her Revolutionary Papers <a href= "https://revolutionarypapers.org/person-organisation/koni-benson/">page here</a>. Sara Kazmi is a scholar, translator, and protest singer, a professor of Literature and Culture of the Global South whose research looks at poetry and drama from 1970s Punjab, in particular focusing on the re-working of oral, folk genres as a literary mode for subverting the bordering logics of the Indian and Pakistani state, and for critiquing the boundaries drawn by caste, patriarchy and institutional religion in the region. Follow her <a href= "https://www.google.com/url?sa=t&source=web&rct=j&opi=89978449&url=https://www.instagram.com/mein.beqaid/%3Fhl%3Den&ved=2ahUKEwixzpSspNCLAxU5AhAIHdRDHdMQFnoECBkQAQ&usg=AOvVaw3osvA_bVfQ_mWg6hk7f4Uc"> on instagram</a> and find her Revolutionary Papers <a href= "https://revolutionarypapers.org/person-organisation/sara-kazmi/">page here</a>. Mahvish Ahmad is an educator, scholar and organiser. She is an Assistant Professor of Human Rights and Politics at the Department of Sociology, London School of Economics, where she studies state violence and the intellectual and political labour of movements targeted in repression. Follow her on twitter <a href= "twitter.com/mahvishahmad">@mahvishahmad</a> and find her Revolutionary Papers <a href= "https://revolutionarypapers.org/person-organisation/mahvish-ahmad/"> page here</a>. <p>Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a> </p>]]></content:encoded>

      <itunes:duration>01:21:25</itunes:duration>
      <itunes:explicit>false</itunes:explicit>

      <title>Reflections on Mau Mau w/ Shiraz Durrani (AR&amp;D Ep. 4)</title>
      <itunes:title>Reflections on Mau Mau w/ Shiraz Durrani (AR&amp;amp;D Ep. 4)</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 07 Mar 2025 07:02:06 +0000</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[ba8991bf-6f46-4bc0-a858-c2a8e6cf7520]]></guid>
      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/reflections-on-mau-mau-w-shiraz-durrani-ard-ep-4]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<div dir="auto"><span dir="auto">With this episode of Guerrilla History, we continue our series on African Revolutions and Decolonization with a brilliant supplement reflecting on the Mau Mau Uprising.  Here, Shiraz Durrani goes through the history and its implications of the uprising, in a really fascinating and useful conversation!  This is a brilliant companion to our previous episode in the series, <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/the-mau-mau-uprising-w-nicholas-mwangi-ard-ep-3"> The Mau Mau Uprising w/ Nicholas Mwangi</a>, which you should also check out if you have not done so.  Be sure to share this series with comrades, we are still in the very early phases of the planned ~40 parts, so it is a great time for them to start listening in as well!</span></div> <div dir="auto"> </div> <div dir="auto"><span dir="auto">Also subscribe to our Substack (free!) to keep up to date with what we are doing.  With so many episodes coming in this series (and beyond), you won't want to miss anything, so get the updates straight to your inbox.  <a href= "guerrillahistory.substack.com">guerrillahistory.substack.com</a></span></div> <div dir="auto"> </div> <div dir="auto"><strong><span dir="auto">Shiraz Durrani</span></strong> is a Kenyan writer who has written expensively on Mau Mau, as well as other aspects of Kenyan history<span dir="auto">.  You can follow him on twitter <a href="twitter.com/sinahabari">@sinahabari</a>, and check out many of his <a href= "https://independent.academia.edu/DurraniShiraz">articles here</a>, as well as <a href= "https://www.africanbookscollective.com/authors-editors/shiraz-durrani"> his numerous books here</a>.</span></div> <p>Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a> </p>]]></description>

      <title>Korea War Games, Trump's Rhetoric on the DPRK, &amp; More w/ Ju-Hyun Park of Nodutdol</title>
      <itunes:title>Korea War Games, Trump&#39;s Rhetoric on the DPRK, &amp;amp; More w/ Ju-Hyun Park of Nodutdol</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 28 Feb 2025 04:36:04 +0000</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[c4c70dbb-06bd-45a2-9ac2-68c96a60ba7e]]></guid>
      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/korea-war-games-trumps-rhetoric-on-the-dprk-more-w-ju-hyun-park-of-nodutdol]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<div dir="auto"><span dir="auto">In this episode of Guerrilla History, we bring back our comrade Ju-Hyun Park (whom you will remember from our recent episodes  <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/a-history-of-american-imperialism-in-korea-us-out-of-korea-w-ju-hyun-park-of-nodutdol"> A History of American Imperialism in Korea</a> and  <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/korea-dispatch-martial-law-impeachment-and-more-w-ju-hyun-park-of-nodutdol"> Korea Dispatch - Martial Law, Impeachment, and More</a>) to discuss the upcoming US led war games taking place in the Peninsula, some interesting rhetoric coming from the Trump administration regarding the DPRK, Nodutdol's positions on each of these topics, and a brief rundown of the latest in the martial law and impeachment story that we covered last time with Ju-Hyun.</span></div> <div dir="auto"><span dir="auto"><span dir="auto">For more information on these topics and more, be sure to follow the material posted on both </span></span><a href= "UsoutofKorea.org">UsoutofKorea.org</a> and <a href= "Nodutdol.org">Nodutdol.org</a>.  Also, check out some of Nodutdol's recent instagram posts here: <a href= "https://www.instagram.com/p/DGgK1xmR0RQ/?igsh=NTc4MTIwNjQ2YQ==">Post 1</a> , <a href= "https://www.instagram.com/p/DGLxLF8x6ii/?igsh=NTc4MTIwNjQ2YQ==">Post 2</a></div> <div dir="auto"> </div> <div dir="auto"><strong><span dir="auto">Ju-Hyun Park</span></strong> is a writer and activist with Nodutdol for Korean Community Development.  Their writing has appeared in a variety of outlets, and they can be followed on Twitter <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/twitter.com/hermit_hwarang">@hermit_hwarang</a>.</div> <p>Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a> </p>]]></description>
      
      <content:encoded><![CDATA[In this episode of Guerrilla History, we bring back our comrade Ju-Hyun Park (whom you will remember from our recent episodes <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/a-history-of-american-imperialism-in-korea-us-out-of-korea-w-ju-hyun-park-of-nodutdol"> A History of American Imperialism in Korea</a> and <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/korea-dispatch-martial-law-impeachment-and-more-w-ju-hyun-park-of-nodutdol"> Korea Dispatch - Martial Law, Impeachment, and More</a>) to discuss the upcoming US led war games taking place in the Peninsula, some interesting rhetoric coming from the Trump administration regarding the DPRK, Nodutdol's positions on each of these topics, and a brief rundown of the latest in the martial law and impeachment story that we covered last time with Ju-Hyun.     <item>
      <title>The Mau Mau Uprising w/ Nicholas Mwangi (AR&amp;D Ep. 3)</title>
      <itunes:title>The Mau Mau Uprising w/ Nicholas Mwangi (AR&amp;amp;D Ep. 3)</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 21 Feb 2025 09:16:04 +0000</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[3dfade28-2011-4e77-b9c9-a0b8b810fbf0]]></guid>
      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/the-mau-mau-uprising-w-nicholas-mwangi-ard-ep-3]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<div dir="auto"><span dir="auto">With this episode of Guerrilla History, we get into our first case study of our series on African Revolutions and Decolonization.  Here, Nicholas Mwangi comes on to discuss the Mau Mau Uprising in Kenya - what led to it, how it unfolded, and its legacies.  Absolutely critical historical case study, you certainly want to hear it, and share with comrades! </span></div> <div dir="auto"> </div> <div dir="auto"><span dir="auto">Also subscribe to our Substack (free!) to keep up to date with what we are doing.  With so many episodes coming in this series (and beyond), you won't want to miss anything, so get the updates straight to your inbox.  <a href= "guerrillahistory.substack.com">guerrillahistory.substack.com</a></span></div> <div dir="auto"> </div> <div dir="auto"><strong><span dir="auto">Nicholas Mwangi</span></strong> <span dir="auto">is a writer and member of the <a href="https://ukombozilibrary.org/">Ukombozi Library</a> in Kenya.  Additionally, he cohosts the <a href= "https://www.youtube.com/@liberatingmindspodcast/videos">Liberating Minds podcast</a>, which you can also support on their <a href= "patreon.com/LiberatingMindsPodcast">Patreon</a>.</span></div> <p>Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a> </p>]]></description>
      
      <content:encoded><![CDATA[With this episode of Guerrilla History, we get into our first case study of our series on African Revolutions and Decolonization. Here, Nicholas Mwangi comes on to discuss the Mau Mau Uprising in Kenya - what led to it, how it unfolded, and its legacies.     <item>
      <title>Introducing Our New Sister Show - The Adnan Husain Show!</title>
      <itunes:title>Introducing Our New Sister Show - The Adnan Husain Show!</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 14 Feb 2025 11:54:18 +0000</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[3bb481b5-202b-4498-8591-7ebc35e434ea]]></guid>
      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/introducing-our-new-sister-show-the-adnan-husain-show]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<p class="p1">The following episode is from Adnan's new show, aptly titled <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oN4lMvsEi3U">The Adnan Husain Show</a>.  Don't worry, Adnan is still continuing with Guerrilla History, and we will be back with our next regular episode next week!  We just wanted to let you know about this exciting new project so that you can subscribe to it.</p> <p class="p1">In this episode, Professor Adnan Husain is joined by two outstanding scholars and thinkers, Drs. Peter Beattie and Karim Bettache of BettBeatMedia ( <a href= "twitter.com/BettBeat_Media"><span class= "s1">@BettBeat_Media</span></a>) .They discuss a number of interrelated topics based on BettBeatMedia newsletters on substack: the current geopolitical order, China's role in it, BRICS and political economy, anti-imperialist politics in the Trump era, the media, as well as the politics of race and Islamophobia beyond "left" and right in "the West".</p> <p class="p1">Check out BettBeat's Substack</p> <p class="p3"><a href= "https://substack.com/@bettbeat">https://substack.com/@bettbeat</a></p> <p class="p1">Subscribe to the channel here:<a href= "https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCVlAELI2OVTx03PvpXoLCWQ"><span class="s2"><span class="Apple-converted-space">  </span> /</span> @bettbeat_media<span class="s2"> </span></a></p> <p class="p1">Please subscribe, share, and support this channel:</p> <p class="p3"><a href= "https://adnanahusain.substack.com/">https://adnanahusain.substack.com/</a></p> <p class="p3"><a href= "https://patreon.com/adnanhusain">https://patreon.com/adnanhusain<span class="s2"> </span></a></p> <p class="p3"><a href= "https://www.adnanhusain.org">https://www.adnanhusain.org</a></p>]]></description>
      
      <content:encoded><![CDATA[<p class="p1">The following episode is from Adnan's new show, aptly titled <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oN4lMvsEi3U">The Adnan Husain Show</a>. Don't worry, Adnan is still continuing with Guerrilla History, and we will be back with our next regular episode next week! We just wanted to let you know about this exciting new project so that you can subscribe to it.</p> <p class="p1">In this episode, Professor Adnan Husain is joined by two outstanding scholars and thinkers, Drs. Peter Beattie and Karim Bettache of BettBeatMedia ( <a href= "twitter.com/BettBeat_Media">@BettBeat_Media</a>) .They discuss a number of interrelated topics based on BettBeatMedia newsletters on substack: the current geopolitical order, China's role in it, BRICS and political economy, anti-imperialist politics in the Trump era, the media, as well as the politics of race and Islamophobia beyond "left" and right in "the West".</p> <p class="p1">Check out BettBeat's Substack</p> <p class="p3"><a href= "https://substack.com/@bettbeat">https://substack.com/@bettbeat</a></p> <p class="p1">Subscribe to the channel here:<a href= "https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCVlAELI2OVTx03PvpXoLCWQ"> / @bettbeat_media </a></p> <p class="p1">Please subscribe, share, and support this channel:</p> <p class="p3"><a href= "https://adnanahusain.substack.com/">https://adnanahusain.substack.com/</a></p> <p class="p3"><a href= "https://patreon.com/adnanhusain">https://patreon.com/adnanhusain </a></p> <p class="p3"><a href= "https://www.adnanhusain.org">https://www.adnanhusain.org</a></p>]]></content:encoded>

    <item>
      <title>Pan-Africanism: A Primer w/ Layla Brown &amp; Jacquie Luqman (AR&amp;D Ep.2)</title>
      <itunes:title>Pan-Africanism: A Primer w/ Layla Brown &amp;amp; Jacquie Luqman (AR&amp;amp;D Ep.2)</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 07 Feb 2025 04:47:55 +0000</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[a0ca5364-93d5-4fdc-b9ca-f24d832b47a2]]></guid>
      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/pan-africanism-a-primer-w-layla-brown-jacquie-luqman-ard-ep2]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<div dir="auto"><span dir="auto">With this episode of Guerrilla History, we launch into Pan-Africanism as a great additional starting point to our series on African Revolutions and Decolonization.  We bring on two marvelous guests, Prof. Layla Brown and Jacquie Luqman, to discuss the history, theoretical currents, and modern expressions of Pan-Africanism.  This is a 2+ hour masterclass, you certainly won't want to miss a moment of it!  Be sure to share this episode with comrades as well, we KNOW they will benefit from listening!</span></div> <div dir="auto"> </div> <div dir="auto"><span dir="auto">Also subscribe to our Substack (free!) to keep up to date with what we are doing.  With so many episodes coming in this series (and beyond), you won't want to miss anything, so get the updates straight to your inbox.  <a href= "guerrillahistory.substack.com">guerrillahistory.substack.com</a></span></div> <div dir="auto"> </div> <div dir="auto"><strong><span dir="auto">Layla Brown</span></strong> <span dir="auto">is an Assistant Professor of Cultural Anthropology & Africana Studies and affiliate faculty in Women's, Gender, and Sexuality Studies. Brown's research focuses on Pan-African, Socialist, and Feminist social movements in Venezuela, the US, and the broader African Diaspora.  She is a member of the <a href="https://www.a-aprp-gc.org/">All-African People's Revolutionary Party (GC)</a>, and can be found on twitter <a href="twitter.com/PanAfrikFem_PhD">@PanAfrikFem_PhD</a>.  She also cohosts the <a href= "https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PL7_X-VeroWRt76-Pb9U7rtzZeNtUNs5Xu"> Life. Study. Revolution podcast</a> alongside Charisse Burden-Stelly.</span></div> <div dir="auto"> </div> <div dir="auto"><strong><span dir="auto">Jacquie Luqman </span></strong><span dir="auto">is a radical activist, journalist, and is a coordinator with <a href= "https://blackallianceforpeace.com/">Black Alliance for Peace</a>.  You can follow some (but not all!) of her writings <a href= "https://www.blackagendareport.com/author/Jacqueline%20Luqman">at Black Agenda Report</a>, and watch her show <a href= "https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PL7_X-VeroWRvv9Of_FfpAl_cZP8h-NHV0"> Luqman Nation on Black Liberation Media</a>. She is on twitter <a href= "twitter.com/luqmannation1">@luqmannation1</a>.</span></div> <p>Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a> </p>]]></description>
      
      <content:encoded><![CDATA[With this episode of Guerrilla History, we launch into Pan-Africanism as a great additional starting point to our series on African Revolutions and Decolonization. We bring on two marvelous guests, Prof. Layla Brown and Jacquie Luqman, to discuss the history, theoretical currents, and modern expressions of Pan-Africanism. This is a 2+ hour masterclass, you certainly won't want to miss a moment of it! Be sure to share this episode with comrades as well, we KNOW they will benefit from listening! Also subscribe to our Substack (free!) to keep up to date with what we are doing. With so many episodes coming in this series (and beyond), you won't want to miss anything, so get the updates straight to your inbox. <a href= "guerrillahistory.substack.com">guerrillahistory.substack.com</a> Layla Brown is an Assistant Professor of Cultural Anthropology & Africana Studies and affiliate faculty in Women's, Gender, and Sexuality Studies. Brown's research focuses on Pan-African, Socialist, and Feminist social movements in Venezuela, the US, and the broader African Diaspora. She is a member of the <a href="https://www.a-aprp-gc.org/">All-African People's Revolutionary Party (GC)</a>, and can be found on twitter <a href="twitter.com/PanAfrikFem_PhD">@PanAfrikFem_PhD</a>. She also cohosts the <a href= "https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PL7_X-VeroWRt76-Pb9U7rtzZeNtUNs5Xu"> Life. Study. Revolution podcast</a> alongside Charisse Burden-Stelly. Jacquie Luqman is a radical activist, journalist, and is a coordinator with <a href= "https://blackallianceforpeace.com/">Black Alliance for Peace</a>. You can follow some (but not all!) of her writings <a href= "https://www.blackagendareport.com/author/Jacqueline%20Luqman">at Black Agenda Report</a>, and watch her show <a href= "https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PL7_X-VeroWRvv9Of_FfpAl_cZP8h-NHV0"> Luqman Nation on Black Liberation Media</a>. She is on twitter <a href= "twitter.com/luqmannation1">@luqmannation1</a>. <p>Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a> </p>]]></content:encoded>

    <item>
      <title>BRICS - A View from South Africa w/ Prof. Narnia Bohler-Muller</title>
      <itunes:title>BRICS - A View from South Africa w/ Prof. Narnia Bohler-Muller</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 31 Jan 2025 04:14:23 +0000</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[b8baa124-5553-45db-abb7-7df0b6c7aab2]]></guid>
      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/brics-a-view-from-south-africa-w-prof-narnia-bohler-muller]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<div dir="auto"><span dir="auto">In this episode of Guerrilla History, we have a fascinating discussion on South Africa's role in BRICS, the view of BRICS in South Africa, South Africa's case against Israel at the ICJ, a new National Health Insurance law in SA, and more.  For this, we bring on someone ideally placed to discussed all of this and more - Prof. Narnia Bohler-Muller, a South African law professor and policy specialist who has been intimately involved in each of these topics.  This is really a great conversation, and hopefully helps you in thinking more about South Africa's role in BRICS when you have discussions about that grouping.</span></div> <div dir="auto"> </div> <div dir="auto"><span dir="auto">Don't forget to subscribe to our Substack (free!) to keep up to date with what we are doing.  We have a LOT of interesting things coming your way (not least of which, our African Revolutions and Decolonization series which began last week and continues with episode 2 next week), and you won't want to miss anything, so get the updates straight to your inbox.  <a href= "guerrillahistory.substack.com">guerrillahistory.substack.com</a></span></div> <div dir="auto"> </div> <div dir="auto"><strong><span dir="auto">Narnia Bohler-Muller</span></strong> is a divisional executive in the Human Sciences Research Council of South Africa's Developmental, Capable and Ethical State research division and acting Group Executive: Shared Services.  She is a lawyer and former Professor at Nelson Mandela University, and was one of the individuals involved in South Africa's admission to BRICS and many of the discussions since then surrounding SA's place in the grouping.  You can find more of her work <a href= "https://hsrc.ac.za/staff/n-narnia-bohler/">on her HSRC page.</a></div> <p>Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a> </p>]]></description>
      
      <content:encoded><![CDATA[In this episode of Guerrilla History, we have a fascinating discussion on South Africa's role in BRICS, the view of BRICS in South Africa, South Africa's case against Israel at the ICJ, a new National Health Insurance law in SA, and more. For this, we bring on someone ideally placed to discussed all of this and more - Prof. Narnia Bohler-Muller, a South African law professor and policy specialist who has been intimately involved in each of these topics. This is really a great conversation, and hopefully helps you in thinking more about South Africa's role in BRICS when you have discussions about that grouping. Don't forget to subscribe to our Substack (free!) to keep up to date with what we are doing. We have a LOT of interesting things coming your way (not least of which, our African Revolutions and Decolonization series which began last week and continues with episode 2 next week), and you won't want to miss anything, so get the updates straight to your inbox. <a href= "guerrillahistory.substack.com">guerrillahistory.substack.com</a> Narnia Bohler-Muller is a divisional executive in the Human Sciences Research Council of South Africa's Developmental, Capable and Ethical State research division and acting Group Executive: Shared Services. She is a lawyer and former Professor at Nelson Mandela University, and was one of the individuals involved in South Africa's admission to BRICS and many of the discussions since then surrounding SA's place in the grouping. You can find more of her work <a href= "https://hsrc.ac.za/staff/n-narnia-bohler/">on her HSRC page.</a> <p>Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a> </p>]]></content:encoded>

    <item>
      <title>African Revolutions and Decolonization (AR&amp;D) - Ep. 1: Introduction w/ Momodou Taal</title>
      <itunes:title>African Revolutions and Decolonization (AR&amp;amp;D) - Ep. 1: Introduction w/ Momodou Taal</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 24 Jan 2025 04:16:25 +0000</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[8aa3b635-1f34-4d3a-8033-4bd3a9b4f5a5]]></guid>
      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/african-revolutions-and-decolonization-ard-ep-1-introduction-w-momodou-taal]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<div dir="auto"><span dir="auto">With this episode of Guerrilla History, we officially launch our long awaited series on African Revolutions and Decolonization!  Every other week (between other, non-thematic episodes) for roughly the next year and a half, we will be turning a spotlight on struggles across the African continent, with both case studies as well as more theoretical or conceptual episodes present.  We could scarcely ask for a better guest to help us launch this series than our comrade Momodou Taal.  In this episode, we discuss the importance of studying African revolutionary history, and what we should be doing with this series.  Get excited, we certainly are!</span></div> <div dir="auto"><span dir="auto">In addition, if you want to read Adnan and Henry's thoughts on this series, they introduced the series <a href= "https://roape.net/2025/01/15/african-revolutions-and-decolonization-a-podcast-series-on-african-resistance/"> in a blogpost for the Review of African Political Economy last week</a>.</span></div> <div dir="auto"> </div> <div dir="auto"><span dir="auto">Also subscribe to our Substack (free!) to keep up to date with what we are doing.  With so many episodes coming in this series (and beyond), you won't want to miss anything, so get the updates straight to your inbox.  <a href= "guerrillahistory.substack.com">guerrillahistory.substack.com</a></span></div> <div dir="auto"> </div> <div dir="auto"><strong><span dir="auto">Momodou Taal</span></strong> is a British-Gambian PhD student at Cornell University studying African Political Economy.  He is host of the outstanding podcast <a href="https://kultural.podbean.com/">The Malcolm Effect</a>, and has a forthcoming book <a href= "https://themalcomeffect.carrd.co/">The Malcolm Effect Revisited</a>, which preorders are open for.  Be sure to also follow him on twitter <a href= "twitter.com/MomodouTaal">@MomodouTaal</a>.</div> <p>Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a> </p>]]></description>
      
      <content:encoded><![CDATA[With this episode of Guerrilla History, we officially launch our long awaited series on African Revolutions and Decolonization! Every other week (between other, non-thematic episodes) for roughly the next year and a half, we will be turning a spotlight on struggles across the African continent, with both case studies as well as more theoretical or conceptual episodes present. We could scarcely ask for a better guest to help us launch this series than our comrade Momodou Taal. In this episode, we discuss the importance of studying African revolutionary history, and what we should be doing with this series. Get excited, we certainly are! In addition, if you want to read Adnan and Henry's thoughts on this series, they introduced the series <a href= "https://roape.net/2025/01/15/african-revolutions-and-decolonization-a-podcast-series-on-african-resistance/"> in a blogpost for the Review of African Political Economy last week</a>. Also subscribe to our Substack (free!) to keep up to date with what we are doing. With so many episodes coming in this series (and beyond), you won't want to miss anything, so get the updates straight to your inbox. <a href= "guerrillahistory.substack.com">guerrillahistory.substack.com</a> Momodou Taal is a British-Gambian PhD student at Cornell University studying African Political Economy. He is host of the outstanding podcast <a href="https://kultural.podbean.com/">The Malcolm Effect</a>, and has a forthcoming book <a href= "https://themalcomeffect.carrd.co/">The Malcolm Effect Revisited</a>, which preorders are open for. Be sure to also follow him on twitter <a href= "twitter.com/MomodouTaal">@MomodouTaal</a>. <p>Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a> </p>]]></content:encoded>

    <item>
      <title>Post-Soviet Georgia History, and Today's Events w/ Sopo Japaridze</title>
      <itunes:title>Post-Soviet Georgia History, and Today&#39;s Events w/ Sopo Japaridze</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 17 Jan 2025 04:33:28 +0000</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[a6e5f8d0-a602-474d-8a01-f442c64ebf0a]]></guid>
      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/post-soviet-georgia-history-and-todays-events-w-sopo-japaridze]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<div dir="auto"><span dir="auto">In this episode of Guerrilla History, we bring on Georgian labor union leader and writer Sopo Japaridze to run through post-Soviet Georgia's history to help us understand the events that are unfolding today!  This is a critical discussion that hopefully will be of use to many of you who find yourself not knowing as much about Georgia as you wish you did, and will allow you to understand the ongoing events much better.  We certainly found quite a bit of value in this episode, and look forward to bringing Sopo back to discuss the history of Soviet Georgia in the future!</span></div> <div dir="auto"> </div> <div dir="auto"><strong><span dir="auto">Sopo Japaridze</span></strong> is a Georgian labor union leader and writer.  You can follow her on twitter <a href= "twitter.com/sopjap">@sopjap</a>, and keep up to date with many of her writings on her <a href= "https://substack.com/@sopjap">Substack</a>.  Also subscribe to her podcast Reimagining Soviet Georgia wherever you get your pods, and follow the show on twitter <a href= "https://x.com/reimaginingg">@ReimaginingG</a></div> <p>Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a> </p> <p>Also subscribe to our Substack (free!) to keep up to date with what we are doing.  <a href= "guerrillahistory.substack.com">guerrillahistory.substack.com</a></p>]]></description>
      
      <content:encoded><![CDATA[In this episode of Guerrilla History, we bring on Georgian labor union leader and writer Sopo Japaridze to run through post-Soviet Georgia's history to help us understand the events that are unfolding today! This is a critical discussion that hopefully will be of use to many of you who find yourself not knowing as much about Georgia as you wish you did, and will allow you to understand the ongoing events much better. We certainly found quite a bit of value in this episode, and look forward to bringing Sopo back to discuss the history of Soviet Georgia in the future! Sopo Japaridze is a Georgian labor union leader and writer. You can follow her on twitter <a href= "twitter.com/sopjap">@sopjap</a>, and keep up to date with many of her writings on her <a href= "https://substack.com/@sopjap">Substack</a>. Also subscribe to her podcast Reimagining Soviet Georgia wherever you get your pods, and follow the show on twitter <a href= "https://x.com/reimaginingg">@ReimaginingG</a> <p>Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a> </p> <p>Also subscribe to our Substack (free!) to keep up to date with what we are doing. <a href= "guerrillahistory.substack.com">guerrillahistory.substack.com</a></p>]]></content:encoded>

    <item>
      <title>[Unlocked] Conferences, What We're Reading, and More (October 30 on Patreon)</title>
      <itunes:title>[Unlocked] Conferences, What We&#39;re Reading, and More (October 30 on Patreon)</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 10 Jan 2025 04:46:43 +0000</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[c02a31c2-2403-48ef-9946-28dbfd6f75f7]]></guid>
      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/unlocked-conferences-what-were-reading-and-more-october-30-on-patreon]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<p data-pm-slice="1 1 []">In this episode of Guerrilla History, we're unlocking a conversation that we recorded for Patreon on October 30.  Here we had an impromptu chat when a guest had to reschedule last minute, but despite not planning in advance, we had a marvelous conversation on a pretty wide variety of topics.  We put out the call to our patrons on whether they thought anything in the conversation would be useful for our non-patreon audience, and some of the responses we heard included: </p> <p data-pm-slice="1 1 []">"I especially enjoyed Adnan's continuation of the Crusades theme he discussed with Sina a couple weeks ago."</p> <p data-pm-slice="1 1 []">"I really liked the Cyprus Isnotrael connection and the reminder that the histories in the region are intertwined going back a very long way."</p> <p data-pm-slice="1 1 []">Be sure to listen and let us know on social media if you found anything interesting or useful!  You can @ us on Twitter at <a href= "twitter.com/guerrilla_pod">@guerrilla_pod</a> and on IG at <a href="https://www.instagram.com/guerrilla_history/">guerrilla_history</a>.</p> <p data-pm-slice="1 1 []">Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a></p>]]></description>
      
      <content:encoded><![CDATA[<p data-pm-slice="1 1 []">In this episode of Guerrilla History, we're unlocking a conversation that we recorded for Patreon on October 30. Here we had an impromptu chat when a guest had to reschedule last minute, but despite not planning in advance, we had a marvelous conversation on a pretty wide variety of topics. We put out the call to our patrons on whether they thought anything in the conversation would be useful for our non-patreon audience, and some of the responses we heard included: </p> <p data-pm-slice="1 1 []">"I especially enjoyed Adnan's continuation of the Crusades theme he discussed with Sina a couple weeks ago."</p> <p data-pm-slice="1 1 []">"I really liked the Cyprus Isnotrael connection and the reminder that the histories in the region are intertwined going back a very long way."</p> <p data-pm-slice="1 1 []">Be sure to listen and let us know on social media if you found anything interesting or useful! You can @ us on Twitter at <a href= "twitter.com/guerrilla_pod">@guerrilla_pod</a> and on IG at <a href="https://www.instagram.com/guerrilla_history/">guerrilla_history</a>.</p> <p data-pm-slice="1 1 []">Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a></p>]]></content:encoded>

    <item>
      <title>The New International Economic Order at 50 w/ Michael Galant &amp; Pawel Wargan</title>
      <itunes:title>The New International Economic Order at 50 w/ Michael Galant &amp;amp; Pawel Wargan</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 27 Dec 2024 05:43:56 +0000</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[405a9863-e26e-463e-afe0-79d18a8e5204]]></guid>
      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/the-new-international-economic-order-at-50-w-michael-galant-pawel-wargan]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<div dir="auto"><span dir="auto">In this episode of Guerrilla History, we bring back Pawel Wargan (whom you'll remember from our episode  <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/disarming-empire-the-elections-in-pakistan-w-pawel-wargan"> Disarming Empire + the Elections in Pakistan</a>) as a guest host to help us interview Michael Galant about a new publication from the <a href= "https://progressive.international/">Progressive International</a>, a series of essays commemorating the New International Economic Order at its 50th anniversary, and updating it for today.  These essays are available in <a href= "https://progressive.international/blueprint/collection/7e2256c4-1bb2-49a3-bf78-a3e0bc6160d2-new-international-economic-order/en/"> English here</a>, and in <a href= "https://biblioteca-repositorio.clacso.edu.ar/bitstream/CLACSO/251550/1/Equilibrio-del-mundo.pdf"> Spanish here</a>.  These essays include historical entries from people like Allende, Nyerere, and Sankara, as well as new essays from comrades including Max Ajl, Cheng Enfu, and Miguel Díaz-Canel.  You will certainly find some essays of great value to you in this collection, so be sure to check it out!</span></div> <div dir="auto"> </div> <div dir="auto"><strong><span dir="auto">Michael Galant</span></strong> is a member of the Secretariat at the Progressive International and is a member of their coordinating team for the New International Economic Order.  You can follow Michael and keep up with his work by following him on twitter <a href= "https://x.com/michael_galant?lang=en">@michael_galant</a>.</div> <div dir="auto"> </div> <div dir="auto"><strong>Pawel Wargan</strong> is an activist, researcher, organizer, and coordinator of the Secretariat of the Progressive International, and has been published in many places. You can follow Pawel on twitter to keep up with his latest work <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/twitter.com/pawelwargan">@pawelwargan</a></div> <p>Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a> </p>]]></description>
      
      <content:encoded><![CDATA[In this episode of Guerrilla History, we bring back Pawel Wargan (whom you'll remember from our episode <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/disarming-empire-the-elections-in-pakistan-w-pawel-wargan"> Disarming Empire + the Elections in Pakistan</a>) as a guest host to help us interview Michael Galant about a new publication from the <a href= "https://progressive.international/">Progressive International</a>, a series of essays commemorating the New International Economic Order at its 50th anniversary, and updating it for today. These essays are available in <a href= "https://progressive.international/blueprint/collection/7e2256c4-1bb2-49a3-bf78-a3e0bc6160d2-new-international-economic-order/en/"> English here</a>, and in <a href= "https://biblioteca-repositorio.clacso.edu.ar/bitstream/CLACSO/251550/1/Equilibrio-del-mundo.pdf"> Spanish here</a>. These essays include historical entries from people like Allende, Nyerere, and Sankara, as well as new essays from comrades including Max Ajl, Cheng Enfu, and Miguel Díaz-Canel. You will certainly find some essays of great value to you in this collection, so be sure to check it out! Michael Galant is a member of the Secretariat at the Progressive International and is a member of their coordinating team for the New International Economic Order. You can follow Michael and keep up with his work by following him on twitter <a href= "https://x.com/michael_galant?lang=en">@michael_galant</a>. Pawel Wargan is an activist, researcher, organizer, and coordinator of the Secretariat of the Progressive International, and has been published in many places. You can follow Pawel on twitter to keep up with his latest work <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/twitter.com/pawelwargan">@pawelwargan</a> <p>Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a> </p>]]></content:encoded>

      <title>Korea Dispatch - Martial Law, Impeachment, and More w/ Ju-Hyun Park of Nodutdol</title>
      <itunes:title>Korea Dispatch - Martial Law, Impeachment, and More w/ Ju-Hyun Park of Nodutdol</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 20 Dec 2024 05:29:03 +0000</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[f33c8177-f989-4f9e-8164-32cf1c78ca11]]></guid>
      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/korea-dispatch-martial-law-impeachment-and-more-w-ju-hyun-park-of-nodutdol]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<div dir="auto"><span dir="auto">In this episode of Guerrilla History, we bring back our comrade Ju-Hyun Park (whom you will remember from our recent episode  <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/a-history-of-american-imperialism-in-korea-us-out-of-korea-w-ju-hyun-park-of-nodutdol"> A History of American Imperialism in Korea</a>) to discuss all the latest in South Korea, with the recent martial law/coup attempt, impeachment, attempts to restart a hot phase of the Korean War, and more as topics of discussion.  This is not only an extremely important dispatch, but also a dynamic situation with new information coming out all the time, so be sure to listen to this conversation to get grounded in what happened so that you can better make sense out of new developments in the situation</span><span dir="auto">.</span></div> <div dir="auto"> </div> <div dir="auto"><span dir="auto">Be sure to read Ju-Hyun's recent pieces related to this discussion, <a href= "https://peoplesdispatch.org/2024/12/08/south-koreas-impeachment-fails-whats-next/"> South Korea's impeachment fails—what's next?</a>, and <a href= "https://peoplesdispatch.org/2024/12/13/was-south-koreas-coup-an-attempt-to-restart-the-korean-war/"> Was South Korea's coup an attempt to restart the Korean War?</a>, and also be sure to check out <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/usoutofkorea.org">usoutofkorea.org</a>!</span></div> <div dir="auto"> </div> <div dir="auto"><strong><span dir="auto">Ju-Hyun Park</span></strong> is a writer and activist with Nodutdol for Korean Community Development.  Their writing has appeared in a variety of outlets, and they can be followed on Twitter <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/twitter.com/hermit_hwarang">@hermit_hwarang</a>.</div> <p>Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a> </p>]]></description>
      
      <content:encoded><![CDATA[In this episode of Guerrilla History, we bring back our comrade Ju-Hyun Park (whom you will remember from our recent episode <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/a-history-of-american-imperialism-in-korea-us-out-of-korea-w-ju-hyun-park-of-nodutdol"> A History of American Imperialism in Korea</a>) to discuss all the latest in South Korea, with the recent martial law/coup attempt, impeachment, attempts to restart a hot phase of the Korean War, and more as topics of discussion. This is not only an extremely important dispatch, but also a dynamic situation with new information coming out all the time, so be sure to listen to this conversation to get grounded in what happened so that you can better make sense out of new developments in the situation. Be sure to read Ju-Hyun's recent pieces related to this discussion, <a href= "https://peoplesdispatch.org/2024/12/08/south-koreas-impeachment-fails-whats-next/"> South Korea's impeachment fails—what's next?</a>, and <a href= "https://peoplesdispatch.org/2024/12/13/was-south-koreas-coup-an-attempt-to-restart-the-korean-war/"> Was South Korea's coup an attempt to restart the Korean War?</a>, and also be sure to check out <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/usoutofkorea.org">usoutofkorea.org</a>! Ju-Hyun Park is a writer and activist with Nodutdol for Korean Community Development. Their writing has appeared in a variety of outlets, and they can be followed on Twitter <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/twitter.com/hermit_hwarang">@hermit_hwarang</a>. <p>Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a> </p>]]></content:encoded>
