    <item>
      <title>Tricontinental's Early (1967-71) Socio-Ecological Dimensions w/ Alejandro Pedregal</title>
      <itunes:title>Tricontinental&#39;s Early (1967-71) Socio-Ecological Dimensions w/ Alejandro Pedregal</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 13 Dec 2024 05:24:21 +0000</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[531c7d2e-be8d-492d-9e24-1c1c5bdf51f5]]></guid>
      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/tricontinentals-early-1967-71-socio-ecological-dimensions-w-alejandro-pedregal]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<p>In this wonderfully esoteric yet very important episode of Guerrilla History, we bring on Alejandro Pedregal to discuss his marvelous co-authored historical article <a href= "https://acris.aalto.fi/ws/portalfiles/portal/160291393/molinero-pedregal-2024-the-early-socio-ecological-dimensions-of-tricontinental-_281967-1971_29-a-sovereign-social.pdf"> The Early Socio-ecological Dimensions of Tricontinental (1967–1971) : A Sovereign Social Metabolism for the Third World</a>.  This piece was published in one of our favorite journals, a resource that you really should all be utilizing, <a href= "https://journals.sagepub.com/home/ags">Agrarian South: Journal of Political Economy</a>.  In this discussion, we talk about OSPAAAL, the Cuban Third World solidarity institution and in particular its magazine <em>Tricontinental, </em>the way it framed sovereignty and the implicit ecological messaging within.  A fascinating conversation, and one which we think you will find a lot of use in!</p> <p><strong>Alejandro Pedregal </strong>is a Research Council of Finland Fellow, and is based at Aalto University.  You can keep up to date with Alejandro's work by checking out his <a href= "https://research.aalto.fi/en/persons/alejandro-pedregal-villodres"> institutional page from Aalto University</a>, and by following him on twitter <a href= "twitter.com/AlejoPedregal">@AlejoPedregal</a></p> <p><span style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: </span><a style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;" href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a><span style="font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> </span></p>]]></description>
      
      <content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>In this wonderfully esoteric yet very important episode of Guerrilla History, we bring on Alejandro Pedregal to discuss his marvelous co-authored historical article <a href= "https://acris.aalto.fi/ws/portalfiles/portal/160291393/molinero-pedregal-2024-the-early-socio-ecological-dimensions-of-tricontinental-_281967-1971_29-a-sovereign-social.pdf"> The Early Socio-ecological Dimensions of Tricontinental (1967–1971) : A Sovereign Social Metabolism for the Third World</a>. This piece was published in one of our favorite journals, a resource that you really should all be utilizing, <a href= "https://journals.sagepub.com/home/ags">Agrarian South: Journal of Political Economy</a>. In this discussion, we talk about OSPAAAL, the Cuban Third World solidarity institution and in particular its magazine <em>Tricontinental, </em>the way it framed sovereignty and the implicit ecological messaging within. A fascinating conversation, and one which we think you will find a lot of use in!</p> <p>Alejandro Pedregal is a Research Council of Finland Fellow, and is based at Aalto University. You can keep up to date with Alejandro's work by checking out his <a href= "https://research.aalto.fi/en/persons/alejandro-pedregal-villodres"> institutional page from Aalto University</a>, and by following him on twitter <a href= "twitter.com/AlejoPedregal">@AlejoPedregal</a></p> <p> Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;" href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a> </p>]]></content:encoded>

    <item>
      <title>The Lost &amp; Early Writings of James Connolly w/ Conor McCabe</title>
      <itunes:title>The Lost &amp;amp; Early Writings of James Connolly w/ Conor McCabe</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 06 Dec 2024 05:13:04 +0000</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[4e3a2c84-f382-4147-9313-3e385cf34b8e]]></guid>
      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/the-lost-early-writings-of-james-connolly-w-conor-mccabe]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<p>In this exciting episode of Guerrilla History, we bring on the editor of the newly released <a href= "https://www.iskrabooks.org/lost-and-early-writings">The Lost & Early Writings of James Connolly: 1889 - 1898</a>, a groundbreaking work that fits wonderfully within our Sources and Methods series of episodes.  Dr. Conor McCabe has done an incredible job of piecing together part of the lost James Connolly writings, and showing Connolly's engagement and adherence with Marxism, applied within the Irish national context.  You won't want to miss this conversation! This book was published by Iskra Books, which means that in addition to the book being available as a beautiful print edition, the PDF is also available for free at <a href= "iskrabooks.org">iskrabooks.org</a>.  Of course download the PDF, but do also consider picking up a physical copy to support Iskra in their project of publishing revolutionary works and making them as accessible and freely available as possible!</p> <p><strong>Conor McCabe</strong> is a historian, author, and scholar specializing in labor history, Irish socialism, and radical political movements. His extensive research has brought new insights into the intersections of class, colonialism, and economic power in Ireland. In addition to the Connolly book discussed today, he also has written <a href= "https://www.amazon.co.uk/Sins-Father-Conor-Mccabe/dp/1845888170">Sins of the Father: Tracing the Decisions That Shaped the Irish Economy</a> and has multiple projects ongoing.  Keep up to date with him <a href="https://conor-mccabe.com/">on his website</a>, and be sure to follow him on twitter <a href= "twitter.com/CMacCaba">@CMacCaba</a></p> <p><span style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: </span><a style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;" href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a><span style="font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> </span></p>]]></description>
      
      <content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>In this exciting episode of Guerrilla History, we bring on the editor of the newly released <a href= "https://www.iskrabooks.org/lost-and-early-writings">The Lost & Early Writings of James Connolly: 1889 - 1898</a>, a groundbreaking work that fits wonderfully within our Sources and Methods series of episodes. Dr. Conor McCabe has done an incredible job of piecing together part of the lost James Connolly writings, and showing Connolly's engagement and adherence with Marxism, applied within the Irish national context. You won't want to miss this conversation! This book was published by Iskra Books, which means that in addition to the book being available as a beautiful print edition, the PDF is also available for free at <a href= "iskrabooks.org">iskrabooks.org</a>. Of course download the PDF, but do also consider picking up a physical copy to support Iskra in their project of publishing revolutionary works and making them as accessible and freely available as possible!</p> <p>Conor McCabe is a historian, author, and scholar specializing in labor history, Irish socialism, and radical political movements. His extensive research has brought new insights into the intersections of class, colonialism, and economic power in Ireland. In addition to the Connolly book discussed today, he also has written <a href= "https://www.amazon.co.uk/Sins-Father-Conor-Mccabe/dp/1845888170">Sins of the Father: Tracing the Decisions That Shaped the Irish Economy</a> and has multiple projects ongoing. Keep up to date with him <a href="https://conor-mccabe.com/">on his website</a>, and be sure to follow him on twitter <a href= "twitter.com/CMacCaba">@CMacCaba</a></p> <p> Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;" href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a> </p>]]></content:encoded>

    <item>
      <title>New Translation of Marx's Capital, Vol. 1 w/ Paul North &amp; Paul Reitter</title>
      <itunes:title>New Translation of Marx&#39;s Capital, Vol. 1 w/ Paul North &amp;amp; Paul Reitter</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 29 Nov 2024 05:21:59 +0000</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[f15d462a-feb9-4b02-9c09-a9f1988ec960]]></guid>
      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/new-translation-of-marxs-capital-vol-1-w-paul-north-paul-reitter]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<p>In this episode of Guerrilla History, we bring on the translator/editors of the new translation of <a href= "https://press.princeton.edu/books/hardcover/9780691190075/capital?srsltid=AfmBOopbzed3ElgZzkHwQO-xyzJdgWt5ZDMGNR0XWsWRfSsV0_TBQpnm"> Capital Vol. 1 by Karl Marx</a>.  We discuss, in addition to other things, the reasons why it was decided that this new translation was needed, the political background to making that decision, why the 2nd German Edition was used for making the translation from, why these introductions were used, whether there will be translations of the subsequent volumes of Capital and if a paperback edition will come out, and more!  An enlightening discussion, lots of food for thought, and plenty of room for constructive dialogue and critique - let us know what you think of the conversation! </p> <p><strong>Paul North</strong> is the Maurice Natanson Professor of German at Yale University. His books include <a href= "https://www.sup.org/books/literary-studies-and-literature/yield"><em>The Yield: Kafka's Atheological Reformation</em></a>.</p> <p><strong>Paul Reitter</strong> is professor of Germanic languages and literatures and former director of the Humanities Institute at the Ohio State University. His translations include <a href= "https://press.princeton.edu/books/hardcover/9780691163857/the-autobiography-of-solomon-maimon?srsltid=AfmBOorHmDlSzbtrXxvKgMOckn3HslrtotFuSja6NR7y0y4XYq2vYZcT"><em>The Autobiography of Solomon Maimon</em></a>.</p> <p><span style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: </span><a style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;" href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a><span style="font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> </span></p>]]></description>
      
      <content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>In this episode of Guerrilla History, we bring on the translator/editors of the new translation of <a href= "https://press.princeton.edu/books/hardcover/9780691190075/capital?srsltid=AfmBOopbzed3ElgZzkHwQO-xyzJdgWt5ZDMGNR0XWsWRfSsV0_TBQpnm"> Capital Vol. 1 by Karl Marx</a>. We discuss, in addition to other things, the reasons why it was decided that this new translation was needed, the political background to making that decision, why the 2nd German Edition was used for making the translation from, why these introductions were used, whether there will be translations of the subsequent volumes of Capital and if a paperback edition will come out, and more! An enlightening discussion, lots of food for thought, and plenty of room for constructive dialogue and critique - let us know what you think of the conversation! </p> <p>Paul North is the Maurice Natanson Professor of German at Yale University. His books include <a href= "https://www.sup.org/books/literary-studies-and-literature/yield"><em>The Yield: Kafka's Atheological Reformation</em></a>.</p> <p>Paul Reitter is professor of Germanic languages and literatures and former director of the Humanities Institute at the Ohio State University.     <item>
      <title>Zionist Rampage &amp; Narrative Distortion in Amsterdam [Dispatch] w/ Jazie Veldhuyzen</title>
      <itunes:title>Zionist Rampage &amp;amp; Narrative Distortion in Amsterdam [Dispatch] w/ Jazie Veldhuyzen</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 22 Nov 2024 05:24:39 +0000</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[8f211c92-02be-4fa3-9dc0-5a58ce3d2119]]></guid>
      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/zionist-rampage-narrative-distortion-in-amsterdam-dispatch-w-jazie-veldhuyzen]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<p>In this dispatch episode of Guerrilla History, bring on left-wing Amsterdam City Council member Jazie Veldhuyzen to discuss the recent events that took place in Amsterdam surrounding an Ajax-Maccabi Tel Aviv football match, where violent Zionist hooligans went on a rampage through the city, but the media and major Dutch politicians instead characterized the event as a "modern pogrom" until the facts became too clear to ignore.  This is a really important discussion that not only clarifies that specific situation, but also examines how Zionism influences narratives in mainstream discourse, why to remain vigilant in the face of these distortions and lies, and how to build movements in the face of these narratives and distortions. </p> <p>Recommendations that were mentioned in this episode were the article by Asa Winstanley, our comrade from Electronic Intifada, titled <a href= "https://electronicintifada.net/blogs/asa-winstanley/ny-times-killed-investigation-israeli-hooligans-internal-email-reveals"> NY Times killed investigation of Israeli hooligans, internal email reveals</a>, as well as discussions on The Majlis around the IHRA "definition" of antisemitism.  Check out <a href= "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aETdFhWX9ZI&list=PLFsqZZZq2NLN2-UQBV0LDEldIQ_a1Ekmf&index=3"> The politics of the IHRA definition of Antisemitism and Academic Freedom</a> as well as <a href= "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7tbHLIjKwSE&list=PLFsqZZZq2NLN2-UQBV0LDEldIQ_a1Ekmf&index=4"> IHRA, Bill 168 and Academic Research and Teaching</a>.</p> <p><strong>Jazie Veldhuyzen</strong> is an activist, social worker, and Amsterdam City Council member and party chairman for <a href= "https://www.devonk.org">De Vonk</a>.  Follow him <a href= "https://www.instagram.com/jazieanthony/?hl=en">on Instagram</a> or on twitter <a href= "twitter.com/JazieAnthony">@JazieAnthony</a>.  You can also follow De Vonk <a href="https://www.instagram.com/devonk020/">on Instagram</a>.</p> <p><span style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: </span><a style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;" href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a><span style="font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> </span></p>]]></description>
      
      <content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>In this dispatch episode of Guerrilla History, bring on left-wing Amsterdam City Council member Jazie Veldhuyzen to discuss the recent events that took place in Amsterdam surrounding an Ajax-Maccabi Tel Aviv football match, where violent Zionist hooligans went on a rampage through the city, but the media and major Dutch politicians instead characterized the event as a "modern pogrom" until the facts became too clear to ignore. This is a really important discussion that not only clarifies that specific situation, but also examines how Zionism influences narratives in mainstream discourse, why to remain vigilant in the face of these distortions and lies, and how to build movements in the face of these narratives and distortions. </p> <p>Recommendations that were mentioned in this episode were the article by Asa Winstanley, our comrade from Electronic Intifada, titled <a href= "https://electronicintifada.net/blogs/asa-winstanley/ny-times-killed-investigation-israeli-hooligans-internal-email-reveals"> NY Times killed investigation of Israeli hooligans, internal email reveals</a>, as well as discussions on The Majlis around the IHRA "definition" of antisemitism. Check out <a href= "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aETdFhWX9ZI&list=PLFsqZZZq2NLN2-UQBV0LDEldIQ_a1Ekmf&index=3"> The politics of the IHRA definition of Antisemitism and Academic Freedom</a> as well as <a href= "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7tbHLIjKwSE&list=PLFsqZZZq2NLN2-UQBV0LDEldIQ_a1Ekmf&index=4"> IHRA, Bill 168 and Academic Research and Teaching</a>.</p> <p>Jazie Veldhuyzen is an activist, social worker, and Amsterdam City Council member and party chairman for <a href= "https://www.devonk.org">De Vonk</a>. Follow him <a href= "https://www.instagram.com/jazieanthony/?hl=en">on Instagram</a> or on twitter <a href= "twitter.com/JazieAnthony">@JazieAnthony</a>. You can also follow De Vonk <a href="https://www.instagram.com/devonk020/">on Instagram</a>.</p> <p> Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;" href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a> </p>]]></content:encoded>

    <item>
      <title>Women and Militarism w/ Sarah Raymundo</title>
      <itunes:title>Women and Militarism w/ Sarah Raymundo</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 15 Nov 2024 05:14:43 +0000</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[0e269a5d-7807-4b85-bf1d-c1b239bc89d3]]></guid>
      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/women-and-militarism-w-sarah-raymundo]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<p>In this important episode of Guerrilla History, bring on Sarah Raymundo to discuss Women and Militarism, with a particular focus on the context of the Philippines, but ranging far beyond that!  Within this conversation, we discuss the impact of militarism, and imperialist/colonialist military presence on women, as well as women's resistance to militarism.  This is a critical discussion, and Sarah brings out many important threads here within the conversation. You, listeners, will no doubt be happy to know that we have plans for another episode with Sarah soon, on indigenous issues within the Philippines, so be sure to stay tuned!</p> <p><strong>Sarah Raymundo</strong> is a faculty member at the University of the Philippines-Diliman Center for International Studies. She is engaged in activist work in <a href= "http://www.bayan.ph/">BAYAN (The New Patriotic Alliance)</a>, the <a href="https://www.ilps-news.com/">International League of Peoples' Struggles</a>, and Chair of the <a href= "https://www.facebook.com/PhilippinesVenezuela/">Philippines-Bolivarian Venezuela Friendship Association</a>. She is a member of the Editorial Board of the J<a href= "https://brill.com/view/journals/jlso/jlso-overview.xml?language=en">ournal for Labor and Society (LANDS</a>) and <a href= "https://www.interfacejournal.net/">Interface: Journal of/and for Social Movements</a>.  You can follow Sarah on twitter <a href="twitter.com/jinkydoo">@jinkydoo</a>.</p> <p><span style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: </span><a style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;" href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a><span style="font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> </span></p>]]></description>
      
      <content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>In this important episode of Guerrilla History, bring on Sarah Raymundo to discuss Women and Militarism, with a particular focus on the context of the Philippines, but ranging far beyond that! Within this conversation, we discuss the impact of militarism, and imperialist/colonialist military presence on women, as well as women's resistance to militarism. This is a critical discussion, and Sarah brings out many important threads here within the conversation.     <item>
      <title>Publishing as Anti-Imperialist Practice w/ Iskra Books Editors Talia, David, &amp; Ben</title>
      <itunes:title>Publishing as Anti-Imperialist Practice w/ Iskra Books Editors Talia, David, &amp;amp; Ben</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 08 Nov 2024 06:01:37 +0000</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[70dfa378-225f-4504-9cca-9b78ad9d3a18]]></guid>
      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/publishing-as-anti-imperialist-practice-w-iskra-books-editors-talia-david-ben]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<p>In this episode of Guerrilla History, we bring on several comrades from <a href="iskrabooks.org">Iskra Books</a>, a non-profit, all volunteer-run, independent communist publishing company to discuss Publishing as Anti-Imperialist Practice!  This discussion also relates to the <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/radical-independent-media-as-anti-imperialist-practice-w-sina-rahmani"> episode we did two weeks ago with Sina Rahmani of The East Is a Podcast on Radical Independent Media as Anti-Imperialist Practice.</a>  We also include the audio of a talk that Henry did on these topics at a China at 75 event hosted by the <a href= "https://socialistchina.org/">Friends of Socialist China</a> a few weeks ago.  This is a marvelous discussion on an important topic with some incredibly committed comrades.  Be sure to check this out, and be sure to check out Iskra Books's catalogue (keeping in mind that physical book purchases support the project, but that the pdfs of all of their books are also available for FREE at <a href="iskrabooks.org">iskrabooks.org</a>).  You can also keep up to date with their releases by following them on twitter <a href="twitter.com/iskrabooks">@iskrabooks</a>.</p> <p>The recently released and forthcoming books from Iskra that we discussed at the end of the episode are available at the following links: </p> <p><a href="https://www.iskrabooks.org/lost-and-early-writings">The Lost & Early Writings of James Connolly: 1889 - 1898, edited by Conor McCabe</a></p> <p><a href="https://www.iskrabooks.org/the-long-transition">The Long Transition Towards Socialism and the End of Capitalism by Torkil Lausen</a></p> <p><a href="https://www.iskrabooks.org/unequal-exchange">Unequal Exchange and the Prospects of Socialism by The Communist Working Group</a></p> <p>Communism - The Highest Stage of Ecology by Guillaume Suing (link forthcoming on the Iskra Books site)</p> <p><span style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> <strong>Talia </strong>is an Editorial Board member of Iskra Books, is one of the hosts of <a href= "https://open.spotify.com/show/0fgRlhmbQhZpYzKOth98gq">The Minyan podcast</a>, and is an academic librarian.  Follow The Minyan on twitter <a href= "twitter.com/the_minyan">@the_minyan</a>.</span></p> <p><span style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> <strong>David Peat </strong>is an Editorial Board member of Iskra Books, is an anti-war activist, and is involved with The Friends of Socialist China.  You can follow David on twitter <a href="twitter.com/dajveism">@dajveism</a>.</span></p> <p><span style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> <strong>Ben Stahnke </strong>is one of the cofounding Editors at Iskra Books, is a Professor of Philosophy, and one of the main art members at Iskra.  Follow Ben on twitter <a href= "twitter.com/phdirtbag">@phdirtbag</a>.</span></p> <p><span style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content:</span> <a style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;" href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a><span style="font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> </span></p>]]></description>
      
      <content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>In this episode of Guerrilla History, we bring on several comrades from <a href="iskrabooks.org">Iskra Books</a>, a non-profit, all volunteer-run, independent communist publishing company to discuss Publishing as Anti-Imperialist Practice! This discussion also relates to the <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/radical-independent-media-as-anti-imperialist-practice-w-sina-rahmani"> episode we did two weeks ago with Sina Rahmani of The East Is a Podcast on Radical Independent Media as Anti-Imperialist Practice.</a> We also include the audio of a talk that Henry did on these topics at a China at 75 event hosted by the <a href= "https://socialistchina.org/">Friends of Socialist China</a> a few weeks ago. This is a marvelous discussion on an important topic with some incredibly committed comrades. Be sure to check this out, and be sure to check out Iskra Books's catalogue (keeping in mind that physical book purchases support the project, but that the pdfs of all of their books are also available for FREE at <a href="iskrabooks.org">iskrabooks.org</a>). You can also keep up to date with their releases by following them on twitter <a href="twitter.com/iskrabooks">@iskrabooks</a>.</p> <p>The recently released and forthcoming books from Iskra that we discussed at the end of the episode are available at the following links: </p> <p><a href="https://www.iskrabooks.org/lost-and-early-writings">The Lost & Early Writings of James Connolly: 1889 - 1898, edited by Conor McCabe</a></p> <p><a href="https://www.iskrabooks.org/the-long-transition">The Long Transition Towards Socialism and the End of Capitalism by Torkil Lausen</a></p> <p><a href="https://www.iskrabooks.org/unequal-exchange">Unequal Exchange and the Prospects of Socialism by The Communist Working Group</a></p> <p>Communism - The Highest Stage of Ecology by Guillaume Suing (link forthcoming on the Iskra Books site)</p> <p> Talia is an Editorial Board member of Iskra Books, is one of the hosts of <a href= "https://open.spotify.com/show/0fgRlhmbQhZpYzKOth98gq">The Minyan podcast</a>, and is an academic librarian. Follow The Minyan on twitter <a href= "twitter.com/the_minyan">@the_minyan</a>.</p> <p> David Peat is an Editorial Board member of Iskra Books, is an anti-war activist, and is involved with The Friends of Socialist China. You can follow David on twitter <a href="twitter.com/dajveism">@dajveism</a>.</p> <p> Ben Stahnke is one of the cofounding Editors at Iskra Books, is a Professor of Philosophy, and one of the main art members at Iskra. Follow Ben on twitter <a href= "twitter.com/phdirtbag">@phdirtbag</a>.</p> <p> Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;" href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a> </p>]]></content:encoded>

    <item>
      <title>Western Marxism w/ Gabriel Rockhill</title>
      <itunes:title>Western Marxism w/ Gabriel Rockhill</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 01 Nov 2024 06:18:30 +0000</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[6cba065a-2d2c-43bf-8ebd-748326c945f9]]></guid>
      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/western-marxism-w-gabriel-rockhill]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<p>In this fantastic episode of Guerrilla History, bring on Gabriel Rockhill to discuss the landmark new English translation of the legendary Domenico Losurdo's <a href= "https://monthlyreview.org/product/western-marxism/">Western Marxism: How it was Born, How it Died, How it can be Reborn</a>, freshly out from Monthly Review Press.  This critical work acts as a trenchant critique of the Western left intelligentsia, showing how it is rooted in the political economy of imperialism.  The conversation we have surrounding this is deep, generative, and thought provoking, so be sure to listen closely!  </p> <p>In addition to reading Western Marxism, Gabriel also recommended the book <a href= "https://monthlyreview.org/product/let-me-speak-new-edition/">Let Me Speak! Testimony of Domitila, A Woman of the Bolivian Mines</a>, which is also available from Monthly Review Press.  Check it out!</p> <p><strong>Gabriel Rockhill</strong> is a philosopher and activist who has published numerous books. He is the Founding Director of the <a href="https://criticaltheoryworkshop.com/">Critical Theory Workshop</a> and Professor of Philosophy at Villanova University. Be sure to follow him on twitter <a href= "twitter.com/GabrielRockhill">@GabrielRockhill</a>.</p> <p><span style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: </span><a style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;" href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a><span style="font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> </span></p>]]></description>
      
      <content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>In this fantastic episode of Guerrilla History, bring on Gabriel Rockhill to discuss the landmark new English translation of the legendary Domenico Losurdo's <a href= "https://monthlyreview.org/product/western-marxism/">Western Marxism: How it was Born, How it Died, How it can be Reborn</a>, freshly out from Monthly Review Press. This critical work acts as a trenchant critique of the Western left intelligentsia, showing how it is rooted in the political economy of imperialism. The conversation we have surrounding this is deep, generative, and thought provoking, so be sure to listen closely! </p> <p>In addition to reading Western Marxism, Gabriel also recommended the book <a href= "https://monthlyreview.org/product/let-me-speak-new-edition/">Let Me Speak! Testimony of Domitila, A Woman of the Bolivian Mines</a>, which is also available from Monthly Review Press. Check it out!</p> <p>Gabriel Rockhill is a philosopher and activist who has published numerous books. He is the Founding Director of the <a href="https://criticaltheoryworkshop.com/">Critical Theory Workshop</a> and Professor of Philosophy at Villanova University. Be sure to follow him on twitter <a href= "twitter.com/GabrielRockhill">@GabrielRockhill</a>.</p> <p> Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;" href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a> </p>]]></content:encoded>

      <description><![CDATA[<p>In this episode of Guerrilla History,  we present a crossover conversation we did with our friend Sina from The East Is a Podcast on the topic of Radical Independent Media As Anti-Imperialist Practice!  This topic stems from a talk Henry gave for the Friends of Socialist China, and will be continued in a forthcoming episode on Publishing As Anti-Imperialist Practice featuring several Editorial Board members of <a href= "iskrabooks.org">Iskra Books</a>.  Be sure to Subscribe to Sina's show (links below), and also <a href= "https://www.youtube.com/@Guerrilla_History">subscribe to our freshly made YouTube channel</a>, which will begin uploading material very soon!</p> <p><strong>Sina Rahmani</strong> is host of <a href= "https://eastisapodcast.libsyn.com/">The East Is a Podcast</a>, which is a critical lens on the history of the present on West Asia and North Africa (and beyond), featuring interviews with experts and archival mashups.  Be sure to also subscribe to <a href= "https://m.youtube.com/@theeastisapodcast">his YouTube channel</a>, and follow him on Twitter <a href= "twitter.com/urorientalist">@urorientalist</a>.</p> <p><span style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: </span><a style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;" href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a><span style="font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> </span></p>]]></description>

    <item>
      <title>Political Traitors and Sellouts w/ J. Moufawad Paul &amp; Immanuel Ness</title>
      <itunes:title>Political Traitors and Sellouts w/ J. Moufawad Paul &amp;amp; Immanuel Ness</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 11 Oct 2024 04:32:49 +0000</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[80439055-0831-4c3a-87ed-f0902117e292]]></guid>
      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/political-traitors-and-sellouts-w-j-moufawad-paul-immanuel-ness]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<p>In this episode of Guerrilla History, we bring on two wonderful comrades to take on a pretty big topic of traitors and sellouts, the processes that take place that cause ideological changing, and some case studies of this phenomenon, including the discussion of <a href= "https://link.springer.com/referenceworkentry/10.1007/978-3-031-25399-7_82-2"> Zak Cope's recent heel turn from Thirdworldist to radical free market capitalist and Zionist</a>, and how to try to prevent this from happening within our organizations and within ourselves.  We could not ask for better guests to tackle this topic than returning friend Manny Ness, who had collaborated with Cope in the past, and J. Moufawad Paul, who in addition to being a friend of the show also wrote <a href= "https://moufawad-paul.blogspot.com/2024/08/obituary-zak-cope.html"> "Obituary": Zak Cope</a> in the aftermath of this situation.  You definitely will want to listen closely here!</p> <p class="p1"><strong>J. Moufawad Paul</strong> is a professor of philosophy at York University and the author of several books including <a href= "https://www.collectiveinkbooks.com/zer0-books/our-books/continuity-rupture"> Continuity and Rupture</a>, <a href= "https://foreignlanguages.press/new-roads/politics-in-command-a-taxonomy-of-economism-j-moufawad-paul/"> Politics in Command: A Taxonomy of Economism</a>, and <a href= "https://foreignlanguages.press/new-roads/critique-of-maoist-reason-j-moufawad-paul/"> Critique of Maoist Reason</a>.  He also is one of the editors at the fantastic <a href="https://materialjournal.net/">Material journal</a>, and has a blog <a href= "https://moufawad-paul.blogspot.com/">M-L-M Mayhem</a> that you should check out. Be sure to also follow him on twitter <a href= "twitter.com/MLM_Mayhem">@MLM_Mayhem</a>.</p> <p class="p1"><strong style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> Immanuel Ness</strong> <span style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;">is Professor of Political Science at Brooklyn College, City University of New York and Visiting Professor of Sociology at the University of Johannesburg.  He is the author or editor of numerous works including <a href= "https://www.plutobooks.com/9780745343594/organizing-insurgency/">Organizing Insurgency: Workers' Movements in the Global South</a>, <a href= "https://www.plutobooks.com/9780745335995/southern-insurgency/">Southern Insurgency: The Coming of the Global Working Class</a>, <a href= "https://link.springer.com/referencework/10.1057/9780230392786">The Palgrave Encyclopedia of Imperialism and Anti-Imperialism</a>, and the incredible <a href= "https://brill.com/view/journals/jlso/jlso-overview.xml?language=en"> Journal of Labor and Society</a>.  You can follow Manny on twitter <a href= "twitter.com/ImmanuelNess">@ImmanuelNess</a>.</span></p> <p><span style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content:</span> <a style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;" href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a><span style="font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> </span></p>]]></description>
      
      <content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>In this episode of Guerrilla History, we bring on two wonderful comrades to take on a pretty big topic of traitors and sellouts, the processes that take place that cause ideological changing, and some case studies of this phenomenon, including the discussion of <a href= "https://link.springer.com/referenceworkentry/10.1007/978-3-031-25399-7_82-2"> Zak Cope's recent heel turn from Thirdworldist to radical free market capitalist and Zionist</a>, and how to try to prevent this from happening within our organizations and within ourselves. We could not ask for better guests to tackle this topic than returning friend Manny Ness, who had collaborated with Cope in the past, and J. Moufawad Paul, who in addition to being a friend of the show also wrote <a href= "https://moufawad-paul.blogspot.com/2024/08/obituary-zak-cope.html"> "Obituary": Zak Cope</a> in the aftermath of this situation. You definitely will want to listen closely here!</p> <p class="p1">J. Moufawad Paul is a professor of philosophy at York University and the author of several books including <a href= "https://www.collectiveinkbooks.com/zer0-books/our-books/continuity-rupture"> Continuity and Rupture</a>, <a href= "https://foreignlanguages.press/new-roads/politics-in-command-a-taxonomy-of-economism-j-moufawad-paul/"> Politics in Command: A Taxonomy of Economism</a>, and <a href= "https://foreignlanguages.press/new-roads/critique-of-maoist-reason-j-moufawad-paul/"> Critique of Maoist Reason</a>. He also is one of the editors at the fantastic <a href="https://materialjournal.net/">Material journal</a>, and has a blog <a href= "https://moufawad-paul.blogspot.com/">M-L-M Mayhem</a> that you should check out. Be sure to also follow him on twitter <a href= "twitter.com/MLM_Mayhem">@MLM_Mayhem</a>.</p> <p class="p1"> Immanuel Ness is Professor of Political Science at Brooklyn College, City University of New York and Visiting Professor of Sociology at the University of Johannesburg. He is the author or editor of numerous works including <a href= "https://www.plutobooks.com/9780745343594/organizing-insurgency/">Organizing Insurgency: Workers' Movements in the Global South</a>, <a href= "https://www.plutobooks.com/9780745335995/southern-insurgency/">Southern Insurgency: The Coming of the Global Working Class</a>, <a href= "https://link.springer.com/referencework/10.1057/9780230392786">The Palgrave Encyclopedia of Imperialism and Anti-Imperialism</a>, and the incredible <a href= "https://brill.com/view/journals/jlso/jlso-overview.xml?language=en"> Journal of Labor and Society</a>.       <title>The West Bank, and the Nature of Resistance w/ Bana &amp; Lara from the Good Shepherd Collective</title>
      <itunes:title>The West Bank, and the Nature of Resistance w/ Bana &amp;amp; Lara from the Good Shepherd Collective</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 04 Oct 2024 07:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[d1718c83-0962-4fd9-af57-2d3c4899088f]]></guid>
      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/the-west-bank-and-the-nature-of-resistance-w-bana-lara-from-the-good-shepherd-collective]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<p>In this episode of Guerrilla History, we bring on two members from the Good Shepherd Collective, Bana Abu Zuluf and Lara Kilani, for a wide ranging conversation on The West Bank, the nature of resistance, the one year mark from October 7, narratives, and more!  This was a terrific and vital discussion with two wonderful comrades, and we will certainly be bringing them back on again soon.  Be sure to follow the Good Shepherd Collective on twitter <a href= "https://twitter.com/Shepherds4Good?ref_src=twsrc%5Egoogle%7Ctwcamp%5Eserp%7Ctwgr%5Eauthor"> @Shepherds4Good</a>, and check out <a href= "https://goodshepherdcollective.org/">their website</a>.  Additionally, read their article <a href= "https://goodshepherdcollective.org/posts/2023/12/15/anti-zionism-as-decolonisation/"> Anti-Zionism as Decolonization</a>, and if you have the ability to do so, consider <a href= "https://support.goodshepherdcollective.org/">supporting them financially to allow them to continue their crucial work</a>.</p> <p class="p1"><strong>Bana Abu Zuluf</strong> is a Palestinian PhD candidate in International Law at Maynooth University Ireland and a member of the Good Shepherd Collective.</p> <p class="p1"><strong>Lara Kilani</strong> is a Palestinian-American researcher and member of the Good Shepherd Collective.</p> <p><span style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content:</span> <a style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;" href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a><span style="font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> </span></p>]]></description>
      
      <content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>In this episode of Guerrilla History, we bring on two members from the Good Shepherd Collective, Bana Abu Zuluf and Lara Kilani, for a wide ranging conversation on The West Bank, the nature of resistance, the one year mark from October 7, narratives, and more!     <item>
      <title>Intro to African Revolutions and Decolonization w/ Leo Zeilig [Remastered]</title>
      <itunes:title>Intro to African Revolutions and Decolonization w/ Leo Zeilig [Remastered]</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 27 Sep 2024 07:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[61518c20-695e-4c84-89e8-62757f740b68]]></guid>
      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/intro-to-african-revolutions-and-decolonization-w-leo-zeilig-remastered-0]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<p>In this episode of Guerrilla History, we first provide a small bit of information about the retribution that friend (and future guest) of the show <a href="twitter.com/MomodouTaal">Momodou Taal</a> is facing from Cornel University for standing in solidarity with Palestine in the face of the ongoing Genocide, before releasing a fully remastered edition of one of our very first episodes, the nearly 4 year old survey on African revolutions and decolonization movements we did.  We still have our ~35 part series on African Revolutions and Decolonization upcoming imminently, so this past episode can serve as a sort of a first precursor/prelude to those coming episodes, and we can call back to this episode for the broader regional/continental historical context.  For this herculean task, we brought on Leo Zeilig, an editor of the <em><a href="https://roape.net/">Review of African Political Economy</a>,</em> a senior research fellow at the Institute of Commonwealth Studies at the School of Advanced Study University of London, and an Honorary Research Associate at the Society, Work and Development Institute (SWOP) at the University of the Witwatersrand, South Africa.</p> <p>Leo's books include <a href= "https://leozeilig.com/portfolio-items/thomas-sankara-voices-of-liberation/"> Thomas Sankara</a>, <a href= "https://www.bloomsbury.com/uk/frantz-fanon-9781848857247/">Frantz Fanon: Philosopher of the Third World</a>, <a href= "https://www.haymarketbooks.org/books/367-african-struggles-today">African Struggles Today: Social Movements Since Independence</a>, and <a href= "https://www.google.com/search?q=Congo%3A+Plunder+and+Resistance&rlz=1C5CHFA_enDE766DE766&oq=Congo%3A+Plunder+and+Resistance&gs_lcrp=EgZjaHJvbWUyBggAEEUYOTIGCAEQRRg60gEHNDMzajBqOagCALACAQ&sourceid=chrome&ie=UTF-8#:~:text=The%20Congo%3A%20Plunder%20and%20Resistance%3A%20Leo,www.bloomsbury.com%20%E2%80%BA%20congo%2D9781842774854"> Congo: Plunder and Resistance</a>.  You can find his website at <a href= "https://leozeilig.com/">https://leozeilig.com/</a> and follow him on twitter <a href= "twitter.com/LeoZeilig">@LeoZeilig</a>.  Also, follow the Review of African Political Economy on twitter <a href= "twitter.com/ROAPEJournal">@ROAPEJournal</a> and their website <a href= "https://roape.net/">https://roape.net/</a> .</p>       <content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>In this episode of Guerrilla History, we first provide a small bit of information about the retribution that friend (and future guest) of the show <a href="twitter.com/MomodouTaal">Momodou Taal</a> is facing from Cornel University for standing in solidarity with Palestine in the face of the ongoing Genocide, before releasing a fully remastered edition of one of our very first episodes, the nearly 4 year old survey on African revolutions and decolonization movements we did. We still have our ~35 part series on African Revolutions and Decolonization upcoming imminently, so this past episode can serve as a sort of a first precursor/prelude to those coming episodes, and we can call back to this episode for the broader regional/continental historical context. For this herculean task, we brought on Leo Zeilig, an editor of the <em><a href="https://roape.net/">Review of African Political Economy</a>,</em> a senior research fellow at the Institute of Commonwealth Studies at the School of Advanced Study University of London, and an Honorary Research Associate at the Society, Work and Development Institute (SWOP) at the University of the Witwatersrand, South Africa.</p> <p>Leo's books include <a href= "https://leozeilig.com/portfolio-items/thomas-sankara-voices-of-liberation/"> Thomas Sankara</a>, <a href= "https://www.bloomsbury.com/uk/frantz-fanon-9781848857247/">Frantz Fanon: Philosopher of the Third World</a>, <a href= "https://www.haymarketbooks.org/books/367-african-struggles-today">African Struggles Today: Social Movements Since Independence</a>, and <a href= "https://www.google.com/search?q=Congo%3A+Plunder+and+Resistance&rlz=1C5CHFA_enDE766DE766&oq=Congo%3A+Plunder+and+Resistance&gs_lcrp=EgZjaHJvbWUyBggAEEUYOTIGCAEQRRg60gEHNDMzajBqOagCALACAQ&sourceid=chrome&ie=UTF-8#:~:text=The%20Congo%3A%20Plunder%20and%20Resistance%3A%20Leo,www.bloomsbury.com%20%E2%80%BA%20congo%2D9781842774854"> Congo: Plunder and Resistance</a>. You can find his website at <a href= "https://leozeilig.com/">https://leozeilig.com/</a> and follow him on twitter <a href= "twitter.com/LeoZeilig">@LeoZeilig</a>. Also, follow the Review of African Political Economy on twitter <a href= "twitter.com/ROAPEJournal">@ROAPEJournal</a> and their website <a href= "https://roape.net/">https://roape.net/</a> .</p> <p> Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;" href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a> </p>]]></content:encoded>

      <title>Islam, the Commons, and (Democratic) Socialism w/ Ali Al-Assam</title>
      <itunes:title>Islam, the Commons, and (Democratic) Socialism w/ Ali Al-Assam</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 20 Sep 2024 07:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[030f3589-1823-4780-bd6d-6bd60e8cf655]]></guid>

      <description><![CDATA[<p>In this wonderful crossover episode between Guerrilla History and <a href= "https://open.spotify.com/show/0nZKmWviaYXBtqwuxOpbbD">The Majlis</a>, we bring on Dr. Ali Al-Assam to discuss the legendary Iraqi Communist leader Ibrahim Allawi's work <a href= "https://www.iskrabooks.org/al-mushtarak">Al-Mushtarak (The Commons), which Ali has just translated an edited edition in English, available from Iskra Books</a>!  This conversation covers the life and work of Allawi, his book Al-Mushtarak, and the fascinating fusion of Islamic culture and socialist politics contained within.  Really a great discussion, you're going to want to check this out (and pick up the book!).</p> <p><strong>Ali Al-Assam</strong> is founder and Secretary of NewsSocial Cooperative and member of the Friends of Socialist China - Britain Committee.  Be sure to check out the <a href= "https://www.mushtarek.org/welcome">Mushtarek platform</a> and the <a href="https://www.newssocial.news/welcome">NewsSocial Cooperative</a>.  You can follow Ali on twitter <a href= "https://x.com/aliassam">@aliassam</a>, and get the book <a href= "https://www.iskrabooks.org/al-mushtarak">Reading In Al-Mushtarak</a> from <a href="twitter.com/IskraBooks">Iskra Books</a>.</p> <p><span style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;">  Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content:</span> <a style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;" href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a><span style="font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> </span></p>]]></description>

      <title>[Urgent] Targeted by the State - Comrade Booker Omole from the Communist Party of Kenya On State Repression and His Personal Ordeal</title>
      <itunes:title>[Urgent] Targeted by the State - Comrade Booker Omole from the Communist Party of Kenya On State Repression and His Personal Ordeal</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 13 Sep 2024 07:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[42f10363-75f3-4202-a710-aa8060eab694]]></guid>
      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/urgent-targeted-by-the-state-comrade-booker-omole-from-the-communist-party-of-kenya-on-state-repression-and-his-personal-ordeal]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<p>In this critically important episode, we bring back our friend Comrade Booker from the Communist Party of Kenya to discuss the breaking news of his arrest and charges against him by the Kenyan governing apparatus.  In addition to discussing his personal case, he analyses and describes the wider repressive nature of the Kenyan government, and how the Communist Party of Kenya is operating in the environment of mass public discontent.  A fascinating, timely, and important conversation!</p> <p>Also, be sure to listen to the other episodes we have with Booker - <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/booker-omole-of-the-communist-party-of-kenya-history-and-class-analysis-of-kenyan-elections"> History and Class Analysis of Kenyan Elections Dispatch</a>, and <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/building-the-communist-party-of-kenya-w-comrade-booker-omole"> Building the Communist Party of Kenya</a>.</p> <p><strong>Booker Omole</strong> is the National Vice Chairperson and National Organizing Secretary of the Communist Party of Kenya.  He can be found on Twitter <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/twitter.com/BookerBiro">@BookerBiro</a>.</p> <p>Support the Communist Party of Kenya! You can follow them on Twitter <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/twitter.com/CommunistsKe">@CommunistsKe</a>, on <a href= "https://www.facebook.com/CommunistKenya">Facebook</a>, <a href="https://www.youtube.com/@communistpartyofkenya">YouTube</a>, or on <a href= "https://www.instagram.com/communistske/">Instagram</a>.  You can also check out their website at <a href= "https://www.communistpartyofkenya.org/">https://www.communistpartyofkenya.org/</a>.</p> <p><span style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content:</span> <a style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;" href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a><span style="font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> </span></p>]]></description>
      
      <content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>In this critically important episode, we bring back our friend Comrade Booker from the Communist Party of Kenya to discuss the breaking news of his arrest and charges against him by the Kenyan governing apparatus.     <item>
      <title>Electoral Theory and Strategy of Marx and Lenin w/ August Nimtz [Remaster]</title>
      <itunes:title>Electoral Theory and Strategy of Marx and Lenin w/ August Nimtz [Remaster]</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 06 Sep 2024 07:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[2189932b-8980-4379-9e13-3bde65118e2e]]></guid>
      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/electoral-theory-and-strategy-of-marx-and-lenin-w-august-nimtz-remaster]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<p>In this fully remastered 3+ year old episode of Guerrilla History, we brought on Professor August Nimtz to talk about his book, <a href= "https://www.haymarketbooks.org/books/1385-the-ballot-the-streets-or-both"> <em>The Ballot, The Streets, or Both? From Marx and Engels to Lenin and the October Revolution</em></a>.  This book takes a look at the theoretical and strategic groundings and evolution of electoralism via the writings of Marx/Engels and Lenin.  A conversation that will add a lot of historical nuance to the debates that we have every election season in the "western democratic" countries!</p> <p><strong>August Nimtz</strong> professor of political science and African American and African studies at the University of Minnesota.  His book <em>The Ballot, The Streets, or Both?</em> is available from Haymarket Books. His other books include <em>Marx and Engels: Their Contribution to the Democratic Breakthrough</em> (SUNY Press), <em>Marx, Tocqueville, and Race in America: The 'Absolute Democracy' or 'Defiled Republic'</em> <em> </em>(Lexington Books), and <em>Marxism versus Liberalism: Comparative Real-Time Political Analysis</em> (Palgrave Macmillan).  </p> <p><span style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content:</span> <a style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;" href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a><span style="font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> </span></p>]]></description>
      
      <content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>In this fully remastered 3+ year old episode of Guerrilla History, we brought on Professor August Nimtz to talk about his book, <a href= "https://www.haymarketbooks.org/books/1385-the-ballot-the-streets-or-both"> <em>The Ballot, The Streets, or Both? From Marx and Engels to Lenin and the October Revolution</em></a>. This book takes a look at the theoretical and strategic groundings and evolution of electoralism via the writings of Marx/Engels and Lenin. A conversation that will add a lot of historical nuance to the debates that we have every election season in the "western democratic" countries!</p> <p>August Nimtz professor of political science and African American and African studies at the University of Minnesota. His book <em>The Ballot, The Streets, or Both?</em> is available from Haymarket Books. His other books include <em>Marx and Engels: Their Contribution to the Democratic Breakthrough</em> (SUNY Press), <em>Marx, Tocqueville, and Race in America: The 'Absolute Democracy' or 'Defiled Republic'</em> <em> </em>(Lexington Books), and <em>Marxism versus Liberalism: Comparative Real-Time Political Analysis</em> (Palgrave Macmillan). </p> <p> Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;" href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a> </p>]]></content:encoded>

      <title>Subjectivity and Decolonization in the Post-Independence Novel and Film w/ Sarah Jilani</title>
      <itunes:title>Subjectivity and Decolonization in the Post-Independence Novel and Film w/ Sarah Jilani</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 16 Aug 2024 07:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[00533e6c-0571-4e58-95dd-62ed161a136e]]></guid>
      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/subjectivity-and-decolonization-in-the-post-independence-novel-and-film-w-sarah-jilani]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<div dir="auto"><span dir="auto">In this episode of Guerrilla History, we have the opportunity to discuss a fabulous new book, <a href= "https://edinburghuniversitypress.com/book-subjectivity-and-decolonisation-in-the-post-independence-novel-and-film.html"> Subjectivity and Decolonisation in the Post-Independence Novel and Film</a> with its brilliant author Sarah Jilani.  Through examinations of novels and film from Africa and South Asia, Frantz Fanon's materialist approach to self and representations of subjectivity and decolonization are discussed.  Really an outstanding conversation, we really hope Sarah will join us again for future conversations!  Another project Sarah is involved with is <a href="https://revolutionarypapers.org/">Revolutionary Papers</a>, and we look forward to discussing this project in weeks to come.</span></div> <div dir="auto"> </div> <div dir="auto"><strong><span dir="auto">Sarah Jilani</span></strong> is a Lecturer in English at City, University of London, and a 2021 AHRC/BBC New Generation Thinker. She is the author of several articles on postcolonial literatures and film that have appeared in Textual Practice, Interventions, and Journal of Commonwealth Literature, amongst others, and a widely published culture journalist.  Keep up to date with Sarah by checking out her <a href="https://sarahjilani.com/">website for more of her work</a>, and follow her on twitter <a href= "twitter.com/sarahjilani">@sarahjilani</a>.</div> <p><span style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content:</span> <a style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;" href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a><span style="font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> </span></p>]]></description>
      
      <content:encoded><![CDATA[In this episode of Guerrilla History, we have the opportunity to discuss a fabulous new book, <a href= "https://edinburghuniversitypress.com/book-subjectivity-and-decolonisation-in-the-post-independence-novel-and-film.html"> Subjectivity and Decolonisation in the Post-Independence Novel and Film</a> with its brilliant author Sarah Jilani. Through examinations of novels and film from Africa and South Asia, Frantz Fanon's materialist approach to self and representations of subjectivity and decolonization are discussed. Really an outstanding conversation, we really hope Sarah will join us again for future conversations! Another project Sarah is involved with is <a href="https://revolutionarypapers.org/">Revolutionary Papers</a>, and we look forward to discussing this project in weeks to come. Sarah Jilani is a Lecturer in English at City, University of London, and a 2021 AHRC/BBC New Generation Thinker. She is the author of several articles on postcolonial literatures and film that have appeared in Textual Practice, Interventions, and Journal of Commonwealth Literature, amongst others, and a widely published culture journalist.       <title>Defiance - Fighting the Far Right in Britain w/ Rajesh Thind &amp; Shahnaz Ali</title>
      <itunes:title>Defiance - Fighting the Far Right in Britain w/ Rajesh Thind &amp;amp; Shahnaz Ali</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 09 Aug 2024 07:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[68e3c308-17a9-4a1a-98b8-146b9f4abe9b]]></guid>
      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/defiance-fighting-the-far-right-in-britain-w-rajesh-thind-shahnaz-ali]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<div dir="auto"><span dir="auto">In this timely episode of Guerrilla History, Adnan discusses <a href= "https://www.channel4.com/programmes/defiance-fighting-the-far-right"> Defiance: Fighting the Far Right</a> w/ Rajesh Thind, a director & producer of the </span><span dir="auto">three part Channel 4 documentary series produced by Rogan Productions in association with Riz Ahmed's Lefthanded Films. The series is an immersive social history that brings the South Asian activists who combatted and organized successfully against far right racist and anti-immigrant violence in the 1970s & early 1980s to our screens. </span> <span dir="auto">Exclusive to Guerrilla History, one of those veteran activists Shahnaz Ali joined the conversation to talk about her experiences organizing in the late 1970's and 80's in Bradford, and since then, fighting for equality and justice in UK society and the National Health Service specifically. This history is incredibly relevant for the resurgence of far right violence and rioting being witnessed right now on city streets across the UK.</span></div> <div dir="auto"> </div> <div dir="auto">In addition to watching <span dir="auto"><a href= "https://www.channel4.com/programmes/defiance-fighting-the-far-right"> Defiance: Fighting the Far Right</a>, you should also listen to our two related previous episodes, <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/african-caribbean-people-in-britain-a-history-w-hakim-adi"> African & Caribbean People in Britain - A History w/ Hakim Adi</a>, and  <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/black-brown-resistance-in-the-uk-1960s-80s-w-preeti-dhillon"> Black & Brown Resistance in the UK (1960s-80s) w/ Preeti Dhillon</a>.</span></div> <div dir="auto"> </div> <div dir="auto"><strong><span dir="auto">Rajesh Thind</span></strong> <span dir="auto">is an award-winning director, writer & producer of films, tv, stage & prose known for tackling challenging & complex subjects.  Keep up to date with his work by checking out his <a href= "https://bio.site/rajeshthind">website</a> and by following him on twitter <a href= "twitter.com/RajeshThind">@RajeshThind</a></span></div> <p><strong><span style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> Shahnaz</span></strong><span style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> <strong>Ali</strong> OBE is former Director of Equality, Inclusion and Human Rights NHSNW. Now a freelance consultant Making Equality Work and Lay Council member for University of Bradford.  You can read more about her work at the <a href= "https://nursingnarratives.com/advisory-panel/">Nursing Narratives website</a>, her <a href= "https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shahnaz_Ali">Wikipedia page</a>, and on <a href= "https://uk.linkedin.com/in/shahnazali">LinkedIn</a>.</span></p> <p><span style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content:</span> <a style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;" href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a><span style="font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> </span></p>]]></description>
      
      <content:encoded><![CDATA[In this timely episode of Guerrilla History, Adnan discusses <a href= "https://www.channel4.com/programmes/defiance-fighting-the-far-right"> Defiance: Fighting the Far Right</a> w/ Rajesh Thind, a director & producer of the three part Channel 4 documentary series produced by Rogan Productions in association with Riz Ahmed's Lefthanded Films. The series is an immersive social history that brings the South Asian activists who combatted and organized successfully against far right racist and anti-immigrant violence in the 1970s & early 1980s to our screens. Exclusive to Guerrilla History, one of those veteran activists Shahnaz Ali joined the conversation to talk about her experiences organizing in the late 1970's and 80's in Bradford, and since then, fighting for equality and justice in UK society and the National Health Service specifically. This history is incredibly relevant for the resurgence of far right violence and rioting being witnessed right now on city streets across the UK. In addition to watching <a href= "https://www.channel4.com/programmes/defiance-fighting-the-far-right"> Defiance: Fighting the Far Right</a>, you should also listen to our two related previous episodes, <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/african-caribbean-people-in-britain-a-history-w-hakim-adi"> African & Caribbean People in Britain - A History w/ Hakim Adi</a>, and <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/black-brown-resistance-in-the-uk-1960s-80s-w-preeti-dhillon"> Black & Brown Resistance in the UK (1960s-80s) w/ Preeti Dhillon</a>. Rajesh Thind is an award-winning director, writer & producer of films, tv, stage & prose known for tackling challenging & complex subjects. Keep up to date with his work by checking out his <a href= "https://bio.site/rajeshthind">website</a> and by following him on twitter <a href= "twitter.com/RajeshThind">@RajeshThind</a> <p> Shahnaz Ali OBE is former Director of Equality, Inclusion and Human Rights NHSNW. Now a freelance consultant Making Equality Work and Lay Council member for University of Bradford. You can read more about her work at the <a href= "https://nursingnarratives.com/advisory-panel/">Nursing Narratives website</a>, her <a href= "https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shahnaz_Ali">Wikipedia page</a>, and on <a href= "https://uk.linkedin.com/in/shahnazali">LinkedIn</a>.</p> <p> Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;" href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a> </p>]]></content:encoded>

    <item>
      <title>Desperation &amp; Defiance: "Israel"'s Assassinations of Haniyeh &amp; Shukr, &amp; the Resolve of the Axis of Resistance w/ al-Fida'i Media &amp; Matteo Capasso</title>
      <itunes:title>Desperation &amp;amp; Defiance: &quot;Israel&quot;&#39;s Assassinations of Haniyeh &amp;amp; Shukr, &amp;amp; the Resolve of the Axis of Resistance w/ al-Fida&#39;i Media &amp;amp; Matteo Capasso</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 02 Aug 2024 12:36:17 +0000</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[6c35e4f3-984a-4575-aa51-7caec0550867]]></guid>
      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/desperation-defiance-israels-assassinations-of-haniyeh-shukr-the-resolve-of-the-axis-of-resistance-w-al-fidai-media-matteo-capasso]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<p>In this critical Dispatch episode of Guerrilla History, we are joined by Abdullah Shehadeh from al-Feda'i Media (formerly known as al-Falastineyeh) and Matteo Capasso (whom you will remember from our episode on the <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/everyday-politics-in-gaddafis-libyan-arab-jamahiriya-w-matteo-capasso"> Libyan Arab Jamahiriya</a>) to discuss the assassinations by the Zionist entity of Ismail Haniyeh (political leader of Hamas) and Fuad Shukr (military commander of Hezbollah), as well as what we might expect from the Axis of Resistance going forward.  This is a very timely discussion, and one which we hope helps you analyze the situation as it continues to unfold.</p> <p>References made in the episode were to the <a href= "https://www.channel4.com/programmes/defiance-fighting-the-far-right"> documentary Defiance</a>, Sarah Jilani's book <a href= "https://edinburghuniversitypress.com/book-subjectivity-and-decolonisation-in-the-post-independence-novel-and-film.html"> Subjectivity and Decolonization in the Post-Independence Novel and Film</a>, and the <a href= "https://www.youtube.com/@MidEastCritique">Middle East Critique video lecture series</a> hosted by Matteo.  Click on the hyperlinks to check them out!</p> <p><strong>al-Fida'i Media</strong> is an independent, viewer supported media network amplifying Palestinian voices for resistance, liberation, and return to a free Palestine.  Be sure to check out their work on their website <a href= "alfidai.org">alfidai.org</a>, and follow them on social media, where their handle on <a href="twitter.com/fidaimedia">Twitter</a> and <a href= "https://www.instagram.com/fidaimedia/p/CzXUqTwJilf/?next=%2Fpondsidehk%2Ffeed%2F&locale=%E8%B0%B7%E6%AD%8C%E8%89%B2%E6%B5%81%E9%9C%B8%E5%B1%8F%E6%8E%A8%E5%B9%BF%E2%96%B2%E8%B0%B7%E6%AD%8C%E6%8E%A8%E5%B9%BF%E8%AE%A4%E8%AF%81seo8.vip%E2%96%BC%E6%B7%98%E7%89%B9%E6%8E%A8%E5%B9%BF%E6%8E%A8%E4%B8%8D%E5%8A%A8%E2%97%8F%E8%B0%B7%E6%AD%8C%E6%8E%A8%E5%B9%BF%E8%AE%A4%E8%AF%81seo8.vip%E2%97%8Fgoogle%E4%BB%BF%E7%89%8C%E5%BC%95%E6%B5%81%E6%8A%80%E5%B7%A7%E2%94%84%E8%B0%B7%E6%AD%8C%E6%8E%A8%E5%B9%BF%E8%AE%A4%E8%AF%81seo8.vip%E2%94%84pnZv"> Instagram</a> is @fidaimedia</p> <p><strong>Matteo Capasso </strong>is the editor of the invaluable journal <a href= "https://www.tandfonline.com/journals/ccri20">Middle East Critique</a> (on twitter <a href= "twitter.com/MidEastCritique">@MidEastCritique</a>), and his work pertains to political economy and international relations.  He is a Marie Curie Fellow between the University of Venice and Columbia University.  In addition to picking up <a href= "https://press.syr.edu/supressbooks/5580/everyday-politics-in-the-libyan-arab-jamahiriya/"> his book</a>, you can follow him on twitter <a href= "twitter.com/capassomat">@capassomat</a>.</p> <p><span style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content:</span> <a style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;" href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a><span style="font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> </span></p>]]></description>
      
      <content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>In this critical Dispatch episode of Guerrilla History, we are joined by Abdullah Shehadeh from al-Feda'i Media (formerly known as al-Falastineyeh) and Matteo Capasso (whom you will remember from our episode on the <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/everyday-politics-in-gaddafis-libyan-arab-jamahiriya-w-matteo-capasso"> Libyan Arab Jamahiriya</a>) to discuss the assassinations by the Zionist entity of Ismail Haniyeh (political leader of Hamas) and Fuad Shukr (military commander of Hezbollah), as well as what we might expect from the Axis of Resistance going forward. This is a very timely discussion, and one which we hope helps you analyze the situation as it continues to unfold.</p> <p>References made in the episode were to the <a href= "https://www.channel4.com/programmes/defiance-fighting-the-far-right"> documentary Defiance</a>, Sarah Jilani's book <a href= "https://edinburghuniversitypress.com/book-subjectivity-and-decolonisation-in-the-post-independence-novel-and-film.html"> Subjectivity and Decolonization in the Post-Independence Novel and Film</a>, and the <a href= "https://www.youtube.com/@MidEastCritique">Middle East Critique video lecture series</a> hosted by Matteo. Click on the hyperlinks to check them out!</p> <p>al-Fida'i Media is an independent, viewer supported media network amplifying Palestinian voices for resistance, liberation, and return to a free Palestine. Be sure to check out their work on their website <a href= "alfidai.org">alfidai.org</a>, and follow them on social media, where their handle on <a href="twitter.com/fidaimedia">Twitter</a> and <a href= "https://www.instagram.com/fidaimedia/p/CzXUqTwJilf/?next=%2Fpondsidehk%2Ffeed%2F&locale=%E8%B0%B7%E6%AD%8C%E8%89%B2%E6%B5%81%E9%9C%B8%E5%B1%8F%E6%8E%A8%E5%B9%BF%E2%96%B2%E8%B0%B7%E6%AD%8C%E6%8E%A8%E5%B9%BF%E8%AE%A4%E8%AF%81seo8.vip%E2%96%BC%E6%B7%98%E7%89%B9%E6%8E%A8%E5%B9%BF%E6%8E%A8%E4%B8%8D%E5%8A%A8%E2%97%8F%E8%B0%B7%E6%AD%8C%E6%8E%A8%E5%B9%BF%E8%AE%A4%E8%AF%81seo8.vip%E2%97%8Fgoogle%E4%BB%BF%E7%89%8C%E5%BC%95%E6%B5%81%E6%8A%80%E5%B7%A7%E2%94%84%E8%B0%B7%E6%AD%8C%E6%8E%A8%E5%B9%BF%E8%AE%A4%E8%AF%81seo8.vip%E2%94%84pnZv"> Instagram</a> is @fidaimedia</p> <p>Matteo Capasso is the editor of the invaluable journal <a href= "https://www.tandfonline.com/journals/ccri20">Middle East Critique</a> (on twitter <a href= "twitter.com/MidEastCritique">@MidEastCritique</a>), and his work pertains to political economy and international relations.
