    <item>
      <title>Great Replacement: Politics, Patriarchy, &amp; Islamophobia in Far Right Conspiracy Theories w/ Luiz Manuel Hernandez Aguilar &amp; Sarah Bracke</title>
      <itunes:title>Great Replacement: Politics, Patriarchy, &amp;amp; Islamophobia in Far Right Conspiracy Theories w/ Luiz Manuel Hernandez Aguilar &amp;amp; Sarah Bracke</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 26 Jul 2024 11:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[2043ef8a-5ecc-4a56-a73d-e89c198e406a]]></guid>
      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/great-replacement-politics-patriarchy-islamophobia-in-far-right-conspiracy-theories-w-luiz-manuel-hernandez-aguilar-sarah-bracke]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<p>In this terrific episode of Guerrilla History, Adnan and returning guest co-host Breht discuss the essays of an important new book studying many aspects of the history and contemporary expression of right wing demographic obsessions, anti-immigrant and fascistic patriarchies, and the politics of Islamophobia in Europe, North America and beyond with co-editors Luiz Manuel Hernandez Aguilar and Sarah Bracke.  The book is <a href= "https://www.routledge.com/The-Politics-of-Replacement-Demographic-Fears-Conspiracy-Theories-and-Race-Wars/Bracke-HernandezAguilar/p/book/9781032304069"> The Politics of Replacement: Demographic Fears, Conspiracy Theories, and Race Wars</a>, and is definitely worth picking up!</p> <p><strong>Sarah Bracke</strong> is Professor of Sociology of Gender and Sexuality at the University of Amsterdam, the Netherlands. She is the principal investigator of the research project <em>EnGendering Europe's "Muslim Question"</em>, funded by the Dutch Research Council.  Follow her on twitter @SarahABracke</p> <p><strong>Luis Manuel Hernández Aguilar</strong> is an associate researcher at the European University Viadrina, Frankfurt Oder, Germany. He holds a PhD in sociology by the Goethe-University Frankfurt am Main. His research interests focus on racism, Islamophobia and antisemitism, conspiracy theories, and the far right.</p> <p><span style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content:</span> <a style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;" href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a><span style="font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> </span></p> <p class="p1"> </p>]]></description>
      
      <content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>In this terrific episode of Guerrilla History, Adnan and returning guest co-host Breht discuss the essays of an important new book studying many aspects of the history and contemporary expression of right wing demographic obsessions, anti-immigrant and fascistic patriarchies, and the politics of Islamophobia in Europe, North America and beyond with co-editors Luiz Manuel Hernandez Aguilar and Sarah Bracke. The book is <a href= "https://www.routledge.com/The-Politics-of-Replacement-Demographic-Fears-Conspiracy-Theories-and-Race-Wars/Bracke-HernandezAguilar/p/book/9781032304069"> The Politics of Replacement: Demographic Fears, Conspiracy Theories, and Race Wars</a>, and is definitely worth picking up!</p> <p>Sarah Bracke is Professor of Sociology of Gender and Sexuality at the University of Amsterdam, the Netherlands. She is the principal investigator of the research project <em>EnGendering Europe's "Muslim Question"</em>, funded by the Dutch Research Council. Follow her on twitter @SarahABracke</p> <p>Luis Manuel Hernández Aguilar is an associate researcher at the European University Viadrina, Frankfurt Oder, Germany. He holds a PhD in sociology by the Goethe-University Frankfurt am Main. His research interests focus on racism, Islamophobia and antisemitism, conspiracy theories, and the far right.</p> <p> Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;" href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a> </p> <p class="p1"> </p>]]></content:encoded>

    <item>
      <title>Bob Menendez &amp; US-Cuba Policy w/ Liz Oliva Fernández from Belly of the Beast</title>
      <itunes:title>Bob Menendez &amp;amp; US-Cuba Policy w/ Liz Oliva Fernández from Belly of the Beast</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 19 Jul 2024 11:28:11 +0000</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[c43173bd-8eeb-4184-affa-eababc9166b4]]></guid>
      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/bob-menendez-us-cuba-policy-w-liz-oliva-fernndez-from-belly-of-the-beast]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<p>In this episode of Guerrilla History, we are lucky to be joined by a special guest in Cuba as well as a special guest host whom many of you will likely remember from past episodes of the show.  Here, we bring on Cuban journalist <a href= "https://www.bellyofthebeastcuba.com/team">Liz Oliva Fernández from Belly of the Beast</a> to discuss Bob Menendez (who was just convicted on corruption charges), US-Cuba policy, and how these are related. This episode is being based off of two documentaries that Liz hosted for Belly of the Beast - <a href= "https://youtu.be/PfRTNTWkPgY?si=1JA3Q3m8BLJ_6Luc">Hardliner of the Hudson</a> which takes a deep look at Menendez, and <a href= "https://youtu.be/XaKB3pSLmGU?si=MuIkpX5lMWaBYjjE">Uphill on the Hill</a> which is an examination of recent US-Cuba policy. Watch these, and subscribe to <a href= "https://www.youtube.com/@BellyofTheBeastCuba">Belly of the Beast on YouTube</a>!</p> <p>Adnan was not able to join Henry for this one, so we drafted in our friend and former guest <strong><a href= "twitter.com/trgenovese">Taylor Genovese</a></strong> as a special guest host.  Taylor is an Assistant Professor of Philosophy at Dutchess Community College, an editor at <a href= "iskrabooks.org">Iskra Books</a>, and a documentary filmmaker.  You may remember Taylor as a guest from two previous episodes - <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/peasants-revolt-of-1381-w-taylor-genovese"> Peasants' Revolt of 1381</a> and <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/art-and-the-working-class-w-taylor-genovese"> Art and the Working Class</a>.  Major thanks to Taylor for coming in on relatively short notice for this one!</p> <p><strong>Liz Oliva Fernández</strong> is a Cuban journalist and the presenter of The War on Cuba, for which she won a Gracie Award. Apart from her journalism and filmmaking, Liz is a dedicated anti-racist and feminist activist.   Follow Belly of the Beast on Twitter <a href= "twitter.com/bellybeastcuba">@bellybeastcuba</a> to keep up with Liz's work.</p> <p><span style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content:</span> <a style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;" href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a><span style="font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> </span></p>]]></description>
      
      <content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>In this episode of Guerrilla History, we are lucky to be joined by a special guest in Cuba as well as a special guest host whom many of you will likely remember from past episodes of the show. Here, we bring on Cuban journalist <a href= "https://www.bellyofthebeastcuba.com/team">Liz Oliva Fernández from Belly of the Beast</a> to discuss Bob Menendez (who was just convicted on corruption charges), US-Cuba policy, and how these are related. This episode is being based off of two documentaries that Liz hosted for Belly of the Beast - <a href= "https://youtu.be/PfRTNTWkPgY?si=1JA3Q3m8BLJ_6Luc">Hardliner of the Hudson</a> which takes a deep look at Menendez, and <a href= "https://youtu.be/XaKB3pSLmGU?si=MuIkpX5lMWaBYjjE">Uphill on the Hill</a> which is an examination of recent US-Cuba policy. Watch these, and subscribe to <a href= "https://www.youtube.com/@BellyofTheBeastCuba">Belly of the Beast on YouTube</a>!</p> <p>Adnan was not able to join Henry for this one, so we drafted in our friend and former guest <a href= "twitter.com/trgenovese">Taylor Genovese</a> as a special guest host.     <item>
      <title>An Ethnographic &amp; Sociological Study of the Delhi Metro w/ Rashmi Sadana</title>
      <itunes:title>An Ethnographic &amp;amp; Sociological Study of the Delhi Metro w/ Rashmi Sadana</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 12 Jul 2024 07:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[011784c3-8770-4442-b1a5-2a09a12798f4]]></guid>
      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/an-ethnographic-sociological-study-of-the-delhi-metro-w-rashmi-sadana]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<p>In this episode of Guerrilla History, we bring on the wonderful Professor Rashmi Sadana to discuss the Delhi metro system from a political economic, sociological, and ethnographic framework, based on her terrific book <a href= "https://www.ucpress.edu/book/9780520383968/the-moving-city">The Moving City: Scenes from the Delhi Metro and the Social Life of Infrastructure</a>.  Talking about the political and sociological dimensions of infrastructure is a critically important topic for us to focus on, and one which we are trying to devote a bit more time to.  We recommend also checking out our recent conversation with <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/red-sea-shipping-gaza-genocide-w-laleh-khalili"> Laleh Khalili on Red Sea Shipping & the Gaza Genocide</a> to hear a bit more of our discussions on transportation infrastructure.</p> <p><strong>Rashmi Sadana</strong>  is Professor of Anthropology at George Mason University and author of <a href= "https://www.ucpress.edu/book/9780520269576/english-heart-hindi-heartland"><em>English Heart, Hindi Heartland: The Political Life of Literature in India</em></a>.  Keep up to date with the Professor's work by checking out <a href="https://soan.gmu.edu/people/rsadana">her faculty webpage</a>.</p> <p><span style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content:</span> <a style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;" href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a><span style="font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> </span></p>]]></description>
      
      <content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>In this episode of Guerrilla History, we bring on the wonderful Professor Rashmi Sadana to discuss the Delhi metro system from a political economic, sociological, and ethnographic framework, based on her terrific book <a href= "https://www.ucpress.edu/book/9780520383968/the-moving-city">The Moving City: Scenes from the Delhi Metro and the Social Life of Infrastructure</a>. Talking about the political and sociological dimensions of infrastructure is a critically important topic for us to focus on, and one which we are trying to devote a bit more time to. We recommend also checking out our recent conversation with <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/red-sea-shipping-gaza-genocide-w-laleh-khalili"> Laleh Khalili on Red Sea Shipping & the Gaza Genocide</a> to hear a bit more of our discussions on transportation infrastructure.</p> <p>Rashmi Sadana is Professor of Anthropology at George Mason University and author of <a href= "https://www.ucpress.edu/book/9780520269576/english-heart-hindi-heartland"><em>English Heart, Hindi Heartland: The Political Life of Literature in India</em></a>. Keep up to date with the Professor's work by checking out <a href="https://soan.gmu.edu/people/rsadana">her faculty webpage</a>.</p> <p> Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;" href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a> </p>]]></content:encoded>

    <item>
      <title>Haiti, Kenya, Imperialism, &amp; More!  GH on Revolutionary Blackout Network</title>
      <itunes:title>Haiti, Kenya, Imperialism, &amp;amp; More!  GH on Revolutionary Blackout Network</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 05 Jul 2024 07:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[1869deff-f11f-47be-b944-2813d5454a53]]></guid>
      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/haiti-kenya-imperialism-more-gh-on-revolutionary-blackout-network]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<p>In this episode, we bring you an appearance we recently made on <a href= "https://www.youtube.com/@revolutionaryblackout7315">Revolutionary Blackout Network</a>.  Adnan and Henry were invited to sit on a roundtable discussion alongside long-time Indigenous activist John Looking Glass to discuss a wide variety of topics.       <title>Red Sea Shipping &amp; Gaza Genocide w/ Laleh Khalili</title>
      <itunes:title>Red Sea Shipping &amp;amp; Gaza Genocide w/ Laleh Khalili</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 28 Jun 2024 06:07:06 +0000</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[443a0f6d-bc81-4151-ab26-36475c4b6ffd]]></guid>
      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/red-sea-shipping-gaza-genocide-w-laleh-khalili]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<p>In this episode of Guerrilla History, we bring on the esteemed Professor Laleh Khalili to discuss Red Sea Shipping and the regional consequences of the Gaza Genocide. This conversation bridges two of the major topics of her work, and is an incredibly thought provoking and generative discussion.  We would love to hear what you find particularly useful  from this one, so let us know on Twitter once you listen!</p> <p><strong>Laleh Khalili</strong> is Professor and Director of the Center for Gulf Studies at the Institute of Arab and Islamic Studies at University of Exeter, and author of multiple books we discussed today including <a href= "https://www.versobooks.com/en-gb/products/606-sinews-of-war-and-trade">Sinews of War and Trade: Shipping and Capitalism in the Arabian Peninsula</a>,  <a href= "https://www.sup.org/books/title/?id=21640">Time in the Shadows: Confinement in Counterinsurgencies</a>, and <a href= "https://www.cambridge.org/core/books/heroes-and-martyrs-of-palestine/06840B11626C45A8176D15FA2581F89B"> Heroes and Martyrs of Palestine: The Politics of National Commemoration</a>.  Follow her on twitter <a href= "twitter.com/LalehKhalili">@LalehKhalili</a></p> <p><span style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content:</span> <a style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;" href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a><span style="font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> </span></p>]]></description>
      
      <content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>In this episode of Guerrilla History, we bring on the esteemed Professor Laleh Khalili to discuss Red Sea Shipping and the regional consequences of the Gaza Genocide. We would love to hear what you find particularly useful from this one, so let us know on Twitter once you listen!</p> <p>Laleh Khalili is Professor and Director of the Center for Gulf Studies at the Institute of Arab and Islamic Studies at University of Exeter, and author of multiple books we discussed today including <a href= "https://www.versobooks.com/en-gb/products/606-sinews-of-war-and-trade">Sinews of War and Trade: Shipping and Capitalism in the Arabian Peninsula</a>, <a href= "https://www.sup.org/books/title/?id=21640">Time in the Shadows: Confinement in Counterinsurgencies</a>, and <a href= "https://www.cambridge.org/core/books/heroes-and-martyrs-of-palestine/06840B11626C45A8176D15FA2581F89B"> Heroes and Martyrs of Palestine: The Politics of National Commemoration</a>.     <item>
      <title>Commune to Capitalism - Decollectivization of Agriculture in China w/ Zhun Xu</title>
      <itunes:title>Commune to Capitalism - Decollectivization of Agriculture in China w/ Zhun Xu</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 21 Jun 2024 06:10:51 +0000</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[7b77fec7-a470-416a-8d9b-9e0e05c33e22]]></guid>
      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/commune-to-capitalism-decollectivization-of-agriculture-in-china-w-zhun-xu]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<p>In this episode of Guerrilla History, we once again have our great friend and comrade Zhun Xu, whom you should remember from two previous episodes of the show, <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/north-korea-industrial-agriculture-w-zhun-xu"> North Korea & Industrial Agriculture</a> as well as  <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/sanctions-against-china-their-political-economy-w-zhun-xu"> Sanctions Against China & Their Political Economy</a>.  Here, we discuss Zhun fantastic book <a href= "https://monthlyreview.org/product/from-commune-to-capitalism-how-chinas-peasants-lost-collective-farming-and-gained-urban-poverty/"> <em>From Commune to Capitalism: How China's Peasants Lost Collective Farming and Gained Urban Poverty</em></a>!  Unsurprisingly, this was a fabulous discussion, and is a really important conversation when added to the two conversations on this period of history that we had in our Modern Chinese History miniseries with Ken Hammond - <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/the-great-leap-forward-cultural-revolution-w-ken-hammond-modern-chinese-history-pt-3"> The Great Leap Forward & Cultural Revolution</a> and the <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/the-deng-reform-period-w-ken-hammond-modern-chinese-history-pt-4">Deng Reform Period</a>. It might be helpful to listen to those two episodes first, but regardless, we are sure that you will find great use in this conversation!</p> <p><strong>Zhun Xu</strong> is Associate Professor of Economics at John Jay College, City University of New York. He is on the editorial boards of Science and Society and the Journal of Labor and Society. His recent book is <a href= "https://monthlyreview.org/product/from-commune-to-capitalism-how-chinas-peasants-lost-collective-farming-and-gained-urban-poverty/"> <em>From Commune to Capitalism: How China's Peasants Lost Collective Farming and Gained Urban Poverty</em></a>.</p> <p><span style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content:</span> <a style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;" href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a><span style="font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> </span></p>]]></description>

    <item>
      <title>Football!  Palestine, Copa América, &amp; the Euros w/ Alex Aviña</title>
      <itunes:title>Football!  Palestine, Copa América, &amp;amp; the Euros w/ Alex Aviña</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 14 Jun 2024 06:29:10 +0000</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[003af05d-95a6-4d00-bf36-3df3b0c880dd]]></guid>
      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/football-palestine-copa-amrica-the-euros-w-alex-avia]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<p>In this episode of Guerrilla History, we end up continuing our informal and unplanned "Football" (soccer to those of you in the US and Canada) miniseries with our friend and comrade Alex Aviña!  Here, we discuss some of the Palestine related goings-on in the football world, as well as give a preview and make predictions for the Copa América and European Championships, which are getting kicked off at the time of this episode being released.  If you've not already heard our previous Football episodes with Alex, check out our first <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/intelligence-briefing-the-beautiful-game-w-alexander-avin"> The Beautiful  Game</a>, plus our newer <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/the-world-cup-sport-politics-history-and-propaganda-w-alexander-avia"> World Cup: Sport, Politics, History, & Propaganda</a>. We are sure that even those of you who are not super football fans will get a lot of use from these discussions!</p> <p><strong>Alexander Aviña</strong> is associate professor of Latin American history at Arizona State University and author of <em>Specters of Revolution: Peasant Guerrillas in the Cold War Mexican Countryside</em>. Alex's website is available at <a href= "alexanderavina.com">alexanderavina.com</a>, and he can be followed on twitter <a href= "twitter.com/Alexander_Avina">@Alexander_Avina</a></p> <p><span style=     <item>
      <title>Haiti as Empire's Laboratory w/ Jemima Pierre</title>
      <itunes:title>Haiti as Empire&#39;s Laboratory w/ Jemima Pierre</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 07 Jun 2024 05:19:21 +0000</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[ab4189f4-8c19-4a73-bc52-79e761f0f774]]></guid>
      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/haiti-as-empires-laboratory-w-jemima-pierre]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<p>In this episode of Guerrilla History, we bring on the absolutely terrific Professor Jemima Pierre to discuss her vital piece <a href="https://nacla.org/haiti-empire-laboratory">Haiti as Empire's Laboratory</a>, which came out in NACLA late last year.  Here, we discuss the history of Western Imperialist intervention in  Haiti primarily since the revolution, and why Haiti is often overlooked outside of analysis of the Revolution, or the current material situation divorced from any historical understanding.  You may remember our episode <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/haiti-and-western-intervention-w-pascal-robert-dispatch"> Haiti and Western Intervention w/ Pascal Robert</a>, which came out just over a year and a half ago.  This conversation is in much the same vein, with some updating and additional analysis, so if you haven't already listened to that other conversation, please do so!</p> <p><strong>Jemima Pierre</strong> is Professor at the Social Justice Institute at the University of British Columbia and is the <a href="https://blackallianceforpeace.com/haiti">Haiti/Americas Coordinator with the Black Alliance for Peace</a>. She is the author of The Predicament of Blackness: Postcolonial Ghana and the Politics of Race and numerous academic and public articles about Haiti.  Try to find her on her secret twitter account, one of the best follows out there, but you have to do the searching yourself!</p> <p><span style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content:</span> <a style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;" href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a><span style="font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> </span></p> <p> </p>]]></description>
      
      <content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>In this episode of Guerrilla History, we bring on the absolutely terrific Professor Jemima Pierre to discuss her vital piece <a href="https://nacla.org/haiti-empire-laboratory">Haiti as Empire's Laboratory</a>, which came out in NACLA late last year. Here, we discuss the history of Western Imperialist intervention in Haiti primarily since the revolution, and why Haiti is often overlooked outside of analysis of the Revolution, or the current material situation divorced from any historical understanding. You may remember our episode <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/haiti-and-western-intervention-w-pascal-robert-dispatch"> Haiti and Western Intervention w/ Pascal Robert</a>, which came out just over a year and a half ago. This conversation is in much the same vein, with some updating and additional analysis, so if you haven't already listened to that other conversation, please do so!</p> <p>Jemima Pierre is Professor at the Social Justice Institute at the University of British Columbia and is the <a href="https://blackallianceforpeace.com/haiti">Haiti/Americas Coordinator with the Black Alliance for Peace</a>. She is the author of The Predicament of Blackness: Postcolonial Ghana and the Politics of Race and numerous academic and public articles about Haiti. Try to find her on her secret twitter account, one of the best follows out there, but you have to do the searching yourself!</p> <p> Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;" href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a> </p> <p> </p>]]></content:encoded>

    <item>
      <title>Black &amp; Brown Resistance in the UK (1960s-80s) w/ Preeti Dhillon</title>
      <itunes:title>Black &amp;amp; Brown Resistance in the UK (1960s-80s) w/ Preeti Dhillon</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 31 May 2024 07:04:17 +0000</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[b5130b0a-e43b-4ec0-a666-450d4a953a60]]></guid>
      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/black-brown-resistance-in-the-uk-1960s-80s-w-preeti-dhillon]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<p>In this episode of Guerrilla History, we discuss a fascinating new book <a href="https://geni.us/the-shoulders-we">The Shoulders We Stand On: How Black and Brown people fought for change in the United Kingdom</a> with its author, Preeti Dhillon.  This conversation is a terrific look at the repression against racially oppressed communities in the UK from the 1960s-80s, and the resistance of those communities.  This episode works excellently in conjunction with our previous episode  <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/african-caribbean-people-in-britain-a-history-w-hakim-adi"> African & Caribbean People in Britain - A History w/ Hakim Adi</a>, so be sure to listen to that episode as well if you have not already!</p> <p><strong>Preeti Dhillon</strong> is is a researcher, writer and historian who is passionate about capturing hidden stories from oppressed and marginalised communities. Preeti was an Independent Research Fellow with the Women's History Network 2021-2022 and has written for many outlets and venues.  Keep up with her work by checking out <a href="https://www.preetidhillon.co.uk/">her website</a>, and follow her on twitter <a href= "https://twitter.com/preetikdhillon">@preetikdhillon</a>.</p> <p><span style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content:</span> <a style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;" href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a><span style="font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> </span></p>]]></description>

      <title>North Korea &amp; Industrial Agriculture w/ Zhun Xu</title>
      <itunes:title>North Korea &amp;amp; Industrial Agriculture w/ Zhun Xu</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 24 May 2024 07:07:08 +0000</pubDate>

      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/north-korea-industrial-agriculture-w-zhun-xu]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<p>In this episode of Guerrilla History, we bring back our great friend and comrade Zhun Xu, whom you may remember from our episode  <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/sanctions-against-china-their-political-economy-w-zhun-xu"> Sanctions Against China & Their Political Economy</a> from our Sanctions As War miniseries.  In this episode, we discuss Zhun terrific new article in Monthly Review, <a href= "https://monthlyreview.org/2024/03/01/industrial-agriculture-lessons-from-north-korea/"> Industrial Agriculture: Lessons from North Korea</a>!  This conversation was incredibly generative, and will certainly be of great benefit to you whether you are someone who studies agricultural systems, the DPRK, or none of the above.  Stay tuned, Zhun will appear on the show again VERY soon for another great topic and discussion...</p> <p><strong>Zhun Xu</strong> is Associate Professor of Economics at John Jay College, City University of New York. He is on the editorial boards of Science and Society and the Journal of Labor and Society. His recent book is <a href= "https://monthlyreview.org/product/from-commune-to-capitalism-how-chinas-peasants-lost-collective-farming-and-gained-urban-poverty/"> <em>From Commune to Capitalism: How China's Peasants Lost Collective Farming and Gained Urban Poverty</em></a>.</p> <p><span style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content:</span> <a style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;" href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a><span style="font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> </span></p>]]></description>

      <title>A Polycentric World &amp; the 'Sixth Great Power' w/ Paris Yeros</title>
      <itunes:title>A Polycentric World &amp;amp; the &#39;Sixth Great Power&#39; w/ Paris Yeros</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 17 May 2024 06:49:19 +0000</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[332eda41-2bbf-4a30-8a31-08c465f200cf]]></guid>

      <description><![CDATA[<p>In this episode of Guerrilla History, we bring on the fantastic and vitally important Paris Yeros to discuss his fabulous article <a href= "https://www.agrariansouth.org/2023/12/16/a-polycentric-world-will-only-be-possible-by-the-intervention-of-the-sixth-great-power/"> A Polycentric World Will Only Be Possible by the Intervention of the 'Sixth Great Power'</a>, which was published by the <a href= "https://www.agrariansouth.org/">Agrarian South Network</a>.  Paris himself and the Agrarian South Network more generally are both some of the best resources out there today, and we hope that you will engage with more of their work. We hope that this conversation similarly will be of great use to you!</p> <p><strong>Paris Yeros</strong> is the a Professor at the Federal University of ABC in Brazil, and is on the Editorial Board of the Agrarian South Network.  The edited book he worked on, which is mentioned in the conversation, <a href= "https://cup.columbia.edu/book/gender-in-agrarian-transitions/9788195839438"> Gender in Agrarian Transitions: Liberation Perspectives from the South</a>, is now available.  We also recommend you keep up to date by checking out <a href="parisyeros.wordpress.com">Paris's website</a> and following him on twitter <a href= "twitter.com/parisyeros">@parisyeros</a></p> <p><span style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content:</span> <a style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;" href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a><span style="font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> </span></p>]]></description>

    <item>
      <title>UN, the Palestine Question, &amp; International Law w/ Ardi Imseis (Crossover w/ The Majlis)</title>
      <itunes:title>UN, the Palestine Question, &amp;amp; International Law w/ Ardi Imseis (Crossover w/ The Majlis)</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 10 May 2024 07:31:48 +0000</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[85f15adc-088d-4fc5-bd31-dce13a9b94e1]]></guid>
      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/un-the-palestine-question-international-law-w-ardi-imseis-crossover-w-the-majlis]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<p>In this special episode of Guerrilla History, we bring you a crossover episode done in collaboration with <a href= "https://open.spotify.com/show/0nZKmWviaYXBtqwuxOpbbD">The Majlis</a>, a project by the Muslim Societies Global Perspectives project at Queens University, which is hosted by our own Adnan Husain (so be sure to <a href= "https://open.spotify.com/show/0nZKmWviaYXBtqwuxOpbbD">subscribe on your podcast app</a>!). Here, Adnan and Dr. Ardi Imseis, explore the complexities of international law, human rights and the urgent imperative of addressing the current situation of Palestine. Through meticulous research and unwavering dedication to justice, Imseis's scholarship offers invaluable insights into the legal frameworks that underpin the Palestinian struggle. As we unpack the historical narratives and contemporary realities shaping the question of Palestine, Imseis's work serves as a guiding beacon, challenging prevailing norms and advocating for a rights-based approach to peace and justice.</p> <p><strong>Ardi Imseis</strong> joined the Queen's University Faculty of Law in 2018, following a 12-year career as a UN official in the Middle East, first with the United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestine Refugees in the Near East (UNRWA), and then with the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR). Dr. Imseis's Latest Book is <a href= "https://www.cambridge.org/core/books/united-nations-and-the-question-of-palestine/E8241B33B6C07028765E5E6785AF5CDE"> The United Nations and the Question of Palestine: Rule by Law and the Structure of International Legal Subalternity</a>.  You can  follow him on twitter <a href= "twitter.com/ArdiImseis">@ArdiImseis</a></p> <p><span style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content:</span> <a style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;" href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a><span style="font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> </span></p>]]></description>
      
      <content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>In this special episode of Guerrilla History, we bring you a crossover episode done in collaboration with <a href= "https://open.spotify.com/show/0nZKmWviaYXBtqwuxOpbbD">The Majlis</a>, a project by the Muslim Societies Global Perspectives project at Queens University, which is hosted by our own Adnan Husain (so be sure to <a href= "https://open.spotify.com/show/0nZKmWviaYXBtqwuxOpbbD">subscribe on your podcast app</a>!).     <item>
      <title>The Deng Reform Period w/ Ken Hammond  (Modern Chinese History Pt. 4)</title>
      <itunes:title>The Deng Reform Period w/ Ken Hammond  (Modern Chinese History Pt. 4)</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 03 May 2024 07:25:11 +0000</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[4ad7e588-3a08-4ebc-b3a0-1512c21803fc]]></guid>
      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/the-deng-reform-period-w-ken-hammond-modern-chinese-history-pt-4]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<p>In this episode of Guerrilla History, we conclude our series on Modern Chinese History with this important, and inevitably controversial discussion of the Deng Reforms and the Reform Period!  Very important that no matter your ideological tendencies, you come into this episode with an open mind, because there will be a lot of useful information for you regardless of how you analyze the Deng Reforms overall - this is meant primarily as a resource to allow you to deepen your personal understanding and analysis of this critical juncture in Chinese and world history.  We definitely want to also thank Ken for spending over 6 hours with us on this mini-series, and we hope that you all get some use from it!</p> <p><strong>Ken Hammond</strong> is Professor of East Asian and Global History at New Mexico State University. He has been engaged in radical politics since his involvement in the anti-war movement at Kent State in 1968-70.  Ken is also the author of the book <a href= "https://1804books.com/products/chinas-revolution-and-the-quest-for-a-socialist-future"> China's Revolution & the Quest for a Socialist Future</a>.</p> <p><span style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content:</span> <a style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;" href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a><span style="font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> </span></p> <div id="highlighter--hover-tools" style="display: none;"> <div id="highlighter--hover-tools--container"> <div class="highlighter--icon       <content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>In this episode of Guerrilla History, we conclude our series on Modern Chinese History with this important, and inevitably controversial discussion of the Deng Reforms and the Reform Period! Very important that no matter your ideological tendencies, you come into this episode with an open mind, because there will be a lot of useful information for you regardless of how you analyze the Deng Reforms overall - this is meant primarily as a resource to allow you to deepen your personal understanding and analysis of this critical juncture in Chinese and world history. We definitely want to also thank Ken for spending over 6 hours with us on this mini-series, and we hope that you all get some use from it!</p> <p>Ken Hammond is Professor of East Asian and Global History at New Mexico State University. He has been engaged in radical politics since his involvement in the anti-war movement at Kent State in 1968-70. Ken is also the author of the book <a href= "https://1804books.com/products/chinas-revolution-and-the-quest-for-a-socialist-future"> China's Revolution & the Quest for a Socialist Future</a>.</p> <p> Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;" href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a> </p>]]></content:encoded>

    <item>
      <title>Everyday Politics in Gaddafi's Libyan Arab Jamahiriya w/ Matteo Capasso</title>
      <itunes:title>Everyday Politics in Gaddafi&#39;s Libyan Arab Jamahiriya w/ Matteo Capasso</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 26 Apr 2024 06:35:45 +0000</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[9b7b4624-6c90-4461-b410-4aa307e3092e]]></guid>
      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/everyday-politics-in-gaddafis-libyan-arab-jamahiriya-w-matteo-capasso]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<p>In this terrific episode of Guerrilla History, we bring on our comrade and friend Matteo Capasso to discuss his fantastic book <a href= "https://press.syr.edu/supressbooks/5580/everyday-politics-in-the-libyan-arab-jamahiriya/"> Everyday Politics in the Libyan Arab Jamahiriya</a>, a work based on oral histories and "provides a unique and vivid look into the political dynamics that characterized the everyday lives of Libyans, offering a compelling counterargument to those who insist on framing the history of the country as a stateless, authoritarian, and rogue state".  Really great conversation and a really important book, we already have plans for Matteo to come back on in a coming miniseries set to drop this summer!</p> <p><strong>Matteo Capasso </strong>is the editor of the invaluable journal <a href= "https://www.tandfonline.com/journals/ccri20">Middle East Critique</a> (on twitter <a href= "twitter.com/MidEastCritique">@MidEastCritique</a>), and his work pertains to political economy and international relations.  He is a Marie Curie Fellow between the University of Venice and Columbia University.  In addition to picking up <a href= "https://press.syr.edu/supressbooks/5580/everyday-politics-in-the-libyan-arab-jamahiriya/"> his book</a>, you can follow him on twitter <a href= "twitter.com/capassomat">@capassomat</a>.</p> <p><span style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content:</span> <a style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;" href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a><span style="font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> </span></p>]]></description>
      
      <content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>In this terrific episode of Guerrilla History, we bring on our comrade and friend Matteo Capasso to discuss his fantastic book <a href= "https://press.syr.edu/supressbooks/5580/everyday-politics-in-the-libyan-arab-jamahiriya/"> Everyday Politics in the Libyan Arab Jamahiriya</a>, a work based on oral histories and "provides a unique and vivid look into the political dynamics that characterized the everyday lives of Libyans, offering a compelling counterargument to those who insist on framing the history of the country as a stateless, authoritarian, and rogue state". Really great conversation and a really important book, we already have plans for Matteo to come back on in a coming miniseries set to drop this summer!</p> <p>Matteo Capasso is the editor of the invaluable journal <a href= "https://www.tandfonline.com/journals/ccri20">Middle East Critique</a> (on twitter <a href= "twitter.com/MidEastCritique">@MidEastCritique</a>), and his work pertains to political economy and international relations. He is a Marie Curie Fellow between the University of Venice and Columbia University. In addition to picking up <a href= "https://press.syr.edu/supressbooks/5580/everyday-politics-in-the-libyan-arab-jamahiriya/"> his book</a>, you can follow him on twitter <a href= "twitter.com/capassomat">@capassomat</a>.</p> <p> Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;" href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a> </p>]]></content:encoded>

    <item>
      <title>The Great Leap Forward &amp; Cultural Revolution w/ Ken Hammond  (Modern Chinese History Pt. 3)</title>
      <itunes:title>The Great Leap Forward &amp;amp; Cultural Revolution w/ Ken Hammond  (Modern Chinese History Pt. 3)</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 19 Apr 2024 07:08:35 +0000</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[1e9f8a0b-43a4-4c26-a185-b0abb8169b53]]></guid>
      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/the-great-leap-forward-cultural-revolution-w-ken-hammond-modern-chinese-history-pt-3]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<p>In this episode of Guerrilla History, we get into part 3 of our 4 part miniseries on modern Chinese history featuring Ken Hammond (and guest host Breht O'Shea of Revolutionary Left Radio) with an amazing discussion of The Great Leap Forward and The Cultural Revolution!  If you haven't already listened to part 1 of the series, on <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/the-taiping-boxer-rebellions-w-ken-hammond-modern-chinese-history-pt-1"> the Taiping and Boxer Rebellions</a>, or part 2 on <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/the-chinese-revolution-civil-war-w-ken-hammond-modern-chinese-history-pt-2"> The Chinese Revolution & Civil War</a>, be sure to go back and check those out because we pick up right where we left off last time.  With these final two episodes in the series, we enter the period where various ideological traditions diverge in their analysis of the events, but regardless of what ideological background you come from, we encourage you to listen to these and engage with the information, as we believe the information will help you deepen your own analysis regardless of your ideological position.  The final installment will drop in two weeks (with another episode in between), and will cover the Reform period, so be sure to subscribe to not miss that episode!</p> <p><strong>Ken Hammond</strong> is Professor of East Asian and Global History at New Mexico State University. He has been engaged in radical politics since his involvement in the anti-war movement at Kent State in 1968-70.  Ken is also the author of the book <a href= "https://1804books.com/products/chinas-revolution-and-the-quest-for-a-socialist-future"> China's Revolution & the Quest for a Socialist Future</a>.</p> <p><span style= "font-family: -apple-system,     <item>
      <title>For Palestine &amp; Liberated Texts w/ Louis Allday</title>
      <itunes:title>For Palestine &amp;amp; Liberated Texts w/ Louis Allday</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 29 Mar 2024 07:06:17 +0000</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[4300f345-7abd-49bb-821d-abda23fa9db2]]></guid>
      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/for-palestine-liberated-texts-w-louis-allday]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<p>In this outstanding episode of Guerrilla History, we have another installment of our Sources and Methods series, and this time with the terrific Louis Allday.  Here, we bring on Louis to discuss <a href="https://liberatedtexts.com/">Liberated Texts</a> and the work that is done within that project, as well as the recently released special edition of <a href= "https://www.ebb-magazine.com/issues/for-palestine-issue-1">Ebb Magazine, <em>For Palestine</em></a>.  We loved the conversation with Louis about preserving and spreading under-appreciated and supressed sources and books, Kanafani, solidarity with Palestine, and more, and we are sure you will too!  Be sure to check out the links we are including to the work Louis does for more!</p> <div class="single-post-content-text"> <p><strong>Louis Allday</strong> is a writer and historian. He has a PhD in History. He is the founding editor of <a href= "https://liberatedtexts.com/">Liberated Texts</a>, a book reviewing and publishing project dedicated to reviewing and (re)publishing works that have been neglected, overlooked or suppressed in the mainstream since their publication. In July 2022, in collaboration with Ebb Books, Liberated Texts published the first English language translation of <a href= "https://www.ebb-magazine.com/books/p/on-zionist-literature">Ghassan Kanafani's On Zionist Literature</a> to commemorate the fiftieth anniversary of his assassination. Louis is also an editor at Ebb Magazine.  Follow Louis on twitter <a href= "twitter.com/Louis_Allday">@Louis_Allday</a></p> </div> <p><span style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content:</span> <a style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;" href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a><span style="font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> </span></p> <div id="highlighter--hover-tools" style="display: none;"> <div id="highlighter--hover-tools--container"> <div class="highlighter--icon highlighter--icon-copy" title="Copy">  </div> <div class="highlighter--separator"> </div> <div class="highlighter--icon highlighter--icon-delete" title= "Delete"> </div> </div> </div> <div id="highlighter--hover-tools" style="display: none;"> <div id="highlighter--hover-tools--container"> <div class="highlighter--icon highlighter--icon-copy" title="Copy">  </div> <div class="highlighter--separator"> </div> <div class="highlighter--icon highlighter--icon-delete" title= "Delete"> </div> </div> </div> <div id="highlighter--hover-tools" style="display: none;"> <div id="highlighter--hover-tools--container"> <div class="highlighter--icon highlighter--icon-copy" title="Copy">  </div> <div class="highlighter--separator"> </div> <div class="highlighter--icon highlighter--icon-delete" title= "Delete"> </div> </div> </div> <div id="highlighter--hover-tools" style="display: none;"> <div id="highlighter--hover-tools--container"> <div class="highlighter--icon highlighter--icon-copy" title="Copy">  </div> <div class="highlighter--separator"> </div> <div class="highlighter--icon highlighter--icon-delete" title= "Delete"> </div> </div> </div> <div id="highlighter--hover-tools" style="display: none;"> <div id="highlighter--hover-tools--container"> <div class="highlighter--icon highlighter--icon-copy" title="Copy">  </div> <div class="highlighter--separator"> </div> <div class="highlighter--icon highlighter--icon-delete" title= "Delete"> </div> </div> </div>]]></description>
      
      <content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>In this outstanding episode of Guerrilla History, we have another installment of our Sources and Methods series, and this time with the terrific Louis Allday. Here, we bring on Louis to discuss <a href="https://liberatedtexts.com/">Liberated Texts</a> and the work that is done within that project, as well as the recently released special edition of <a href= "https://www.ebb-magazine.com/issues/for-palestine-issue-1">Ebb Magazine, <em>For Palestine</em></a>. We loved the conversation with Louis about preserving and spreading under-appreciated and supressed sources and books, Kanafani, solidarity with Palestine, and more, and we are sure you will too! Be sure to check out the links we are including to the work Louis does for more!</p> <p>Louis Allday is a writer and historian. He has a PhD in History. He is the founding editor of <a href= "https://liberatedtexts.com/">Liberated Texts</a>, a book reviewing and publishing project dedicated to reviewing and (re)publishing works that have been neglected, overlooked or suppressed in the mainstream since their publication. In July 2022, in collaboration with Ebb Books, Liberated Texts published the first English language translation of <a href= "https://www.ebb-magazine.com/books/p/on-zionist-literature">Ghassan Kanafani's On Zionist Literature</a> to commemorate the fiftieth anniversary of his assassination. Louis is also an editor at Ebb Magazine. Follow Louis on twitter <a href= "twitter.com/Louis_Allday">@Louis_Allday</a></p> <p> Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;" href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a> </p>]]></content:encoded>

    <item>
      <title>The Taiping &amp; Boxer Rebellions w/ Ken Hammond  (Modern Chinese History Pt. 1)</title>
      <itunes:title>The Taiping &amp;amp; Boxer Rebellions w/ Ken Hammond  (Modern Chinese History Pt. 1)</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 22 Mar 2024 06:30:04 +0000</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[f003bed5-fc55-4dd4-a4b3-d07ba10ee969]]></guid>
      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/the-taiping-boxer-rebellions-w-ken-hammond-modern-chinese-history-pt-1]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<p>In this episode of Guerrilla History, we launch our 4 part miniseries on modern Chinese history featuring Ken Hammond (and guest host Breht O'Shea of Revolutionary Left Radio) with this terrific discussion on the Taiping and Boxer Rebellions!  Be sure to go back and listen to the <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/chinas-revolution-the-quest-for-a-socialist-future-w-ken-hammond"> previous episode we did with Ken in the fall</a>, which serves as a bit of an introductory work for this miniseries. The other three installments will drop every other week (with other episodes in between), and will cover the Chinese Revolution/Civil War, the Great Leap Forward and Cultural Revolution, and the Reform period, so be sure to subscribe to not miss any of those coming episodes!</p> <p><strong>Ken Hammond</strong> is Professor of East Asian and Global History at New Mexico State University. He has been engaged in radical politics since his involvement in the anti-war movement at Kent State in 1968-70.  Ken is also the author of the book <a href= "https://1804books.com/products/chinas-revolution-and-the-quest-for-a-socialist-future"> China's Revolution & the Quest for a Socialist Future</a>.</p> <p><span style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content:</span> <a style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;" href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a><span style="font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open       <content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>In this episode of Guerrilla History, we launch our 4 part miniseries on modern Chinese history featuring Ken Hammond (and guest host Breht O'Shea of Revolutionary Left Radio) with this terrific discussion on the Taiping and Boxer Rebellions! Be sure to go back and listen to the <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/chinas-revolution-the-quest-for-a-socialist-future-w-ken-hammond"> previous episode we did with Ken in the fall</a>, which serves as a bit of an introductory work for this miniseries. Ken is also the author of the book <a href= "https://1804books.com/products/chinas-revolution-and-the-quest-for-a-socialist-future"> China's Revolution & the Quest for a Socialist Future</a>.</p> <p> Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;" href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a> </p>]]></content:encoded>

    <item>
      <title>History of Palestinian Communism w/ Patrick Higgins</title>
      <itunes:title>History of Palestinian Communism w/ Patrick Higgins</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 15 Mar 2024 07:19:13 +0000</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[b794d218-3ddb-4c14-91cd-9c44842f6db3]]></guid>
      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/history-of-palestinian-communism-w-patrick-higgins]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<p>In this absolutely fascinating and important episode of Guerrilla History, we are joined once again by Patrick Higgins to discuss the history of Palestinian communism. Patrick serves up an masterclass here, and honestly this one is worth listening to and then re-listening to while taking notes despite its 2 hour length.  You certainly don't want to miss this one!  Also be sure to share this with comrades, this episode is sure to benefit many!</p> <p>If you didn't catch Patrick's last appearance on the show, you should check out our episode <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/palestinian-resistance-vs-the-zionist-project-w-max-ajl-patrick-higgins"> Palestinian Resistance vs. The Zionist Project w/ Max Ajl & Patrick Higgins</a>, where he and comrade Max Ajl provided biting and vital analysis immediately after October 7.  A wonderful (and extremely popular) episode of Guerrilla History in its own right!</p> <p><span style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> <strong>Patrick Higgins</strong> is a researcher and writer, holding a PhD in Arab History.  Patrick recently completed his dissertation titled "Palestinian Revolution and World Imperialism in the 'American Century': 1945-1972".  While Patrick doesn't use social media, he is going to be <a href= "https://x.com/mideastcritique/status/1768261137445834757?s=46">co-presenting a class on April 13 on the topic History of Palestinian Revolution</a>, which is hosted by the excellent journal Middle East Critique as part of their Ramadan Course on Palestine and Imperialism.  The whole course is free, so sign up!</span></p> <p><span style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content:</span> <a style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;" href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a><span style="font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> </span></p> <div id="highlighter--hover-tools" style="display: none;"> <div id="highlighter--hover-tools--container"> <div class="highlighter--icon     <item>
      <title>Parting Ways (For Now): Guerrilla History Bids Farewell to Breht &amp; Dave</title>
      <itunes:title>Parting Ways (For Now): Guerrilla History Bids Farewell to Breht &amp;amp; Dave</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 08 Mar 2024 06:55:28 +0000</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[7274d40b-a548-4a9d-9201-b09e72599e4e]]></guid>
      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/parting-ways-for-now-guerrilla-history-bids-farewell-to-breht-dave]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<p>In this episode of Guerrilla History, we mark an era change in the show's history as we bid farewell to cohost Breht and Producer Dave.  After almost three and a half years of working together on the show, we amicably part ways as Breht and Dave take on new endeavors in their lives and renew their focus on Rev Left Radio and Red Menace.  From the bottom of our hearts, Adnan and Henry thank the Breht and Dave for their tireless pursuit of justice and for the effort they have put in alongside us from the inception of this show.  While we are officially parting ways for now, we will remain lifelong friends, and are looking forward to continuing to collaborate periodically going forward (including on an upcoming miniseries that you will be hearing soon on the History of Modern China, which Breht is guest hosting!).  Be sure to keep up with everything that they continue to do at <a href="revolutionaryleftradio.com">revolutionaryleftradio.com</a>.</p> <p>Also, special thanks to <a href="twitter.com/BookerBiro">Comrade Booker Omole</a>, <a href="twitter.com/ImmanuelNess">Manny Ness</a>, <a href="twitter.com/HunnicuttWolfe">Brandon Wolfe-Hunnicutt</a>, Ken Hammond, <a href= "twitter.com/JonathanMelrod">Jon Melrod</a>, and <a href= "twitter.com/Alexander_Avina">Alex Aviña</a> for coming through on short notice to make an audio contribution to this episode, we deeply appreciate it!  Further thanks to all of the other guests we have had since the show's inception, we know that Breht has appreciated working with each of you!</p> <p><span style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content:</span> <a style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;" href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a><span style="font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> </span></p>]]></description>
      
      <content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>In this episode of Guerrilla History, we mark an era change in the show's history as we bid farewell to cohost Breht and Producer Dave. After almost three and a half years of working together on the show, we amicably part ways as Breht and Dave take on new endeavors in their lives and renew their focus on Rev Left Radio and Red Menace. From the bottom of our hearts, Adnan and Henry thank the Breht and Dave for their tireless pursuit of justice and for the effort they have put in alongside us from the inception of this show. While we are officially parting ways for now, we will remain lifelong friends, and are looking forward to continuing to collaborate periodically going forward (including on an upcoming miniseries that you will be hearing soon on the History of Modern China, which Breht is guest hosting!).     <item>
      <title>The History of Modern Yemen &amp; the Struggle Against Zionist Imperialism w/ Shireen Al-Adeimi &amp; Rune "Aldanmarki" Agerhus</title>
      <itunes:title>The History of Modern Yemen &amp;amp; the Struggle Against Zionist Imperialism w/ Shireen Al-Adeimi &amp;amp; Rune &quot;Aldanmarki&quot; Agerhus</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 01 Mar 2024 06:17:45 +0000</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[7ba6233f-b87a-4e0c-a144-298deb792e86]]></guid>
      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/the-history-of-modern-yemen-the-struggle-against-zionist-imperialism-w-shireen-al-adeimi-rune-aldanmarki-agerhus]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<p>In this blockbuster episode of Guerrilla History, we bring on two outstanding guests to discuss the modern history of Yemen, as well as their ongoing struggle against Zionist imperialism and opposition to the genocide in Gaza.   Shireen and Rune bring fantastic insight and analysis, making this complicated history accessible and utilizable for individuals in our movement against imperialism in all forms, and Zionist imperialism specifically at this moment.  Be sure to take in all that our guests say, and share this episode with comrades you believe would similarly benefit!</p> <p><strong>Shireen Al-Adeimi </strong>is an assistant professor of language and literacy at Michigan State University, and is an expert on the war and humanitarian crisis in her country of birth, Yemen. She writes for <a href= "https://inthesetimes.com/authors/shireen-al-adeimi">In These Times</a> and <a href= "https://responsiblestatecraft.org/author/shireenaladeimi/">Responsible Statecraft</a>, and speaks and writes frequently on Yemen for media globally.  You can follow her on twitter <a href= "twitter.com/shireen818">@shireen818</a>, and help support the <a href="https://yemenfoundation.org/">Yemen Relief & Reconstruction Foundation</a>.</p> <p><strong>Rune Agerhus </strong>Political Commentator & Member of the International Commission for Solidarity with Yemen (ICSY).  He is the founder of <a href= "https://twitter.com/HamraBooks">Hamra Books</a>, which Iskra Books and Guerrilla History have just <a href= "https://x.com/guerrilla_pod/status/1760336754081480908?s=46">announced a partnership with in order to release materials from the socialist People's Democratic Republic of Yemen</a>. You can follow him on twitter <a href= "https://twitter.com/Aldanmarki">@Aldanmarki</a>.</p> <p><span style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content:</span> <a style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;" href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a><span style="font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> </span></p>]]></description>
      
      <content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>In this blockbuster episode of Guerrilla History, we bring on two outstanding guests to discuss the modern history of Yemen, as well as their ongoing struggle against Zionist imperialism and opposition to the genocide in Gaza. Shireen and Rune bring fantastic insight and analysis, making this complicated history accessible and utilizable for individuals in our movement against imperialism in all forms, and Zionist imperialism specifically at this moment. Be sure to take in all that our guests say, and share this episode with comrades you believe would similarly benefit!</p> <p>Shireen Al-Adeimi is an assistant professor of language and literacy at Michigan State University, and is an expert on the war and humanitarian crisis in her country of birth, Yemen. She writes for <a href= "https://inthesetimes.com/authors/shireen-al-adeimi">In These Times</a> and <a href= "https://responsiblestatecraft.org/author/shireenaladeimi/">Responsible Statecraft</a>, and speaks and writes frequently on Yemen for media globally. You can follow her on twitter <a href= "twitter.com/shireen818">@shireen818</a>, and help support the <a href="https://yemenfoundation.org/">Yemen Relief & Reconstruction Foundation</a>.</p> <p>Rune Agerhus Political Commentator & Member of the International Commission for Solidarity with Yemen (ICSY). He is the founder of <a href= "https://twitter.com/HamraBooks">Hamra Books</a>, which Iskra Books and Guerrilla History have just <a href= "https://x.com/guerrilla_pod/status/1760336754081480908?s=46">announced a partnership with in order to release materials from the socialist People's Democratic Republic of Yemen</a>. You can follow him on twitter <a href= "https://twitter.com/Aldanmarki">@Aldanmarki</a>.</p> <p> Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;" href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a> </p>]]></content:encoded>

      <title>African &amp; Caribbean People in Britain - A History w/ Hakim Adi</title>
      <itunes:title>African &amp;amp; Caribbean People in Britain - A History w/ Hakim Adi</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 23 Feb 2024 06:29:12 +0000</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[e9dbb07d-c4d3-45fc-8506-778e9c7463be]]></guid>
      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/african-caribbean-people-in-britain-a-history-w-hakim-adi]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<p>In this fantastic episode of Guerrilla History, we bring back our esteemed friend and guest, Prof. Hakim Adi, to discuss his eminently important new book <a href= "https://www.amazon.co.uk/African-Caribbean-People-Britain-History/dp/1802060685/ref=tmm_pap_swatch_0?_encoding=UTF8&qid=&sr="> African and Caribbean People in Britain: A History</a>, which has just been shortlisted for the prestigious Wolfson History Prize!  In this conversation, we trace this history back thousands of years and come up to the present, but you MUST get this book in order to truly appreciate the work that Prof. Adi has done here.  We also get an update on the <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/save-the-history-of-africa-the-african-diaspora-mres-w-hakim-adi"> previous conversation we had with Hakim about the eminent closure of the MRes in the History of Africa and the African Diaspora program</a>.  For more updates on the legal challenges and ways to get involved, <a href= "https://www.historymatters.online/save-mres-campaign">follow this link</a>.</p> <p><strong>Hakim Adi</strong> is a Professor of the History of Africa and the African Diaspora, and the founder of <a href= "https://www.historymatters.online/journal">History Matters and its affiliated journal</a>.  He has authored numerous <a href= "hakimadi.org/publications">books</a>, and has written many articles which can be found on his website <a href= "hakimadi.org">hakimadi.org</a>.  You can follow him on twitter <a href="twitter.com/hakimadi1">@hakimadi1</a></p> <p><span style= you also will get bonus content:</span> <a style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;" href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a><span style="font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> </span></p>]]></description>
      
      <content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>In this fantastic episode of Guerrilla History, we bring back our esteemed friend and guest, Prof. Hakim Adi, to discuss his eminently important new book <a href= "https://www.amazon.co.uk/African-Caribbean-People-Britain-History/dp/1802060685/ref=tmm_pap_swatch_0?_encoding=UTF8&qid=&sr="> African and Caribbean People in Britain: A History</a>, which has just been shortlisted for the prestigious Wolfson History Prize!       <title>American Imperialism's Shadow on Latin America w/ Michael Fox</title>

      <pubDate>Fri, 16 Feb 2024 06:05:43 +0000</pubDate>

      <description><![CDATA[<p>In this episode of Guerrilla History, we are joined by returning guest Michael Fox (whom you may remember from our episode <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/the-rise-of-fascism-bolsonaro-the-brazilian-elections-w-michael-fox-dispatch"> The Rise of Fascism, Bolsonaro, & the Brazilian Elections</a>) to discuss his excellent new series <a href= "https://therealnews.com/under-the-shadow">Under the Shadow</a>, a collaboration between The Real News Network and NACLA which examines the lasting impacts of American imperialism on Latin America.  This is a fantastic conversation, and one which we hope to follow up with Michael on as his project continues for years to come!</p> <p><strong>Michael Fox</strong> is a Brazil-based journalist, contributor to The World, former Editor of NACLA, and the host of the podcast series <a href= "https://therealnews.com/under-the-shadow">Under the Shadow</a> and  <a href="https://therealnews.com/brazil-on-fire">Brazil on Fire</a>, both collaborations between NACLA and The Real News Network.
