    <item>
      <title>Archiving Arghiri Emmanuel's Works w/  The Arghiri Emmanuel  Association</title>
      <itunes:title>Archiving Arghiri Emmanuel&#39;s Works w/  The Arghiri Emmanuel  Association</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 09 Feb 2024 06:53:11 +0000</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[dbb49e71-b2bd-4953-ad41-c8b8f6f414e2]]></guid>
      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/archiving-arghiri-emmanuels-works-w-the-arghiri-emmanuel-association]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<p>In this terrific Sources and Methods episode of Guerrilla History, we are joined by Torkil Lauesen, Nemanja Lukić from the Anti-Imperialist Network, Immanuel Ness, and Joseph Mullen (whom you may remember from <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/bring-anti-imperialism-to-young-comrades-learn-from-the-global-south-w-the-cadre-journal"> our episode with The Cadre Journal</a>, which has since merged with Anti-Imperialist Network), who are members of the newly formed Arghiri Emmanuel Association!  We discuss the life of the legendary theorist of Unequal Exchange, his theory, as well as the Association's efforts to archive his works.  A fantastic conversation on some incredibly important work being done!  Be sure to check out the <a href= "https://unequalexchange.org/category/digital-archive/">Arghiri Emmanuel Digital Archive</a>.</p> <p><strong>Torkil Lauesen</strong> is a longtime anti-imperialist activist and writer living in Denmark. From 1970 to 1989, he was a full-time member of a communist anti-imperialist group, supporting Third World liberation movements by both legal and illegal means.  He has been a multiple time guest on Rev Left and Guerrilla History discussing his books <a href= "https://revolutionaryleftradio.libsyn.com/contradiction">The Principle Contradiction</a> and <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/swedens-integration-into-the-imperialist-world-system-remastered"> Riding the Wave: Sweden's Integration into the Imperialist  World Order</a>.</p> <p><strong>Nemanja Lukić </strong>is a Yugoslav anti-imperialist activist who runs the <a href= "https://anti-imperialist.net/">Anti-Imperialist Network website</a>. You can also follow Anti-Imp Net on twitter <a href= "twitter.com/antiimpnet">@antiimpnet</a>.</p> <p><strong style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> Immanuel Ness</strong> <span style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;">  is  Professor of Political Science at Brooklyn College, City University of New York and Visiting Professor of Sociology at the University of Johannesburg.  He is the author or editor of numerous works including <a href= "https://www.plutobooks.com/9780745343594/organizing-insurgency/">Organizing Insurgency: Workers' Movements in the Global South</a>, <a href= "https://www.plutobooks.com/9780745335995/southern-insurgency/">Southern Insurgency: The Coming of the Global Working Class</a>, and <a href="https://link.springer.com/referencework/10.1057/9780230392786"> The Palgrave Encyclopedia of Imperialism and Anti-Imperialism</a>.  You can follow Manny on twitter <a href="twitter.com/ImmanuelNess">@ImmanuelNess</a>.</span></p> <p><span style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> <strong>Joseph Mullen</strong> is a student activist who was a member of the Cadre Journal, which has since been merged with Anti-Imperialist Network.  He runs <a href= "https://unequalexchange.org/">unequalexchange.org/</a>.  You can follow Anti-Imperialist Network  - North America on twitter <a href= "twitter.com/antiimpnetna">@antiimpnetna</a>.</span></p> <p>Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a></p>]]></description>
      
      <content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>In this terrific Sources and Methods episode of Guerrilla History, we are joined by Torkil Lauesen, Nemanja Lukić from the Anti-Imperialist Network, Immanuel Ness, and Joseph Mullen (whom you may remember from <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/bring-anti-imperialism-to-young-comrades-learn-from-the-global-south-w-the-cadre-journal"> our episode with The Cadre Journal</a>, which has since merged with Anti-Imperialist Network), who are members of the newly formed Arghiri Emmanuel Association! We discuss the life of the legendary theorist of Unequal Exchange, his theory, as well as the Association's efforts to archive his works. A fantastic conversation on some incredibly important work being done! Be sure to check out the <a href= "https://unequalexchange.org/category/digital-archive/">Arghiri Emmanuel Digital Archive</a>.</p> <p>Torkil Lauesen is a longtime anti-imperialist activist and writer living in Denmark. From 1970 to 1989, he was a full-time member of a communist anti-imperialist group, supporting Third World liberation movements by both legal and illegal means. He has been a multiple time guest on Rev Left and Guerrilla History discussing his books <a href= "https://revolutionaryleftradio.libsyn.com/contradiction">The Principle Contradiction</a> and <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/swedens-integration-into-the-imperialist-world-system-remastered"> Riding the Wave: Sweden's Integration into the Imperialist World Order</a>.</p> <p>Nemanja Lukić is a Yugoslav anti-imperialist activist who runs the <a href= "https://anti-imperialist.net/">Anti-Imperialist Network website</a>. You can also follow Anti-Imp Net on twitter <a href= "twitter.com/antiimpnet">@antiimpnet</a>.</p> <p> Immanuel Ness is Professor of Political Science at Brooklyn College, City University of New York and Visiting Professor of Sociology at the University of Johannesburg. He is the author or editor of numerous works including <a href= "https://www.plutobooks.com/9780745343594/organizing-insurgency/">Organizing Insurgency: Workers' Movements in the Global South</a>, <a href= "https://www.plutobooks.com/9780745335995/southern-insurgency/">Southern Insurgency: The Coming of the Global Working Class</a>, and <a href="https://link.springer.com/referencework/10.1057/9780230392786"> The Palgrave Encyclopedia of Imperialism and Anti-Imperialism</a>. You can follow Manny on twitter <a href="twitter.com/ImmanuelNess">@ImmanuelNess</a>.</p> <p> Joseph Mullen is a student activist who was a member of the Cadre Journal, which has since been merged with Anti-Imperialist Network.     <item>
      <title>Making the Toussaint Louverture Graphic Novel w/ Sakina Karimjee &amp; Nic Watts</title>
      <itunes:title>Making the Toussaint Louverture Graphic Novel w/ Sakina Karimjee &amp;amp; Nic Watts</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 02 Feb 2024 06:16:54 +0000</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[c64d0e75-bccf-409a-9311-136e44c3c110]]></guid>
      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/making-the-toussaint-louverture-graphic-novel-w-sakina-karimjee-nic-watts]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<p>In this great episode of Guerrilla History, we are joined by the creative team behind the new graphic novel <a href= "https://www.versobooks.com/products/2535-toussaint-louverture">Toussaint Louverture: The Story of the Only Successful Slave Revolt in History</a>!  This tremendous work is the graphic novelization of a long lost CLR James play about the Haitian Revolution (which, incidentally, starred the great Paul Robeson the only time it was staged). In this conversation, we talk about this play and the process of adapting it, as well as the objectives behind doing so.  A great discussion about how to make subjects like the Haitian Revolution more accessible to broad audiences!</p> <p><strong>Sakina Karimjee </strong>is a theatre designer and draughtsperson, an activist and socialist and co-creator of graphic novels with her partner Nic Watts.</p> <p><strong>Nic Watts</strong> is an illustrator, activist and socialist. He has created artwork for numerous fiction and non-fiction books for children and adults, as well as other publications, websites, political campaigns and newspapers. He is the co-creator of graphic novels with his partner Sakina Karimjee. You can follow him on instagram <a href= "https://www.instagram.com/nicwatts_illustrator/?next=%2Fgurudosmares%2Ftagged%2F&hl=fr"> @nicwatts_illustrator</a></p> <p>Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a></p>]]></description>
      
      <content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>In this great episode of Guerrilla History, we are joined by the creative team behind the new graphic novel <a href= "https://www.versobooks.com/products/2535-toussaint-louverture">Toussaint Louverture: The Story of the Only Successful Slave Revolt in History</a>! This tremendous work is the graphic novelization of a long lost CLR James play about the Haitian Revolution (which, incidentally, starred the great Paul Robeson the only time it was staged). In this conversation, we talk about this play and the process of adapting it, as well as the objectives behind doing so. A great discussion about how to make subjects like the Haitian Revolution more accessible to broad audiences!</p> <p>Sakina Karimjee is a theatre designer and draughtsperson, an activist and socialist and co-creator of graphic novels with her partner Nic Watts.</p> <p>Nic Watts is an illustrator, activist and socialist. He has created artwork for numerous fiction and non-fiction books for children and adults, as well as other publications, websites, political campaigns and newspapers. He is the co-creator of graphic novels with his partner Sakina Karimjee. You can follow him on instagram <a href= "https://www.instagram.com/nicwatts_illustrator/?next=%2Fgurudosmares%2Ftagged%2F&hl=fr"> @nicwatts_illustrator</a></p> <p>Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a></p>]]></content:encoded>

    <item>
      <title>Migration as Economic Imperialism w/ Immanuel Ness</title>
      <itunes:title>Migration as Economic Imperialism w/ Immanuel Ness</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 26 Jan 2024 07:11:33 +0000</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[01fed4e4-f4ce-4c4b-90d8-a85bcaef06b5]]></guid>
      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/migration-as-economic-imperialism-w-immanuel-ness]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<p>In this fascinating episode of Guerrilla History, we are joined by fan-favorite Manny Ness to discuss one of his new books, <a href="https://www.wiley.com/en-us/Migration+as+Economic+Imperialism%3A+How+International+Labour+Mobility+Undermines+Economic+Development+in+Poor+Countries-p-9781509554003"> Migration as Economic Imperialism: How International Labour Mobility Undermines Economic Development in Poor Countries</a>.  This work directly takes on and dismantles the notion that labor migration is beneficial for the countries of the Global South who send their workers abroad.  This is a common refrain in mainstream, neoliberal developmentalist discourse, and this book and the conversation we are having around it are a vital corrective.  We are sure you are going to get a lot out of this one!</p> <p><strong style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> Immanuel Ness</strong> <span style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;">  is  Professor of Political Science at Brooklyn College, City University of New York and Visiting Professor of Sociology at the University of Johannesburg.  He is the author or editor of numerous works including <a href= "https://www.plutobooks.com/9780745343594/organizing-insurgency/">Organizing Insurgency: Workers' Movements in the Global South</a>, <a href= "https://www.plutobooks.com/9780745335995/southern-insurgency/">Southern Insurgency: The Coming of the Global Working Class</a>, and <a href="https://link.springer.com/referencework/10.1057/9780230392786"> The Palgrave Encyclopedia of Imperialism and Anti-Imperialism</a>.  You can follow Manny on twitter <a href="twitter.com/ImmanuelNess">@ImmanuelNess</a>.</span></p> <p>Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a></p>]]></description>
      
      <content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>In this fascinating episode of Guerrilla History, we are joined by fan-favorite Manny Ness to discuss one of his new books, <a href="https://www.wiley.com/en-us/Migration+as+Economic+Imperialism%3A+How+International+Labour+Mobility+Undermines+Economic+Development+in+Poor+Countries-p-9781509554003"> Migration as Economic Imperialism: How International Labour Mobility Undermines Economic Development in Poor Countries</a>. This work directly takes on and dismantles the notion that labor migration is beneficial for the countries of the Global South who send their workers abroad. This is a common refrain in mainstream, neoliberal developmentalist discourse, and this book and the conversation we are having around it are a vital corrective. We are sure you are going to get a lot out of this one!</p> <p> Immanuel Ness is Professor of Political Science at Brooklyn College, City University of New York and Visiting Professor of Sociology at the University of Johannesburg. He is the author or editor of numerous works including <a href= "https://www.plutobooks.com/9780745343594/organizing-insurgency/">Organizing Insurgency: Workers' Movements in the Global South</a>, <a href= "https://www.plutobooks.com/9780745335995/southern-insurgency/">Southern Insurgency: The Coming of the Global Working Class</a>, and <a href="https://link.springer.com/referencework/10.1057/9780230392786"> The Palgrave Encyclopedia of Imperialism and Anti-Imperialism</a>. You can follow Manny on twitter <a href="twitter.com/ImmanuelNess">@ImmanuelNess</a>.</p> <p>Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a></p>]]></content:encoded>

      <title>Intro to Colonialism &amp; Imperialism (The Deprogram Collab)</title>
      <itunes:title>Intro to Colonialism &amp;amp; Imperialism (The Deprogram Collab)</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 19 Jan 2024 08:32:33 +0000</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[6e3f6ede-29d2-4c8e-a292-259227dd5b64]]></guid>
      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/intro-to-colonialism-imperialism-the-deprogram-collab]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<p>In this collaboration, we went onto The Deprogram (hosted by comrades <a href="https://www.youtube.com/@YaBoiHakim">Hakim</a>, <a href="https://www.youtube.com/c/SecondThought">JT</a>, and <a href="https://www.youtube.com/c/yugopnik">Yugopnik</a>) to provide an introduction to Colonialism and Imperialism.  While we didn't have  quite as much time to discuss newer theories of imperialism, such as World Systems Theory and Unequal Exchange, or specific forms of colonialism, such as settler-colonialism and neocolonialism, we hope that this primer will be  of use to you and we also hope to reconvene with The Deprogram boys again to talk about some of these other threads.  </p> <p><strong>The Deprogram</strong> (<a href= "https://open.spotify.com/show/7tk1sTZDeE8p9lnxYLy4Ky">Spotify</a> | <a href="https://www.youtube.com/@thedeprogram9999">YouTube</a>) can be supported on <a href= "https://www.patreon.com/TheDeprogram">patreon</a>, and you can  follow them on twitter <a href= "twitter.com/TheDeprogramPod">@TheDeprogramPod</a></p> <p>Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a></p>]]></description>
      
      <content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>In this collaboration, we went onto The Deprogram (hosted by comrades <a href="https://www.youtube.com/@YaBoiHakim">Hakim</a>, <a href="https://www.youtube.com/c/SecondThought">JT</a>, and <a href="https://www.youtube.com/c/yugopnik">Yugopnik</a>) to provide an introduction to Colonialism and Imperialism.     <item>
      <title>Lebanon vs. Zioimperialism w/ Ali Kadri &amp; Rania Khalek</title>
      <itunes:title>Lebanon vs. Zioimperialism w/ Ali Kadri &amp;amp; Rania Khalek</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 12 Jan 2024 07:37:01 +0000</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[510d9d3f-619b-45c3-bd17-09641045ff67]]></guid>
      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/lebanon-vs-zioimperialism-w-ali-kadri-rania-khalek]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<p>In this critical episode of Guerrilla History, we have a two part-conversation with absolutely terrific guests.  Ali Kadri rejoins us to give a more theoretical background on the role of Lebanon historically and in the present with regards to its relations to the West and to the Zioimperialist project, after which Rania Khalek comes on to discuss some of the recent history and analyzes the current role of Lebanon vs. the Zioimperialist project and how it relates to the struggle in Gaza.  A fantastic conversation, one you don't want to miss!  Be sure to share this with comrades you think would benefit!</p> <p>Also, don't miss Rania's incredible <a href= "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dYkIixyNKrM">interview with Hezbollah's second-in-command Sheikh Naim Qassem</a>!</p> <p><strong style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> Ali Kadri</strong> <span style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> is an esteemed Professor at various institutions around the world, as well as the author of many important books including</span> <em style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> Arab Development Denied: Dynamics of Accumulation by Wars of Encroachment</em><span style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;">,</span> <em style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> <span role="heading" aria-level="4">The Accumulation of Waste: A Political Economy of Systemic Destruction, </span></em><span style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;" role="heading" aria-level="4">and <em>The Unmaking of Arab Socialism.  </em></span></p> <p><strong><span style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;" role="heading" aria-level="4">Rania</span></strong><span style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;" role="heading" aria-level="4"> <strong>Khalek </strong>is a renowned journalist at <a href= "https://www.youtube.com/@BreakThroughNews">Breakthrough News</a> and who's work has appeared in numerous outlets.  You can follow Rania's work on her website <a href= "https://raniakhalek.com/">https://raniakhalek.com/</a> and by following her on Instagram <a href= "https://www.instagram.com/raniakhalek/?hl=en">@raniakhalek</a> and on twitter <a href= "twitter.com/RaniaKhalek">@RaniaKhalek</a>.</span></p> <p>Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a></p>]]></description>
      
      <content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>In this critical episode of Guerrilla History, we have a two part-conversation with absolutely terrific guests. Ali Kadri rejoins us to give a more theoretical background on the role of Lebanon historically and in the present with regards to its relations to the West and to the Zioimperialist project, after which Rania Khalek comes on to discuss some of the recent history and analyzes the current role of Lebanon vs. the Zioimperialist project and how it relates to the struggle in Gaza. A fantastic conversation, one you don't want to miss! Be sure to share this with comrades you think would benefit!</p> <p>Also, don't miss Rania's incredible <a href= "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dYkIixyNKrM">interview with Hezbollah's second-in-command Sheikh Naim Qassem</a>!</p> <p> Ali Kadri is an esteemed Professor at various institutions around the world, as well as the author of many important books including <em style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> Arab Development Denied: Dynamics of Accumulation by Wars of Encroachment</em>, <em style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> The Accumulation of Waste: A Political Economy of Systemic Destruction, </em>and <em>The Unmaking of Arab Socialism. </em></p> <p>Rania Khalek is a renowned journalist at <a href= "https://www.youtube.com/@BreakThroughNews">Breakthrough News</a> and who's work has appeared in numerous outlets. You can follow Rania's work on her website <a href= "https://raniakhalek.com/">https://raniakhalek.com/</a> and by following her on Instagram <a href= "https://www.instagram.com/raniakhalek/?hl=en">@raniakhalek</a> and on twitter <a href= "twitter.com/RaniaKhalek">@RaniaKhalek</a>.</p> <p>Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a></p>]]></content:encoded>

    <item>
      <title>Indigeneity &amp; Palestine w/ Nick Estes &amp; Mohamed Abdou</title>
      <itunes:title>Indigeneity &amp;amp; Palestine w/ Nick Estes &amp;amp; Mohamed Abdou</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 05 Jan 2024 08:42:10 +0000</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[652acc13-81da-4b26-8952-86ba0ff6f016]]></guid>
      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/indigeneity-palestine-w-nick-estes-mohamed-abdou]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<p>In this episode of Guerrilla History, bring on two exceptional guests to discuss a critical topic for deepening our understanding of Palestine and the ongoing settler-colonial domination by the state of "Israel"!  Nick Estes and Mohamed Abdou come on the show for a conversation about Indigeneity and Palestine, and we found this discussion to be incredibly fruitful and useful when analyzing the situation in Occupied Palestine today. We are sure that you will also find use in this, and we encourage you to send it along to comrades to help them deepen their thinking of this as well!</p> <p>A few pieces to check out:  Mohamed did an <a href= "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=J9-emuwWeP8">YouTube event</a> and <a href= "https://twitter.com/AJEnglish/status/1735016075245375804">wrote an article</a> on the topic "1492 Palestine". Nick was active in the in the <a href= "https://www.youtube.com/redirect?event=video_description&redir_token=QUFFLUhqbHY2VHVkU2xFa3gwWkFmM1RsWE80SzV3TDZzQXxBQ3Jtc0tsaWtNYmpzNXh6bXEzT1BxYmh5Q193OXNEa3Z0VkcyVnJRSUNXUjhVb1h5UFRTRDQ0RU9hVl8yNlRkV0NRNTZTRG1CZV9FODlGdUc5a2l2NU9GZlUyd1hPcmQxb0ZBRTNDSFAtOVgxU2lZVlVXN01Zaw&q=https%3A%2F%2Ftherednation.org%2Fstatement-of-indigenous-solidarity-with-palestine%2F&v=IRaFbSRqe-o"> drafting of a letter</a> by indigenous activists and scholars condemning the actions of Israel, and there is also an <a href= "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IRaFbSRqe-o">episode of The Red Nation</a> where you can learn about this letter and indigenous solidarity with Palestine.</p> <p><strong>Nick Estes</strong> is a Lakota organizer, journalist, and historian at the University of Minnesota. He has cofounded <a href="https://therednation.org/">The Red Nation</a> and Red Media. Be sure to pick up Nick's book <a href= "https://www.versobooks.com/en-gb/products/600-our-history-is-the-future"> Our History is the Future</a>, and he can be followed on twitter <a href="https://twitter.com/nickwestes">@nickwestes</a> </p> <p><strong>Mohamed Abdou</strong> is a North African-Egyptian Muslim anarchist activist-scholar. He has been a Visiting Scholar at Cornell University and an Assistant Professor of Sociology at the American University of Cairo, and is incoming at Columbia University. Pick up his book <a href= "https://www.plutobooks.com/9780745341927/islam-and-anarchism/">Islam and Anarchism: Relationships and Resonances</a>, and follow him on twitter <a href= "https://twitter.com/minuetinGmajor">@minuetinGmajor</a> </p> <p>Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a></p>]]></description>
      
      <content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>In this episode of Guerrilla History, bring on two exceptional guests to discuss a critical topic for deepening our understanding of Palestine and the ongoing settler-colonial domination by the state of "Israel"! Nick Estes and Mohamed Abdou come on the show for a conversation about Indigeneity and Palestine, and we found this discussion to be incredibly fruitful and useful when analyzing the situation in Occupied Palestine today. We are sure that you will also find use in this, and we encourage you to send it along to comrades to help them deepen their thinking of this as well!</p> <p>A few pieces to check out: Mohamed did an <a href= "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=J9-emuwWeP8">YouTube event</a> and <a href= "https://twitter.com/AJEnglish/status/1735016075245375804">wrote an article</a> on the topic "1492 Palestine". Nick was active in the in the <a href= "https://www.youtube.com/redirect?event=video_description&redir_token=QUFFLUhqbHY2VHVkU2xFa3gwWkFmM1RsWE80SzV3TDZzQXxBQ3Jtc0tsaWtNYmpzNXh6bXEzT1BxYmh5Q193OXNEa3Z0VkcyVnJRSUNXUjhVb1h5UFRTRDQ0RU9hVl8yNlRkV0NRNTZTRG1CZV9FODlGdUc5a2l2NU9GZlUyd1hPcmQxb0ZBRTNDSFAtOVgxU2lZVlVXN01Zaw&q=https%3A%2F%2Ftherednation.org%2Fstatement-of-indigenous-solidarity-with-palestine%2F&v=IRaFbSRqe-o"> drafting of a letter</a> by indigenous activists and scholars condemning the actions of Israel, and there is also an <a href= "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IRaFbSRqe-o">episode of The Red Nation</a> where you can learn about this letter and indigenous solidarity with Palestine.</p> <p>Nick Estes is a Lakota organizer, journalist, and historian at the University of Minnesota. He has cofounded <a href="https://therednation.org/">The Red Nation</a> and Red Media. Be sure to pick up Nick's book <a href= "https://www.versobooks.com/en-gb/products/600-our-history-is-the-future"> Our History is the Future</a>, and he can be followed on twitter <a href="https://twitter.com/nickwestes">@nickwestes</a> </p> <p>Mohamed Abdou is a North African-Egyptian Muslim anarchist activist-scholar.       <title>Guerrilla History's 2023 In Review</title>

      <pubDate>Fri, 29 Dec 2023 06:58:22 +0000</pubDate>

      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/guerrilla-historys-2023-in-review]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<p>In this year end episode, we do our annual Year In Review.  We discuss some of the major things that happened globally in 2023 as well as the work we have done over the course of this year.  With this, we've released over 50 publicly available episodes this year on a wide range of topic, and we are really proud of what we have been able to provide to you for political education purposes.  We are looking forward to continuing to grow and expand as we go into 2024!  If you appreciate what we do, consider signing up to our patreon to help us do what we do.</p> <p>Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a></p>]]></description>

    <item>
      <title>"Israel" and Its Role in Latin America w/ Alexander Aviña</title>
      <itunes:title>&quot;Israel&quot; and Its Role in Latin America w/ Alexander Aviña</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 22 Dec 2023 07:22:07 +0000</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[eeec68c5-87fb-47a8-845a-9844cac323b0]]></guid>
      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/israel-and-its-role-in-latin-america-w-alexander-avia]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<p>In this episode of Guerrilla History, we bring back the official unofficial fourth member of the hosting panel, Alexander Aviña!  Here we discuss Alex's freshly released article at Foreign Exchanges titled <a href= "https://www.foreignexchanges.news/p/a-future-of-walls-or-liberation?utm_campaign=post"> A Future of Walls or Liberation</a>, which examines some of the role and relationships between "Israel" and the countries and governments in Latin America.  This is a really interesting piece of the Zioimperialist story, and one which is frankly very under-discussed.  Tune in, learn something, and share with others who you think would also benefit from hearing this history!</p> <p><strong>Alexander Aviña</strong> is associate professor of Latin American history at Arizona State University and author of <em>Specters of Revolution: Peasant Guerrillas in the Cold War Mexican Countryside</em>. Alex's website is available at <a href= "alexanderavina.com">alexanderavina.com</a>, and he can be followed on twitter <a href= "twitter.com/Alexander_Avina">@Alexander_Avina</a></p> <p><span style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content:</span> <a style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;" href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a><span style="font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> </span></p> <div id="highlighter--hover-tools" style="display: none;"> <div id="highlighter--hover-tools--container"> <div class="highlighter--icon highlighter--icon-delete" title= "Delete"> </div> </div> </div> <div id="highlighter--hover-tools" style="display: none;"> <div id="highlighter--hover-tools--container"> <div class="highlighter--icon highlighter--icon-copy" title="Copy">  </div> <div class="highlighter--separator"> </div> <div class="highlighter--icon highlighter--icon-delete" title= "Delete"> </div> </div> </div> <div id="highlighter--hover-tools" style="display: none;"> <div id="highlighter--hover-tools--container"> <div class="highlighter--icon highlighter--icon-copy" title="Copy">  </div> <div class="highlighter--separator"> </div> <div class="highlighter--icon highlighter--icon-delete" title= "Delete"> </div> </div> </div>]]></description>
      
      <content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>In this episode of Guerrilla History, we bring back the official unofficial fourth member of the hosting panel, Alexander Aviña! Here we discuss Alex's freshly released article at Foreign Exchanges titled <a href= "https://www.foreignexchanges.news/p/a-future-of-walls-or-liberation?utm_campaign=post"> A Future of Walls or Liberation</a>, which examines some of the role and relationships between "Israel" and the countries and governments in Latin America. This is a really interesting piece of the Zioimperialist story, and one which is frankly very under-discussed. Tune in, learn something, and share with others who you think would also benefit from hearing this history!</p> <p>Alexander Aviña is associate professor of Latin American history at Arizona State University and author of <em>Specters of Revolution: Peasant Guerrillas in the Cold War Mexican Countryside</em>. Alex's website is available at <a href= "alexanderavina.com">alexanderavina.com</a>, and he can be followed on twitter <a href= "twitter.com/Alexander_Avina">@Alexander_Avina</a></p> <p> Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;" href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a> </p>]]></content:encoded>

    <item>
      <title>Understanding Apartheid: South Africa, Settler Colonialism, and Lessons for Palestine</title>
      <itunes:title>Understanding Apartheid: South Africa, Settler Colonialism, and Lessons for Palestine</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 15 Dec 2023 07:02:11 +0000</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[a8ee9a03-7f88-4405-a8f5-8eb476b50d3e]]></guid>
      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/-understanding-apartheid-south-africa-settler-colonialism-and-lessons-for-palestine-3]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<p>In this Revolutionary Guerrilla Menace get-together, also known as the <em>Rev Left Family Annual Collab</em> (<a href= "https://revolutionaryleftradio.libsyn.com/">Rev Left</a>+<a href= "https://redmenace.libsyn.com/">Red Menace</a>+<a href= "https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/">Guerrilla History</a>), Alyson, Henry, Adnan, and Breht sit down for a deep dive on South African Apartheid. Together they discuss its euro-colonialist origins, explain the significance of the Boer Wars, define and explicate the origins of apartheid, explore the political economy of apartheid and how brutal racism shaped it, examine the multi-faceted indigenous resistance to apartheid, analyze the end of formal apartheid as well as its ongoing legacy in post-apartheid South Africa, and try to extract important lessons from this history to apply to the ongoing struggle in Palestine.</p> <p>Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a></p>]]></description>

    <item>
      <title>Settler Colonial Law &amp; Sue the T. rex w/ the Leninist Lawyer</title>
      <itunes:title>Settler Colonial Law &amp;amp; Sue the T. rex w/ the Leninist Lawyer</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 08 Dec 2023 06:49:49 +0000</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[d130fdff-6f84-49f6-8297-c1d6ec365618]]></guid>
      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/settler-colonial-law-sue-the-t-rex-w-the-leninist-lawyer]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<p>In this episode of Guerrilla History, we bring on The Leninist Lawyer to discuss settler colonial law, and use the case study of Sue the T. rex, which was extracted from native lands, to help demonstrate how this works.  A really interesting conversation, and while we are using a dinosaur fossil as the case study, this conversation is much more about settler colonial law generally, and therefore should be relevant for all of you regardless of whether you find dinosaurs interesting or not!</p> <p>*Note, this episode was recorded before October 7, 2023, and has had its release delayed while we have been creating materials for understanding the history and ongoing conflict in Palestine*</p> <p>The Leninist Lawyer is an anonymous lawyer from Georgia that specializes in tribal law and worker's compensation law.  While we cannot provide more details than this about him, you should follow him on twitter <a href= "http://twitter.com/MarxistLaw">@MarxistLaw</a> and <a href= "twitter.com/LovelyLeninist">@LovelyLeninist</a>!</p> <p>Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a></p>]]></description>
      
      <content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>In this episode of Guerrilla History, we bring on The Leninist Lawyer to discuss settler colonial law, and use the case study of Sue the T. rex, which was extracted from native lands, to help demonstrate how this works. A really interesting conversation, and while we are using a dinosaur fossil as the case study, this conversation is much more about settler colonial law generally, and therefore should be relevant for all of you regardless of whether you find dinosaurs interesting or not!</p> <p>*Note, this episode was recorded before October 7, 2023, and has had its release delayed while we have been creating materials for understanding the history and ongoing conflict in Palestine*</p> <p>The Leninist Lawyer is an anonymous lawyer from Georgia that specializes in tribal law and worker's compensation law. While we cannot provide more details than this about him, you should follow him on twitter <a href= "http://twitter.com/MarxistLaw">@MarxistLaw</a> and <a href= "twitter.com/LovelyLeninist">@LovelyLeninist</a>!</p> <p>Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a></p>]]></content:encoded>

      <itunes:duration>01:50:56</itunes:duration>
      <itunes:explicit>true</itunes:explicit>
      
      <itunes:keywords />
      
      <itunes:season>4</itunes:season>

    <item>
      <title>Palestine - War, Occupation, and Proletarianization w/ Ali Kadri</title>
      <itunes:title>Palestine - War, Occupation, and Proletarianization w/ Ali Kadri</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 01 Dec 2023 08:43:20 +0000</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[2ee474ed-c6bf-4abf-929a-0f4e06d6fded]]></guid>
      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/palestine-war-occupation-and-proletarianization-w-ali-kadri]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<p>In this critical episode of Guerrilla History, we bring the esteemed and critically important Ali Kadri onto the show to discuss Palestine.  This episode is largely based off of Ali's terrific book <em><a href= "https://link.springer.com/book/10.1007/978-981-15-3200-9">A Theory of Forced Labour Migration: The Proletarianisation of the West Bank Under Occupation (1967-1992)</a>.  </em>In this conversation, we discuss themes including war as a method of capital accumulation, indigenous labour extirpation, and much, much more.  We want to thank friend of the show <a href= "twitter.com/maxajl">Max Ajl</a> for helping connect us with Ali, whose work has been something we have wanted to discuss for quite some time.  We also hope to bring Ali back on soon to discuss more of his work, on a variety of topics he studies.</p> <p><strong>Ali Kadri</strong> is an esteemed Professor at various institutions around the world, as well as the author of many important books including <em>Arab Development Denied: Dynamics of Accumulation by Wars of Encroachment</em>, <em><span role="heading" aria-level="4">The Accumulation of Waste: A Political Economy of Systemic Destruction, </span></em><span role="heading" aria-level="4">and <em>The Unmaking of Arab Socialism.  </em></span></p> <p>Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a></p>]]></description>
      
      <content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>In this critical episode of Guerrilla History, we bring the esteemed and critically important Ali Kadri onto the show to discuss Palestine. This episode is largely based off of Ali's terrific book <em><a href= "https://link.springer.com/book/10.1007/978-981-15-3200-9">A Theory of Forced Labour Migration: The Proletarianisation of the West Bank Under Occupation (1967-1992)</a>. </em>In this conversation, we discuss themes including war as a method of capital accumulation, indigenous labour extirpation, and much, much more. We want to thank friend of the show <a href= "twitter.com/maxajl">Max Ajl</a> for helping connect us with Ali, whose work has been something we have wanted to discuss for quite some time. We also hope to bring Ali back on soon to discuss more of his work, on a variety of topics he studies.</p> <p>Ali Kadri is an esteemed Professor at various institutions around the world, as well as the author of many important books including <em>Arab Development Denied: Dynamics of Accumulation by Wars of Encroachment</em>, <em>The Accumulation of Waste: A Political Economy of Systemic Destruction, </em>and <em>The Unmaking of Arab Socialism. </em></p> <p>Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a></p>]]></content:encoded>

    <item>
      <title>Black Scare/Red Scare w/ Charisse Burden-Stelly</title>
      <itunes:title>Black Scare/Red Scare w/ Charisse Burden-Stelly</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 24 Nov 2023 06:34:18 +0000</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[e5e3f428-b389-459c-b170-b4784986551d]]></guid>
      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/black-scarered-scare-w-charisse-burden-stelly]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<p>In this absolutely fabulous episode of Guerrilla History, we bring back on the one and only Dr. CBS, Charisse Burden-Stelly!  Here, we discuss her outstanding new book <a href= "https://press.uchicago.edu/ucp/books/book/chicago/B/bo207945104.html"> Black Scare/Red Scare: Theorizing Capitalist Racism in the United States</a>.  This work focuses on how anti-radical repression (especially anti-communist repression) is infused and inseparable with anti-Black racial oppression, and vice versa.  This is a critical work by one of the most critical voices in our times, and we think that this conversation is a truly important one for everyone to hear!</p> <p><strong>Charisse Burden-Stelly</strong> is associate professor of African American studies at Wayne State University. She is the coauthor (alongside Gerald Horne) of <em>W.E.B. Du Bois: A Life in American History</em> and the coeditor (alongside Jodi Dean) of <em>Organize, Fight, Win: Black Communist Women's Political Writing</em>.  Join the <a href= "https://blackallianceforpeace.com/">Black Alliance for Peace or BAP Solidarity Network</a>, keep up with Dr. CBS's work by checking out her website <a href= "https://www.charisseburdenstelly.com">www.charisseburdenstelly.com</a>, and follow her on twitter <a href= "twitter.com/blackleftaf">@blackleftaf</a>.</p> <p>Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a></p>]]></description>
      
      <content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>In this absolutely fabulous episode of Guerrilla History, we bring back on the one and only Dr. CBS, Charisse Burden-Stelly! Here, we discuss her outstanding new book <a href= "https://press.uchicago.edu/ucp/books/book/chicago/B/bo207945104.html"> Black Scare/Red Scare: Theorizing Capitalist Racism in the United States</a>. This work focuses on how anti-radical repression (especially anti-communist repression) is infused and inseparable with anti-Black racial oppression, and vice versa. This is a critical work by one of the most critical voices in our times, and we think that this conversation is a truly important one for everyone to hear!</p> <p>Charisse Burden-Stelly is associate professor of African American studies at Wayne State University. She is the coauthor (alongside Gerald Horne) of <em>W.E.B. Du Bois: A Life in American History</em> and the coeditor (alongside Jodi Dean) of <em>Organize, Fight, Win: Black Communist Women's Political Writing</em>. Join the <a href= "https://blackallianceforpeace.com/">Black Alliance for Peace or BAP Solidarity Network</a>, keep up with Dr. CBS's work by checking out her website <a href= "https://www.charisseburdenstelly.com">www.charisseburdenstelly.com</a>, and follow her on twitter <a href= "twitter.com/blackleftaf">@blackleftaf</a>.</p> <p>Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a></p>]]></content:encoded>

    <item>
      <title>Apartheid: An Introduction w/ Ashley Fataar</title>
      <itunes:title>Apartheid: An Introduction w/ Ashley Fataar</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 17 Nov 2023 09:59:09 +0000</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[6704a03f-871d-495b-98f2-3ad68988c3de]]></guid>
      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/apartheid-an-introduction-w-ashley-fataar]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<p>In this crossover episode that we have done in collaboration with our sister podcast RevLeft Radio, we bring on Ashley Fataar to provide a primer into Apartheid in the South African context, and where we also begin to explore some of the parallels to the apartheid that the settler-colonial state of Israel is enforcing in occupied Palestine today.  This is a good introduction to the topic, and we plan on getting everyone in the RevLeft family (Breht, Henry, Adnan, & Alyson) together in the coming weeks to do a deep dive into apartheid in South Africa and where we can further explore these connections to what we are seeing today!  Be sure to listen to this conversation to prepare for that coming conversation, and be sure to subscribe to <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/">Guerrilla History</a>, <a href="https://revolutionaryleftradio.libsyn.com/">RevLeft</a>, and <a href="https://redmenace.libsyn.com/">Red Menace</a> wherever you get your pods.</p> <p><strong>Ashley Fataar</strong> is a long time socialist activist and writer based in South Africa.  If you would like to get in touch with Ashley, you can reach him via email at <a href= "mailto:ash.fataar@gmail.com">ash.fataar@gmail.com</a>.  </p> <p>Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a></p>]]></description>
      
      <content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>In this crossover episode that we have done in collaboration with our sister podcast RevLeft Radio, we bring on Ashley Fataar to provide a primer into Apartheid in the South African context, and where we also begin to explore some of the parallels to the apartheid that the settler-colonial state of Israel is enforcing in occupied Palestine today. This is a good introduction to the topic, and we plan on getting everyone in the RevLeft family (Breht, Henry, Adnan, & Alyson) together in the coming weeks to do a deep dive into apartheid in South Africa and where we can further explore these connections to what we are seeing today!     <item>
      <title>Palestine &amp; the BDS Movement w/ Corinna Mullin</title>
      <itunes:title>Palestine &amp;amp; the BDS Movement w/ Corinna Mullin</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 10 Nov 2023 07:46:18 +0000</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[35b3df3c-72fa-4dab-abae-f7946ed7c208]]></guid>
      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/palestine-the-bds-movement-w-corinna-mullin]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<p>In another vital episode of Guerrilla History, we close out our Sanctions As War miniseries while continuing to examine Palestine and the various components of the conflict in Occupied Palestine.  This time, we bring on Corinna Mullin to discuss sanctions from below, the BDS movement, and how what those in the West can do to support the Palestine liberation movement.  This is a really important conversation, so be sure to share with anyone you think would benefit from hearing it!</p> <p>Follow the <a href="https://sanctionstribunal.org/">The International People's Tribunal on U.S. Imperialism</a> and <a href="https://twitter.com/Cuny4P">CUNY for Palestine</a> for more information on the organizations Corinna is involved with.</p> <p><strong>Corinna Mullin</strong> is an anti-imperialist scholar teaching at John Jay and Brooklyn College, City University of New York (CUNY). She researches, writes and teaches about: the politics and political economy of West Asia and North Africa, genealogies of global south security/carceral states, the politics of development, US imperialism, racial capitalism, anti-/decolonial theory and struggles, knowledge production, and popular education. Corinna has been involved in BDS struggles in the US, Tunisia and New York.  You can follow her on twitter <a href= "twitter.com/MullinCorinna">@MullinCorinna</a></p> <p>Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a></p>]]></description>
      
      <content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>In another vital episode of Guerrilla History, we close out our Sanctions As War miniseries while continuing to examine Palestine and the various components of the conflict in Occupied Palestine. This time, we bring on Corinna Mullin to discuss sanctions from below, the BDS movement, and how what those in the West can do to support the Palestine liberation movement. This is a really important conversation, so be sure to share with anyone you think would benefit from hearing it!</p> <p>Follow the <a href="https://sanctionstribunal.org/">The International People's Tribunal on U.S. Imperialism</a> and <a href="https://twitter.com/Cuny4P">CUNY for Palestine</a> for more information on the organizations Corinna is involved with.</p> <p>Corinna Mullin is an anti-imperialist scholar teaching at John Jay and Brooklyn College, City University of New York (CUNY). She researches, writes and teaches about: the politics and political economy of West Asia and North Africa, genealogies of global south security/carceral states, the politics of development, US imperialism, racial capitalism, anti-/decolonial theory and struggles, knowledge production, and popular education. Corinna has been involved in BDS struggles in the US, Tunisia and New York. You can follow her on twitter <a href= "twitter.com/MullinCorinna">@MullinCorinna</a></p> <p>Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a></p>]]></content:encoded>

      <title>Palestine and the Media w/ Tara Alami</title>

      <pubDate>Fri, 03 Nov 2023 06:11:45 +0000</pubDate>

      <description><![CDATA[<p>In another crucial episode of Guerrilla History, we continue to examine Palestine and the various components of the conflict in Occupied Palestine.  This time, we bring on Tara Alami to discuss the ongoing bombardment of Gaza and media misrepresentations/propaganda surrounding it.  This is a really critically important conversation, and we hope that you will share it next week when it comes out on our general feed - this is something that we need as many people to hear as possible!</p> <p><strong>Tara Alami</strong> is a Palestinian writer from Occupied Jerusalem and Occupied Yafa, currently living in Montreal. You can follow Tara on twitter <a href= "http://twitter.com/taraxrh">@taraxrh</a>, and keep up with <a href="https://linktr.ee/taraalami">her work and mutual aid resources here</a>.</p> <p>Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a></p>]]></description>

    <item>
      <title>Understanding the Conflict in Occupied Palestine - History &amp; Geopolitics w/ Rabab Abdulhadi &amp; Ariel Salzmann</title>
      <itunes:title>Understanding the Conflict in Occupied Palestine - History &amp;amp; Geopolitics w/ Rabab Abdulhadi &amp;amp; Ariel Salzmann</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 27 Oct 2023 08:07:55 +0000</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[223dc84e-d003-4af4-89a8-aa5a4ec55f3c]]></guid>
      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/understanding-the-conflict-in-occupied-palestine-history-geopolitics-w-rabab-abdulhadi-ariel-salzmann]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<p>In this important and wide-ranging episode of Guerrilla History, we bring on two esteemed guests, Professors Rabab Abdulhadi and Ariel Salzmann, to discuss the conflict in occupied Palestine, the bombardment in Gaza, attempts to legitimize the Zionist project that is the so-called State of Israel, and public activist movements.  This is another really crucial conversation that builds off of our previous episode with <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/palestinian-resistance-vs-the-zionist-project-w-max-ajl-patrick-higgins"> Max Ajl and Patrick Higgins on Palestinian Resistance vs. the Zionist Project</a>.  If you find this conversation useful, please send it along to your comrades, friends, and family - we really need people to understand this!</p> <p>Our guests recommend you to check out the work done by <a href= "https://www.jadaliyya.com/">Jadaliyya</a>, the <a href= "https://linktr.ee/amedstudies">Arab and Muslim Ethnicities and Diasporas Study Program/Teaching Palestine</a>, the <a href= "https://drive.google.com/file/d/17IsdrVlu2EDu0Rd3pKZ-9Wom3I3IPFn2/view"> statement</a> from the <a href= "https://criticalzionismstudies.org/">Institute for the Critical Study of Zionism</a>, the <a href= "https://mondoweiss.net/2023/10/birzeit-university-union-we-are-all-palestinians-in-the-face-of-colonial-fascism/"> statement from Birzeit University</a>, and the work being done by <a href="https://www.jewishvoiceforpeace.org/">Jewish Voice for Peace</a>.</p> <p><strong>Rabab Abdulhadi</strong> is the founding Director and Senior Scholar of <a href="https://amed.sfsu.edu/">Arab and Muslim Ethnicities and Diasporas Study Program</a> at San Francisco State University, co-founding Editorial Board Member of the <a href= "https://www.plutojournals.com/islamophobia/">Islamophobia Studies Journal</a>, and Director/Principal Investigator of Teaching Palestine, as well as author of numerous scholarly works.</p> <p><span style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> <strong>Ariel Salzmann</strong> is a professor of Islamic and world history at Queen's University, and her research addresses theories of state formation, histories of Mediterranean communities and Muslim societies, the transformation of market systems and the making of global capitalism.  Her forthcoming book, <em><a href= "https://www.hurstpublishers.com/book/the-exclusionary-west/">The Exclusionary West: Medieval Minorities and the Making of Modern Europe</a>,</em> will be out in May 2024.</span></p> <p><span style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content:</span> <a style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;" href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a><span style="font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> </span></p> <div id="highlighter--hover-tools" style="display: none;"> <div id="highlighter--hover-tools--container"> <div class="highlighter--icon highlighter--icon-copy" title="Copy">  </div> <div class="highlighter--separator"> </div> <div class="highlighter--icon highlighter--icon-delete" title= "Delete"> </div> </div> </div> <div id="highlighter--hover-tools" style="display: none;"> <div id="highlighter--hover-tools--container"> <div class="highlighter--icon highlighter--icon-copy" title="Copy">  </div> <div class="highlighter--separator"> </div> <div class="highlighter--icon highlighter--icon-delete" title= "Delete"> </div> </div> </div> <div id="highlighter--hover-tools" style="display: none;"> <div id="highlighter--hover-tools--container"> <div class="highlighter--icon highlighter--icon-copy" title="Copy">  </div> <div class="highlighter--separator"> </div> <div class="highlighter--icon highlighter--icon-delete" title= "Delete"> </div> </div> </div> <div id="highlighter--hover-tools" style="display: none;"> <div id="highlighter--hover-tools--container"> <div class="highlighter--icon highlighter--icon-copy" title="Copy">  </div> <div class="highlighter--separator"> </div> <div class="highlighter--icon highlighter--icon-delete" title= "Delete"> </div> </div> </div> <div id="highlighter--hover-tools" style="display: none;"> <div id="highlighter--hover-tools--container"> <div class="highlighter--icon highlighter--icon-copy" title="Copy">  </div> <div class="highlighter--separator"> </div> <div class="highlighter--icon highlighter--icon-delete" title= "Delete"> </div> </div> </div>]]></description>
      
      <content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>In this important and wide-ranging episode of Guerrilla History, we bring on two esteemed guests, Professors Rabab Abdulhadi and Ariel Salzmann, to discuss the conflict in occupied Palestine, the bombardment in Gaza, attempts to legitimize the Zionist project that is the so-called State of Israel, and public activist movements. This is another really crucial conversation that builds off of our previous episode with <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/palestinian-resistance-vs-the-zionist-project-w-max-ajl-patrick-higgins"> Max Ajl and Patrick Higgins on Palestinian Resistance vs. the Zionist Project</a>. If you find this conversation useful, please send it along to your comrades, friends, and family - we really need people to understand this!</p> <p>Our guests recommend you to check out the work done by <a href= "https://www.jadaliyya.com/">Jadaliyya</a>, the <a href= "https://linktr.ee/amedstudies">Arab and Muslim Ethnicities and Diasporas Study Program/Teaching Palestine</a>, the <a href= "https://drive.google.com/file/d/17IsdrVlu2EDu0Rd3pKZ-9Wom3I3IPFn2/view"> statement</a> from the <a href= "https://criticalzionismstudies.org/">Institute for the Critical Study of Zionism</a>, the <a href= "https://mondoweiss.net/2023/10/birzeit-university-union-we-are-all-palestinians-in-the-face-of-colonial-fascism/"> statement from Birzeit University</a>, and the work being done by <a href="https://www.jewishvoiceforpeace.org/">Jewish Voice for Peace</a>.</p> <p>Rabab Abdulhadi is the founding Director and Senior Scholar of <a href="https://amed.sfsu.edu/">Arab and Muslim Ethnicities and Diasporas Study Program</a> at San Francisco State University, co-founding Editorial Board Member of the <a href= "https://www.plutojournals.com/islamophobia/">Islamophobia Studies Journal</a>, and Director/Principal Investigator of Teaching Palestine, as well as author of numerous scholarly works.</p> <p> Ariel Salzmann is a professor of Islamic and world history at Queen's University, and her research addresses theories of state formation, histories of Mediterranean communities and Muslim societies, the transformation of market systems and the making of global capitalism. Her forthcoming book, <em><a href= "https://www.hurstpublishers.com/book/the-exclusionary-west/">The Exclusionary West: Medieval Minorities and the Making of Modern Europe</a>,</em> will be out in May 2024.</p> <p> Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;" href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a> </p>]]></content:encoded>

      <title>Palestinian Resistance vs. The Zionist Project w/ Max Ajl &amp; Patrick Higgins</title>
      <itunes:title>Palestinian Resistance vs. The Zionist Project w/ Max Ajl &amp;amp; Patrick Higgins</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 20 Oct 2023 08:58:45 +0000</pubDate>

      <description><![CDATA[<p>In this critical episode of Guerrilla History, we bring on Max Ajl and Patrick Higgins to discuss some recent history and the ongoing situation regarding Palestinian resistance to the Zionist project and the ongoing bombardment on Gaza.  Max and Patrick provide some absolutely crucial information here, so be sure to tune in, and forward the episode along to anyone you think would benefit from it.</p> <p>Our guests recommend you to donate to the <a href= "https://www.mecaforpeace.org/">Middle East Children's Alliance</a>, read the work of <a href= "electronicintifada.net">Electronic Intifada</a> and <a href= "mondoweiss.net">Mondoweiss</a>, as well as follow their respective social media pages <a href="twitter.com/intifada">@intifada</a> and <a href="twitter.com/Mondoweiss">@Mondoweiss</a>, and keep up to date with the <a href= "https://palestinianyouthmovement.com/">Palestinian Youth Movement</a> and <a href="https://wolpalestine.com/">Within Our Lifetime</a>.</p> <p><strong>Max Ajl</strong> is a postdoctoral researcher at the Ghent University, and is author of the fantastic <a href= "https://www.plutobooks.com/9780745341750/a-peoples-green-new-deal/"> A People's Green New Deal</a>.  Read Max's other written work on his <a href= "https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Max-Ajl">Researchgate page</a>.  Max also has a twitter page, but you must find it yourself!</p> <p><span style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont,       <pubDate>Fri, 13 Oct 2023 10:26:51 +0000</pubDate>

Thompson to talk about her book How the West Stole Democracy from the Arabs, about the historic Syrian-Arab Congress of 1920. </p> <p>Elizabeth Thompson is the Mohamed S. Farsi Chair of Islamic Peace and Professor of History at American University.  Her book was published by Atlantic Monthly Press, and is available here: <a href= "https://groveatlantic.com/book/how-the-west-stole-democracy-from-the-arabs/"> https://groveatlantic.com/book/how-the-west-stole-democracy-from-the-arabs/</a>    </p> <p><span style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content:</span> <a style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;" href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a><span style="font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> </span></p>]]></description>

    <item>
      <title>The Mexican Dirty War: A War to the Death w/ Alexander Aviña &amp; Benjamin T. Smith</title>
      <itunes:title>The Mexican Dirty War: A War to the Death w/ Alexander Aviña &amp;amp; Benjamin T. Smith</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 06 Oct 2023 08:50:44 +0000</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[b8249605-7553-4226-b160-a03b80e60431]]></guid>
      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/the-mexican-dirty-war-a-war-to-the-death-w-alexander-avia-benjamin-t-smith-0]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<p>In this episode of Guerrilla History, we bring on Benjamin T. Smith and his coauthor, returning fan favorite Alexander Aviña, to talk about an article that they just cowrote about the (ongoing) Mexican Dirty War for NACLA titled <a href= "https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/10714839.2023.2247740"><em>A War to the Death</em></a>!  This short article condenses the decades history of the Mexican Dirty War in advance of an upcoming Truth Commission report on state terrorism within Cold War era Mexico.  As our guests highlight though, this dirty war never really ended.  A great conversation, do us a favor and send it to comrades who are interested in Cold War Latin America, Mexican history, or state sponsored dirty wars, they will certainly find this useful!</p> <p><strong>Benjamin T. Smith</strong> <em>is professor of Latin American history at the University of Warwick and author of several books, including</em> The Dope: The Real History of the Mexican Drug Trade.  Ben's website is available at <a href= "thedope.co.uk">thedope.co.uk</a>, and he can be followed on twitter <a href= "twitter.com/benjamintsmith7">@benjamintsmith7</a></p> <p><strong>Alexander Aviña</strong> <em>is associate professor of Latin American history at Arizona State University and author of</em> Specters of Revolution: Peasant Guerrillas in the Cold War Mexican Countryside. Alex's website is available at <a href= "alexanderavina.com">alexanderavina.com</a>, and he can be followed on twitter <a href= "twitter.com/Alexander_Avina">@Alexander_Avina</a></p> <p><span style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content:</span> <a style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;" href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a><span style="font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> </span></p> <div id="highlighter--hover-tools" style="display: none;"> <div id="highlighter--hover-tools--container"> <div class="highlighter--icon highlighter--icon-copy" title="Copy">  </div> <div class="highlighter--separator"> </div> <div class="highlighter--icon highlighter--icon-delete" title= "Delete"> </div> </div> </div> <div       <title>The Mexican Dirty War: A War to the Death w/ Alexander Aviña &amp; Benjamin T. Smith</title>
      <itunes:title>The Mexican Dirty War: A War to the Death w/ Alexander Aviña &amp;amp; Benjamin T. Smith</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 06 Oct 2023 08:50:31 +0000</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[6a26614c-bb8b-412c-906b-1eee4b7040f3]]></guid>
      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/the-mexican-dirty-war-a-war-to-the-death-w-alexander-avia-benjamin-t-smith]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<p>In this episode of Guerrilla History, we bring on Benjamin T. Smith and his coauthor, returning fan favorite Alexander Aviña, to talk about an article that they just cowrote about the (ongoing) Mexican Dirty War for NACLA titled <a href= "https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/10714839.2023.2247740"><em>A War to the Death</em></a>!  This short article condenses the decades history of the Mexican Dirty War in advance of an upcoming Truth Commission report on state terrorism within Cold War era Mexico.  As our guests highlight though, this dirty war never really ended.  A great conversation, do us a favor and send it to comrades who are interested in Cold War Latin America, Mexican history, or state sponsored dirty wars, they will certainly find this useful!</p> <p><strong>Benjamin T. Smith</strong> <em>is professor of Latin American history at the University of Warwick and author of several books, including</em> The Dope: The Real History of the Mexican Drug Trade.  Ben's website is available at <a href= "thedope.co.uk">thedope.co.uk</a>, and he can be followed on twitter <a href= "twitter.com/benjamintsmith7">@benjamintsmith7</a></p> <p><strong>Alexander Aviña</strong> <em>is associate professor of Latin American history at Arizona State University and author of</em> Specters of Revolution: Peasant Guerrillas in the Cold War Mexican Countryside. Alex's website is available at <a href= "alexanderavina.com">alexanderavina.com</a>, and he can be followed on twitter <a href= "twitter.com/Alexander_Avina">@Alexander_Avina</a></p> <p><span style= you also will get bonus content:</span> <a style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;" href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a><span style="font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open       <content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>In this episode of Guerrilla History, we bring on Benjamin T. Smith and his coauthor, returning fan favorite Alexander Aviña, to talk about an article that they just cowrote about the (ongoing) Mexican Dirty War for NACLA titled <a href= "https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/10714839.2023.2247740"><em>A War to the Death</em></a>! This short article condenses the decades history of the Mexican Dirty War in advance of an upcoming Truth Commission report on state terrorism within Cold War era Mexico. As our guests highlight though, this dirty war never really ended. A great conversation, do us a favor and send it to comrades who are interested in Cold War Latin America, Mexican history, or state sponsored dirty wars, they will certainly find this useful!</p> <p>Benjamin T. Smith <em>is professor of Latin American history at the University of Warwick and author of several books, including</em> The Dope: The Real History of the Mexican Drug Trade. Ben's website is available at <a href= "thedope.co.uk">thedope.co.uk</a>, and he can be followed on twitter <a href= "twitter.com/benjamintsmith7">@benjamintsmith7</a></p> <p>Alexander Aviña <em>is associate professor of Latin American history at Arizona State University and author of</em> Specters of Revolution: Peasant Guerrillas in the Cold War Mexican Countryside. Alex's website is available at <a href= "alexanderavina.com">alexanderavina.com</a>, and he can be followed on twitter <a href= "twitter.com/Alexander_Avina">@Alexander_Avina</a></p> <p> Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;" href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a> </p>]]></content:encoded>

    <item>
      <title>China's Revolution &amp; the Quest for a Socialist Future w/ Ken Hammond</title>
      <itunes:title>China&#39;s Revolution &amp;amp; the Quest for a Socialist Future w/ Ken Hammond</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 29 Sep 2023 07:08:55 +0000</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[c8a2a941-6054-446d-80f7-7c3057ba5571]]></guid>
      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/chinas-revolution-the-quest-for-a-socialist-future-w-ken-hammond]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<p>In this episode of Guerrilla History, we bring on Ken Hammond to talk about his new book <a href= "https://1804books.com/products/chinas-revolution-and-the-quest-for-a-socialist-future"> China's Revolution & the Quest for a Socialist Future</a>!  Here, we provide an overview of modern Chinese history, and Ken makes his case that China is still on the path to a socialist future.  This was a fantastic survey of this history, and will serve as a great introduction to a forthcoming mini-series we will be doing with Ken on some specific events in modern Chinese History!</p> <p><strong>Ken Hammond</strong> is Professor of East Asian and Global History at New Mexico State University. He has been engaged in radical politics since his involvement in the anti-war movement at Kent State in 1968-70. He is a member of the Party for Socialism and Liberation, and an activist with Pivot to Peace.  You can get the book we discussed in this episode from <a href= "https://1804books.com/products/chinas-revolution-and-the-quest-for-a-socialist-future"> 1804 books</a>.</p> <p><span style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto,     <item>
      <title>Organizing, Militant Unionism, &amp; the Class War: The Fighting (Life &amp;) Times of Jon Melrod</title>
      <itunes:title>Organizing, Militant Unionism, &amp;amp; the Class War: The Fighting (Life &amp;amp;) Times of Jon Melrod</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 22 Sep 2023 09:16:39 +0000</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[62e1ecce-a5d7-4c5f-a47f-1e1f53b940ea]]></guid>
      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/organizing-militant-unionism-the-class-war-the-fighting-life-times-of-jon-melrod]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<p>In this outstanding episode of Guerrilla History, we bring on Jon Melrod to discuss his new book <a href= "https://pmpress.org/index.php?l=product_detail&p=1289">Fighting Times: Organizing on the Front Lines of the Class War</a> (use code FIGHTING to get 40% off)!  In this episode, we discuss the life and times of Jon, who in many ways is a real working class hero.  We talk about his early embrace of radical political ideology, his radical campus organizing, his 13 years fighting in and organizing within industrial factories in Wisconsin, his rise within the UAW, and his post-factory work as a lawyer representing political refugees and victims of police violence.  This conversation is really inspiring, and we cannot recommend enough that you pick up the book, read it with fellow workers, and share this episode with those you think would benefit!</p> <p><strong>Jon Melrod</strong> is a journalist, activist, and lawyer that left the campus for the factory in 1973. For thirteen years, he immersed himself in the day-to-day struggles of Milwaukee's working class, both on the factory floor and in the political arena. Despite FBI surveillance and interference, Jon organized a militant rank-and-file caucus and rose through union ranks to a top leadership position in UAW Local 72. After this part of his career, he opened a law firm in San Francisco, successfully representing hundreds of political refugees.  You can follow Jon on twitter <a href= "twitter.com/JonathanMelrod">@JonathanMelrod</a>, and keep up with his latest work and read more about his story on his website <a href="jonathanmelrod.com">jonathanmelrod.com</a>.</p> <p><span style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content:</span> <a style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;" href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a><span style="font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> </span></p> <div id="highlighter--hover-tools" style="display: none;"> <div id="highlighter--hover-tools--container"> <div class="highlighter--icon class="highlighter--separator"> </div> <div class="highlighter--icon highlighter--icon-delete" title= "Delete"> </div> </div> </div> <div id="highlighter--hover-tools" style="display: none;"> <div       <content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>In this outstanding episode of Guerrilla History, we bring on Jon Melrod to discuss his new book <a href= "https://pmpress.org/index.php?l=product_detail&p=1289">Fighting Times: Organizing on the Front Lines of the Class War</a> (use code FIGHTING to get 40% off)! In this episode, we discuss the life and times of Jon, who in many ways is a real working class hero. We talk about his early embrace of radical political ideology, his radical campus organizing, his 13 years fighting in and organizing within industrial factories in Wisconsin, his rise within the UAW, and his post-factory work as a lawyer representing political refugees and victims of police violence. This conversation is really inspiring, and we cannot recommend enough that you pick up the book, read it with fellow workers, and share this episode with those you think would benefit!</p> <p>Jon Melrod is a journalist, activist, and lawyer that left the campus for the factory in 1973. For thirteen years, he immersed himself in the day-to-day struggles of Milwaukee's working class, both on the factory floor and in the political arena. Despite FBI surveillance and interference, Jon organized a militant rank-and-file caucus and rose through union ranks to a top leadership position in UAW Local 72. After this part of his career, he opened a law firm in San Francisco, successfully representing hundreds of political refugees. You can follow Jon on twitter <a href= "twitter.com/JonathanMelrod">@JonathanMelrod</a>, and keep up with his latest work and read more about his story on his website <a href="jonathanmelrod.com">jonathanmelrod.com</a>.</p> <p> Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;" href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a> </p>]]></content:encoded>
