taken over the <a href= "https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/marx-madness/id1440691768">Marx Madness Podcast</a>.  Listen to the season of <a href= "https://peopleshistorypod.net/#season-two">People's History</a> they are putting together that goes much more into depth on the events of the Wounded Knee Occupation.  Also be sure to follow the Chunka Luta Network (<a href= "twitter.com/ChunkaLuta1973">@ChunkaLuta1973</a>) and Sungmanitou (<a href="twitter.com/BandsIsland">@BandsIsland</a>) on twitter!</div> </div> <div class="CNxNUMI4vuO8-fkO8bPPMQ== FdGBl7+r1sQJZTUFqRjvJw==" data-block="true" data-editor="6g5p4" data-offset-key="fnksa-0-0"> <div class= "public-DraftStyleDefault-block public-DraftStyleDefault-ltr" data-offset-key="fnksa-0-0"> </div> <div class= "public-DraftStyleDefault-block public-DraftStyleDefault-ltr" data-offset-key="fnksa-0-0"><span data-offset-key= "fnksa-0-0"><span data-text="true">Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content:</span></span> <a href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory"><span data-offset-key= "fnksa-1-0"><span data-text= "true">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</span></span></a></div> </div>]]></description>
      
      <content:encoded><![CDATA[In this episode of Guerrilla History, we bring on Sungmanitou Tanka to discuss the 50th anniversary of the Wounded Knee Occupation in 1973! We talk about the causes, the events themselves, and the legacy with 50 years of hindsight, a very important discussion on all of these fronts. Sungmanitou is of the Oglala Lakota Nation, is one of the hosts of <a href= "https://bandsofturtleislan.wixsite.com/home">Bands of Turtle Island</a>, and has recently also taken over the <a href= "https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/marx-madness/id1440691768">Marx Madness Podcast</a>. Listen to the season of <a href= "https://peopleshistorypod.net/#season-two">People's History</a> they are putting together that goes much more into depth on the events of the Wounded Knee Occupation. Also be sure to follow the Chunka Luta Network (<a href= "twitter.com/ChunkaLuta1973">@ChunkaLuta1973</a>) and Sungmanitou (<a href="twitter.com/BandsIsland">@BandsIsland</a>) on twitter! Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a>]]></content:encoded>

    <item>
      <title>Black Communist Women's Political Writing w/ Charisse Burden-Stelly and Jodi Dean</title>
      <itunes:title>Black Communist Women&#39;s Political Writing w/ Charisse Burden-Stelly and Jodi Dean</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 24 Feb 2023 09:15:05 +0000</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[267830da-9489-47d3-a51a-708be265cb1e]]></guid>
      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/black-communist-womens-political-writing-w-charisse-burden-stelly-and-jodi-dean]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<div class="CNxNUMI4vuO8-fkO8bPPMQ== FdGBl7+r1sQJZTUFqRjvJw==" data-block="true" data-editor="6g5p4" data-offset-key="296p8-0-0"> <div class= "public-DraftStyleDefault-block public-DraftStyleDefault-ltr" data-offset-key="296p8-0-0"><span data-offset-key= "296p8-0-0"><span data-text="true">In this episode of Guerrilla History, we bring on two fantastic guests, Prof. Charisse Burden-Stelly and Prof. Jodi Dean</span></span><span data-offset-key= "296p8-4-0"><span data-text="true">. We discuss their co-edited collection, <a href= "https://www.versobooks.com/books/4071-organize-fight-win">Organize, Fight, Win: Black Communist Women's Political Writing</a>, which is an absolutely indispensable resource for those of us serious about achieving liberation!  This collection includes writings focused on the period from 1919-1956, which argue that racial and economic equality can only be achieved by overthrowing capitalism.  Pick up the book!</span></span></div> <div class= "public-DraftStyleDefault-block public-DraftStyleDefault-ltr" data-offset-key="296p8-0-0"> </div> </div> <div class="CNxNUMI4vuO8-fkO8bPPMQ== FdGBl7+r1sQJZTUFqRjvJw==" data-block="true" data-editor="6g5p4" data-offset-key="6vi2b-0-0"> <div class= "public-DraftStyleDefault-block public-DraftStyleDefault-ltr" data-offset-key="6vi2b-0-0">Dr. CBS is an Associate Professor of African American Studies at <em>Wayne State</em> <em>University</em>.  She is an organizer with <a href= "https://blackallianceforpeace.com/">Black Alliance for Peace</a> and a Co-Author of <a href= "https://www.abc-clio.com/products/a5807c/">W.E.B. Du Bois: A Life in American History</a> alongside our mutual friend Gerald Horne.  She can be followed on twitter <a href= "twitter.com/blackleftaf">@blackleftaf</a> or on her website <a href= "https://www.charisseburdenstelly.com/">https://www.charisseburdenstelly.com/</a>.</div> </div> <div class="CNxNUMI4vuO8-fkO8bPPMQ== FdGBl7+r1sQJZTUFqRjvJw==" data-block="true" data-editor="6g5p4" data-offset-key="fnksa-0-0"> <div class= "public-DraftStyleDefault-block public-DraftStyleDefault-ltr" data-offset-key="fnksa-0-0"> </div> <div class= "public-DraftStyleDefault-block public-DraftStyleDefault-ltr" data-offset-key="fnksa-0-0">Dr. Jodi Dean is a Professor of Political Science at <em>Hobart and William Smith Colleges</em>.  She is the author of numerous books including <a href="https://www.versobooks.com/books/3060-comrade">Comrade: An Essay on Political Belonging</a>, <a href= "https://www.versobooks.com/books/2802-crowds-and-party">Crowds and Party</a>, and <a href= "https://www.versobooks.com/books/2718-the-communist-horizon">The Communist Horizon</a>.  She can be followed on twitter <a href="twitter.com/jodi7768">@jodi7768</a>.</div> <div class= "public-DraftStyleDefault-block public-DraftStyleDefault-ltr" data-offset-key="fnksa-0-0"> </div> <div class= "public-DraftStyleDefault-block public-DraftStyleDefault-ltr" data-offset-key="fnksa-0-0"><span data-offset-key= "fnksa-0-0"><span data-text="true">Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: </span></span><a href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory"><span data-offset-key= "fnksa-1-0"><span data-text= "true">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</span></span></a></div> </div>]]></description>
      
      <content:encoded><![CDATA[In this episode of Guerrilla History, we bring on two fantastic guests, Prof. Charisse Burden-Stelly and Prof. Jodi Dean. We discuss their co-edited collection, <a href= "https://www.versobooks.com/books/4071-organize-fight-win">Organize, Fight, Win: Black Communist Women's Political Writing</a>, which is an absolutely indispensable resource for those of us serious about achieving liberation! This collection includes writings focused on the period from 1919-1956, which argue that racial and economic equality can only be achieved by overthrowing capitalism. Pick up the book! Dr. CBS is an Associate Professor of African American Studies at <em>Wayne State</em> <em>University</em>. She is an organizer with <a href= "https://blackallianceforpeace.com/">Black Alliance for Peace</a> and a Co-Author of <a href= "https://www.abc-clio.com/products/a5807c/">W.E.B. Du Bois: A Life in American History</a> alongside our mutual friend Gerald Horne. She can be followed on twitter <a href= "twitter.com/blackleftaf">@blackleftaf</a> or on her website <a href= "https://www.charisseburdenstelly.com/">https://www.charisseburdenstelly.com/</a>. Dr. Jodi Dean is a Professor of Political Science at <em>Hobart and William Smith Colleges</em>. She is the author of numerous books including <a href="https://www.versobooks.com/books/3060-comrade">Comrade: An Essay on Political Belonging</a>, <a href= "https://www.versobooks.com/books/2802-crowds-and-party">Crowds and Party</a>, and <a href= "https://www.versobooks.com/books/2718-the-communist-horizon">The Communist Horizon</a>. She can be followed on twitter <a href="twitter.com/jodi7768">@jodi7768</a>. Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a>]]></content:encoded>

      <content:encoded><![CDATA[This is an episode from our spin-off show. On this exciting episode of <a href= "https://twitter.com/guerrilla_pod">Guerrilla Radio</a>, Partisan Brigade members <a href= "https://twitter.com/GoodVibePolitik">James</a> and <a href= "https://twitter.com/shathawhat">Shatha</a> are joined by the two founders of <a href= "https://palestineaction.org/">Palestine Action</a>, <a href= "https://twitter.com/HudaAmmori">Huda Ammori</a> and <a href= "https://twitter.com/Richard_palact">Richard Barnard</a>. Palestine Action is an organization engaged in direct action to materially disrupt the supply chain of of Israel's largest arms, drones, and security manufacturer: Elbit Systems. In this episode we breakdown direct action, the important role Palestine Action plays in the Palestinian solidarity struggle and how it connects to a larger global internationalist struggle against Zionist colonial expansion and imperialism. To connect with Palestine Action they are on Twitter, Instagram and Tiktok as <a href= "https://twitter.com/Pal_Action">Pal_Action</a> and by email: info@palestineaction.org The intro/outro song is <a href= "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PEra1mdP9ns"> Model Home by snny ft. Topaz Jones</a>]]></content:encoded>

      <pubDate>Fri, 17 Feb 2023 21:01:06 +0000</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[21e5fdd8-b919-4e63-a633-b4141bbd8d9c]]></guid>
      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/the-black-liberation-army-w-comrade-z-of-rookery-press]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<div class="CNxNUMI4vuO8-fkO8bPPMQ== FdGBl7+r1sQJZTUFqRjvJw==" data-block="true" data-editor="6g5p4" data-offset-key="296p8-0-0"> <div class= "public-DraftStyleDefault-block public-DraftStyleDefault-ltr" data-offset-key="296p8-0-0"><span data-offset-key= "296p8-0-0"><span data-text="true">In this episode of Guerrilla History, we bring on Comrade Z from</span></span> <a href= "https://rookerypress.wordpress.com/"><span data-offset-key= "296p8-1-0"><span data-text="true">Rookery Press</span></span></a> <span data-offset-key="296p8-2-0"><span data-text="true">to talk about a vital new book</span></span> <a href= "https://rookerypress.wordpress.com/2023/02/08/collected-works-of-the-black-liberation-army-vol-1/"> <span data-offset-key="296p8-3-0"><span data-text="true">Collected Works of the Black Liberation Army</span></span></a><span data-offset-key= "296p8-4-0"><span data-text="true">. In this episode, we discuss the history, idology, tactics, and legacy of the BLA, and we truly feel this is an important episode. We highly encourage everyone to pick up the book, and also share the episode with others who would benefit from hearing about a militant and radical organization, based off of their own writings!</span></span></div> <div class= "public-DraftStyleDefault-block public-DraftStyleDefault-ltr" data-offset-key="296p8-0-0"> </div> </div> <div class="CNxNUMI4vuO8-fkO8bPPMQ== FdGBl7+r1sQJZTUFqRjvJw==" data-block="true" data-editor="6g5p4" data-offset-key="6vi2b-0-0"> <div class= "public-DraftStyleDefault-block public-DraftStyleDefault-ltr" data-offset-key="6vi2b-0-0"><span data-offset-key= "6vi2b-0-0"><span data-text="true">Comrade Z is a member of the Rookery Press. Rookery Press is a new publishing house dedicated to retrieving forgotten texts and theory lost to the Whirlwind. You can find their published works on their</span></span> <a href= "https://rookerypress.wordpress.com/"><span data-offset-key= "6vi2b-1-0"><span data-text= "true">website</span></span></a><span data-offset-key= "6vi2b-2-0"><span data-text="true">, and you can also follow them on twitter</span></span> <a href= "https://anchor.fm/dashboard/episode/e1tk842/metadata/twitter.com/rookerypress"> <span data-offset-key="6vi2b-3-0"><span data-text= "true">@rookerypress</span></span></a></div> </div> <div class="CNxNUMI4vuO8-fkO8bPPMQ== FdGBl7+r1sQJZTUFqRjvJw==" data-block="true" data-editor="6g5p4" data-offset-key="fnksa-0-0"> <div class= "public-DraftStyleDefault-block public-DraftStyleDefault-ltr" data-offset-key="fnksa-0-0"> </div> <div class= "public-DraftStyleDefault-block public-DraftStyleDefault-ltr" data-offset-key="fnksa-0-0"><span data-offset-key= "fnksa-0-0"><span data-text="true">Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: </span></span><a href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory"><span data-offset-key= "fnksa-1-0"><span data-text= "true">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</span></span></a></div> </div>]]></description>
      
      <content:encoded><![CDATA[In this episode of Guerrilla History, we bring on Comrade Z from <a href= "https://rookerypress.wordpress.com/">Rookery Press</a> to talk about a vital new book <a href= "https://rookerypress.wordpress.com/2023/02/08/collected-works-of-the-black-liberation-army-vol-1/"> Collected Works of the Black Liberation Army</a>. In this episode, we discuss the history, idology, tactics, and legacy of the BLA, and we truly feel this is an important episode. We highly encourage everyone to pick up the book, and also share the episode with others who would benefit from hearing about a militant and radical organization, based off of their own writings! Comrade Z is a member of the Rookery Press. Rookery Press is a new publishing house dedicated to retrieving forgotten texts and theory lost to the Whirlwind. You can find their published works on their <a href= "https://rookerypress.wordpress.com/">website</a>, and you can also follow them on twitter <a href= "https://anchor.fm/dashboard/episode/e1tk842/metadata/twitter.com/rookerypress"> @rookerypress</a> Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a>]]></content:encoded>

    <item>
      <title>The History &amp; Impact of Sanctions on Iraq w/ Nima Nakhaei</title>
      <itunes:title>The History &amp;amp; Impact of Sanctions on Iraq w/ Nima Nakhaei</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 10 Feb 2023 09:47:14 +0000</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[f62df69e-9e74-45c8-9e9b-4507f9dd4314]]></guid>
      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/the-history-impact-of-sanctions-on-iraq-w-nima-nakhaei]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<p>This episode of Guerrilla History is a continuation of our Sanctions As War miniseries.  In this important episode, we bring on Nima Nakhaei to discuss the history and impact of sanctions on Iraq, the repercussions of which we continue to see today!  Get the word out and share this with comrades involved in the anti-sanctions movement.</p> <div class="page" title="Page 12"> <div class="layoutArea"> <div class="column"> <div class="page" title="Page 14"> <div class="layoutArea"> <div class="column"> <p><span style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> Nima Nakhaei is a faculty member in the Department of Politics at York University. His research sits at the nexus of Marxist political economy, Poulantzasian state theory and Gramscian discourse analysis. Within this approach, he explores the ways in which the political economy, state formations and identity discourses in the Middle East have been structured by the interiorization of imperialist relations and their crises.</span></p> <p><span style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content:</span> <a style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;" href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a><span style="font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> </span></p> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div>]]></description>
      
      <content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>This episode of Guerrilla History is a continuation of our Sanctions As War miniseries. In this important episode, we bring on Nima Nakhaei to discuss the history and impact of sanctions on Iraq, the repercussions of which we continue to see today! Get the word out and share this with comrades involved in the anti-sanctions movement.</p> <p> Nima Nakhaei is a faculty member in the Department of Politics at York University. His research sits at the nexus of Marxist political economy, Poulantzasian state theory and Gramscian discourse analysis. Within this approach, he explores the ways in which the political economy, state formations and identity discourses in the Middle East have been structured by the interiorization of imperialist relations and their crises.</p> <p> Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;" href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a> </p>]]></content:encoded>

      <description><![CDATA[<p>In this episode of Guerrilla History, we present something a bit different than usual!  We recently appeared on Lee Camp's program Behind the Headlines to discuss interview on Lee's show in its entirety.  A very fun interview, be sure to check out <a href= "https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC5AAzW7rmImKFqnx5YldIGA?app=desktop"> Behind the Headlines</a> if you     <item>
      <title>National Liberation Struggles &amp; the Agrarian Question w/ Max Ajl</title>
      <itunes:title>National Liberation Struggles &amp;amp; the Agrarian Question w/ Max Ajl</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 27 Jan 2023 09:34:55 +0000</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[70ad786b-1528-4b4a-bae8-c1033bfad616]]></guid>
      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/national-liberation-struggles-the-agrarian-question-w-max-ajl]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<p>In this episode of Guerrilla History, we bring on a good comrade of ours, Max Ajl (much overdue, we might add)!  Here, we get a primer on the agrarian question and discuss its importance to national liberation struggles globally!  Max is the perfect guest for this conversation, and we know you'll get a lot out of it.</p> <p>Max Ajl is is an associated researcher with the Tunisian Observatory for Food Sovereignty and the Environment, a researcher on decolonization, post-colonial planning, Arab dependency theory and food sovereignty at Ghent University, and the author of the outstanding <a href= "https://www.plutobooks.com/9780745341750/a-peoples-green-new-deal/"> A People's Green New Deal</a>.  You can follow Max on twitter <a href="twitter.com/maxajl">@maxajl</a>. </p> <p><span style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content:</span> <a style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;" href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a><span style="font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> </span></p>]]></description>
      
      <content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>In this episode of Guerrilla History, we bring on a good comrade of ours, Max Ajl (much overdue, we might add)! Here, we get a primer on the agrarian question and discuss its importance to national liberation struggles globally! Max is the perfect guest for this conversation, and we know you'll get a lot out of it.</p> <p>Max Ajl is is an associated researcher with the Tunisian Observatory for Food Sovereignty and the Environment, a researcher on decolonization, post-colonial planning, Arab dependency theory and food sovereignty at Ghent University, and the author of the outstanding <a href= "https://www.plutobooks.com/9780745341750/a-peoples-green-new-deal/"> A People's Green New Deal</a>. You can follow Max on twitter <a href="twitter.com/maxajl">@maxajl</a>. </p> <p> Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;" href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a> </p>]]></content:encoded>

      <title>Sanctions Against China &amp; Their Political Economy w/ Zhun Xu</title>
      <itunes:title>Sanctions Against China &amp;amp; Their Political Economy w/ Zhun Xu</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 20 Jan 2023 09:20:55 +0000</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[aa5d2626-2da2-4c30-9ca1-de24f87c0fab]]></guid>
      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/sanctions-against-china-their-political-economy-w-zhun-xu]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<p>This episode of Guerrilla History is a continuation of our Sanctions As War miniseries.  In this fantastic episode, we have a discussion with Professor Zhun Xu on the political economy of US sanctions on China, both from a historical perspective as well as analyzing current developments.  We're sure that this will be of great interest to many of you and your comrades.  Help us get the word out by sending it along!</p> <div class="page" title="Page 12"> <div class="layoutArea"> <div class="column"> <div class="page" title="Page 14"> <div class="layoutArea"> <div class="column"> <p>Zhun Xu is Associate Professor of Economics at John Jay College, City University of New York. He is on the editorial boards of Science and Society and the Journal of Labor and Society. His recent book is <a href= "https://monthlyreview.org/product/from-commune-to-capitalism-how-chinas-peasants-lost-collective-farming-and-gained-urban-poverty/"> <em>From Commune to Capitalism: How China's Peasants Lost Collective Farming and Gained Urban Poverty</em></a><span style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;">.</span></p> <p><span style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content:</span> <a style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;" href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a><span style="font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> </span></p> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div>]]></description>
      
      <content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>This episode of Guerrilla History is a continuation of our Sanctions As War miniseries. In this fantastic episode, we have a discussion with Professor Zhun Xu on the political economy of US sanctions on China, both from a historical perspective as well as analyzing current developments. We're sure that this will be of great interest to many of you and your comrades. Help us get the word out by sending it along!</p> <p>Zhun Xu is Associate Professor of Economics at John Jay College, City University of New York. He is on the editorial boards of Science and Society and the Journal of Labor and Society. His recent book is <a href= "https://monthlyreview.org/product/from-commune-to-capitalism-how-chinas-peasants-lost-collective-farming-and-gained-urban-poverty/"> <em>From Commune to Capitalism: How China's Peasants Lost Collective Farming and Gained Urban Poverty</em></a>.</p> <p> Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;" href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a> </p>]]></content:encoded>

    <item>
      <title>World-Ecology and the Capitalocene w/ Jason Moore</title>
      <itunes:title>World-Ecology and the Capitalocene w/ Jason Moore</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 13 Jan 2023 09:31:16 +0000</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[650d8d09-ab80-4ff1-9b45-381ecec8fccc]]></guid>
      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/world-ecology-and-the-capitalocene-w-jason-moore]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<p>In this episode of Guerrilla History, we bring on a good friend and comrade of ours, Professor Jason W. Moore!  In this fabulous conversation, we discuss world-ecology, the capitalocene, and how to view/analyze history through these lenses.  We intend on getting into much further discussion with Jason in a couple of upcoming episodes that we already have planned, so be sure to check this one out to prepare yourself for those!</p> <p>Jason W. Moore is an environmental historian and historical geographer at Binghamton University, and has authored multiple outstanding books that you should check out. Among these are <a href= "https://secure.pmpress.org/index.php?l=product_detail&p=779">Anthropocene or Capitalocene? Nature, History, and the Crisis of Capitalism</a>, <a href= "https://www.versobooks.com/books/1924-capitalism-in-the-web-of-life"> Capitalism in the Web of Life: Ecology and the Accumulation of Capital</a>, and (with Raj Patel) <a href= "https://www.ucpress.edu/book/9780520299931/a-history-of-the-world-in-seven-cheap-things#:~:text=Nature%2C%20money%2C%20work%2C%20care,%2C%20governed%2C%20and%20devastated%20Earth."> A History of the World in Seven Cheap Things: A Guide to Capitalism, Nature, and the Future of the Planet</a>, the last of which we already have an upcoming episode planned for.  You can follow Jason on twitter <a href= "twitter.com/oikeios">@oikeios</a>. </p> <p><span style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content:</span> <a style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;" href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a><span style="font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> </span></p> <p>We also have a (free!) <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.substack.com/p/guerrilla-history-newsletter-1"> newsletter</a> you can sign up for, a great resource for political education!</p>]]></description>

      <pubDate>Fri, 06 Jan 2023 13:40:49 +0000</pubDate>

      <description><![CDATA[<p>In this episode of Guerrilla History, we bring back returning fan favorite Professor Gerald Horne to discuss his latest book <a href= "https://www.intpubnyc.com/browse/the-counter-revolution-of-1836-texas-slavery-jim-crow-and-the-roots-of-u-s-fascism/"> The Counter-Revolution of 1836: Texas Slavery & Jim Crow and the Roots of U. S. Fascism</a>.  As always, the conversation with Prof Horne is incredibly enlightening and very entertaining.  We hope you get some use from it!</p> <p>Gerald Horne is the John J. and Rebecca Moores Chair of History and African American Studies at the University of Houston.  His research interests are unbelievably varied, encompassing biographies of W.E.B. Du Bois and Paul Robeson, to The Haitian Revolution, to Hollywood in the '30s-'50s, to Jazz and Justice.  Be sure to check out his bibliography, you're certain to find something that interests you!</p> <p><span style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content:</span> <a style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;" href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a><span style="font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> </span></p> <p>We also have a (free!) <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.substack.com/p/guerrilla-history-newsletter-1"> newsletter</a> you can sign up for, a great resource for political education!</p>]]></description>

    <item>
      <title>The British Marxist Historians w/ Harvey J. Kaye</title>
      <itunes:title>The British Marxist Historians w/ Harvey J. Kaye</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 23 Dec 2022 10:11:33 +0000</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[181ab42e-15dc-4fd6-9c06-98161006aade]]></guid>
      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/the-british-marxist-historians-w-harvey-j-kaye]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<p>This episode of Guerrilla History is with Professor Harvey J. Kaye about his book <a href= "https://www.johnhuntpublishing.com/zer0-books/our-books/british-marxist-historians"> The British Marxist Historians</a>, the first and most complete study of the work of the British Marxist intellectuals Maurice Dobb, Rodney Hilton, Christopher Hill, Eric Hobsbawm, and E.P. Thompson, and has just gotten released as a new edition from Zer0 Books.  A fascinating conversation about a fascinating group of characters!</p> <div class="page" title="Page 12"> <div class="layoutArea"> <div class="column"> <div class="page" title="Page 14"> <div class="layoutArea"> <div class="column"> <p>Harvey J. Kaye is Professor Emeritus of Democracy and Justice Studies at the University of Wisconsin–Green Bay.  In addition to The British Marxist Historians, he written numerous other books including <a href= "https://www.johnhuntpublishing.com/zer0-books/our-books/take-hold-of-our-history"> Take Hold of Our History: Make America Radical Again</a>, <a href= "https://us.macmillan.com/books/9780374707064/thomaspaineandthepromiseofamerica"> Thomas Paine and the Promise of America</a>, and <a href= "https://www.simonandschuster.com/books/The-Fight-for-the-Four-Freedoms/Harvey-J-Kaye/9781451691443"> The Fight for the Four Freedoms</a>.  He can be followed on twitter <a href="twitter.com/harveyjkaye">@harveyjkaye</a></p> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> <p><span style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content:</span> <a style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;" href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a><span style="font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> </span></p> <p>We also have a (free!) <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.substack.com/p/guerrilla-history-newsletter-1"> newsletter</a> you can sign up for, a great resource for political education!</p>]]></description>
      
      <content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>This episode of Guerrilla History is with Professor Harvey J. Kaye about his book <a href= "https://www.johnhuntpublishing.com/zer0-books/our-books/british-marxist-historians"> The British Marxist Historians</a>, the first and most complete study of the work of the British Marxist intellectuals Maurice Dobb, Rodney Hilton, Christopher Hill, Eric Hobsbawm, and E.P. Thompson, and has just gotten released as a new edition from Zer0 Books. A fascinating conversation about a fascinating group of characters!</p> <p>Harvey J. Kaye is Professor Emeritus of Democracy and Justice Studies at the University of Wisconsin–Green Bay. In addition to The British Marxist Historians, he written numerous other books including <a href= "https://www.johnhuntpublishing.com/zer0-books/our-books/take-hold-of-our-history"> Take Hold of Our History: Make America Radical Again</a>, <a href= "https://us.macmillan.com/books/9780374707064/thomaspaineandthepromiseofamerica"> Thomas Paine and the Promise of America</a>, and <a href= "https://www.simonandschuster.com/books/The-Fight-for-the-Four-Freedoms/Harvey-J-Kaye/9781451691443"> The Fight for the Four Freedoms</a>. He can be followed on twitter <a href="twitter.com/harveyjkaye">@harveyjkaye</a></p> <p> Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;" href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a> </p> <p>We also have a (free!) <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.substack.com/p/guerrilla-history-newsletter-1"> newsletter</a> you can sign up for, a great resource for political education!</p>]]></content:encoded>

    <item>
      <title>People's History of Europe (Part 2 - Post-WWII) w/ Raquel Varela</title>
      <itunes:title>People&#39;s History of Europe (Part 2 - Post-WWII) w/ Raquel Varela</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 16 Dec 2022 10:08:03 +0000</pubDate>

      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/peoples-history-of-europe-part-2-post-wwii-w-raquel-varela]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<p>This episode of Guerrilla History is Part 2 of a two-part conversation with Professor Raquel Varela on the history of modern Europe.  In this installment, we carry on from last time, where we left off at the end of WWII.  If you haven't already checked out part 1, be sure to do so!  This work necessitates critical engagement!</p> <div class="page" title="Page 12"> <div class="layoutArea"> <div class="column"> <div class="page" title="Page 14"> <div class="layoutArea"> <div class="column"> <p>Raquel Varela is a labour historian, researcher and Professor at New University of Lisbon, and Honorary Fellow at the International Institute for Social History.  She is the author of <a href= "https://www.plutobooks.com/9780745341354/a-peoples-history-of-europe/"> A People's History of Europe: From WWI to Today</a>.  </p> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> <p><span style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content:</span> <a style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;" href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a><span style="font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> </span></p> <p>We also have a (free!) <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.substack.com/p/guerrilla-history-newsletter-1"> newsletter</a> you can sign up for, a great resource for political education!</p>]]></description>
      
      <content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>This episode of Guerrilla History is Part 2 of a two-part conversation with Professor Raquel Varela on the history of modern Europe. In this installment, we carry on from last time, where we left off at the end of WWII. If you haven't already checked out part 1, be sure to do so! This work necessitates critical engagement!</p> <p>Raquel Varela is a labour historian, researcher and Professor at New University of Lisbon, and Honorary Fellow at the International Institute for Social History. She is the author of <a href= "https://www.plutobooks.com/9780745341354/a-peoples-history-of-europe/"> A People's History of Europe: From WWI to Today</a>. </p> <p> Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;" href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a> </p> <p>We also have a (free!) <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.substack.com/p/guerrilla-history-newsletter-1"> newsletter</a> you can sign up for, a great resource for political education!</p>]]></content:encoded>

      <title>People's History of Europe (Part 1 - WWI through WWII) w/ Raquel Varela</title>
      <itunes:title>People&#39;s History of Europe (Part 1 - WWI through WWII) w/ Raquel Varela</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 09 Dec 2022 10:00:46 +0000</pubDate>

      <description><![CDATA[<p>This episode of Guerrilla History is Part 1 of a two-part conversation with Professor Raquel Varela on the history of modern Europe.  In this installment, we cover the period from WWI through WWII, and it was a great conversation!  The next part will come out next week and will bring us from the end of WWII to today.</p> <div class="page" title="Page 12"> <div class="layoutArea"> <div class="column"> <div class="page" title="Page 14"> <div class="layoutArea"> <div class="column"> <p>Raquel Varela is a labour historian, researcher and Professor at New University of Lisbon, and Honorary Fellow at the International Institute for Social History.  She is the author of <a href= "https://www.plutobooks.com/9780745341354/a-peoples-history-of-europe/"> A People's History of Europe: From WWI to Today</a>.  </p> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> <p><span style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content:</span> <a style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;" href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a><span style="font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> </span></p> <p>We also have a (free!) <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.substack.com/p/guerrilla-history-newsletter-1"> newsletter</a> you can sign up for, a great resource for political education!</p>]]></description>
      
      <content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>This episode of Guerrilla History is Part 1 of a two-part conversation with Professor Raquel Varela on the history of modern Europe. In this installment, we cover the period from WWI through WWII, and it was a great conversation! The next part will come out next week and will bring us from the end of WWII to today.</p> <p>Raquel Varela is a labour historian, researcher and Professor at New University of Lisbon, and Honorary Fellow at the International Institute for Social History. She is the author of <a href= "https://www.plutobooks.com/9780745341354/a-peoples-history-of-europe/"> A People's History of Europe: From WWI to Today</a>. </p> <p> Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;" href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a> </p> <p>We also have a (free!) <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.substack.com/p/guerrilla-history-newsletter-1"> newsletter</a> you can sign up for, a great resource for political education!</p>]]></content:encoded>

      <title>The Battle of Spioen Kop - From the Archives</title>
      <itunes:title>The Battle of Spioen Kop - From the Archives</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 02 Dec 2022 10:36:22 +0000</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[6091d1ea-2e6b-4ba6-866c-2902496e1836]]></guid>
      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/the-battle-of-spioen-kop-from-the-archives]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<p>Guerrilla History "From the Archives" is a new series of episodes, consisting of previously patreon-exclusive episodes that we are unlocking for the general public after one year.  This From the Archives episode was originally released on Patreon on May 29, 2021, and is about the Battle of Spioen Kop, during the Second Boer War.  This battle, which was an utter calamity for the British, was the last high water mark for the Boers during the Boer Wars, and ushered us  into the 20th century of warfare.</p> <p>You can support Guerrilla History by joining us at <a href= "patreon.com/guerrillahistory">patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a>, where you will also get bonus content!</p>]]></description>

      <title>The History of US Sanctions on Cuba w/ Helen Yaffe</title>
      <itunes:title>The History of US Sanctions on Cuba w/ Helen Yaffe</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 25 Nov 2022 13:09:41 +0000</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[76231c82-9365-4fa1-84d5-23694f6c0274]]></guid>
      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/the-history-of-us-sanctions-on-cuba-w-helen-yaffe]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<p>This episode of Guerrilla History is a continuation of our Sanctions As War miniseries.  In this excellent episode, we have a discussion with Professor Helen Yaffe on the history and the impacts of sanctions on Cuba, absolutely something that all anti-imperialists need to be fully aware of and engage with to act in solidarity with the Cuban Revolution.  Help us spread the word by sharing with comrades, it will be of benefit to the show and to the left movement generally.  Be sure to also stay turned for more installments of our Sanctions As War series!</p> <div class="page" title="Page 12"> <div class="layoutArea"> <div class="column"> <div class="page" title="Page 14"> <div class="layoutArea"> <div class="column"> <p>Helen Yaffe <span style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> is a lecturer in Economic and Social History at the University of Glasgow, specialising in Cuban and Latin American development. She is the author of <em>We Are Cuba! How a Revolutionary People Have Survived in a Post-Soviet World</em> (Yale University Press, 2020) and <em>Che Guevara: The Economics of Revolution</em> (Palgrave Macmillan, 2009</span>).  She can be found on Twitter <a href= "twitter.com/HelenYaffe">@HelenYaffe</a></p> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> <p><span style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content:</span> <a style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;" href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a><span style="font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> </span></p> <p>We also have a (free!) <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.substack.com/p/guerrilla-history-newsletter-1"> newsletter</a> you can sign up for, a great resource for political education!</p>]]></description>
      
      <content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>This episode of Guerrilla History is a continuation of our Sanctions As War miniseries. In this excellent episode, we have a discussion with Professor Helen Yaffe on the history and the impacts of sanctions on Cuba, absolutely something that all anti-imperialists need to be fully aware of and engage with to act in solidarity with the Cuban Revolution. Help us spread the word by sharing with comrades, it will be of benefit to the show and to the left movement generally. Be sure to also stay turned for more installments of our Sanctions As War series!</p> <p>Helen Yaffe is a lecturer in Economic and Social History at the University of Glasgow, specialising in Cuban and Latin American development. She is the author of <em>We Are Cuba! How a Revolutionary People Have Survived in a Post-Soviet World</em> (Yale University Press, 2020) and <em>Che Guevara: The Economics of Revolution</em> (Palgrave Macmillan, 2009). She can be found on Twitter <a href= "twitter.com/HelenYaffe">@HelenYaffe</a></p> <p> Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;" href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a> </p> <p>We also have a (free!) <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.substack.com/p/guerrilla-history-newsletter-1"> newsletter</a> you can sign up for, a great resource for political education!</p>]]></content:encoded>

      <title>The World Cup: Sport, Politics, History, and Propaganda w/ Alexander Aviña</title>
      <itunes:title>The World Cup: Sport, Politics, History, and Propaganda w/ Alexander Aviña</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 18 Nov 2022 09:23:34 +0000</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[bbbedbda-678e-41ca-b0cc-5f8f39a2e744]]></guid>
      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/the-world-cup-sport-politics-history-and-propaganda-w-alexander-avia]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<p>This episode of Guerrilla History comes out just in time for the start of the 2022 World Cup in Qatar!  In this episode, we bring back fan favorite Alexander Aviña to discuss the politics behind the World Cup, both historically and in this current edition.  We hit on topics of human rights, sports washing, and propaganda in both cases. We also talk about the sport itself and the prospects on the field for this edition of the biggest prize within The Beautiful Game!</p> <p>Alexander Aviña is historian at Arizona State University, and is author of the book Specters of Revolution:  Peasant Guerrilla in the Cold War Mexican Countryside (Oxford University Press, 2014, <a href= "https://alexanderavina.com/specters-of-revolution/">https://alexanderavina.com/specters-of-revolution/</a> ).  Find him on Twitter <a href= "twitter.com/Alexander_Avina">@Alexander_Avina</a>, and listen to the episode we did with him on <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/intelligence-briefing-the-beautiful-game-w-alexander-avin"> The Beautiful Game</a>.</p> <p>You can support Guerrilla History by joining us at <a href= "patreon.com/guerrillahistory">patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a>, where you will also get bonus content!</p>]]></description>
      
      <content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>This episode of Guerrilla History comes out just in time for the start of the 2022 World Cup in Qatar! In this episode, we bring back fan favorite Alexander Aviña to discuss the politics behind the World Cup, both historically and in this current edition. We hit on topics of human rights, sports washing, and propaganda in both cases. We also talk about the sport itself and the prospects on the field for this edition of the biggest prize within The Beautiful Game!</p> <p>Alexander Aviña is historian at Arizona State University, and is author of the book Specters of Revolution: Peasant Guerrilla in the Cold War Mexican Countryside (Oxford University Press, 2014, <a href= "https://alexanderavina.com/specters-of-revolution/">https://alexanderavina.com/specters-of-revolution/</a> ). Find him on Twitter <a href= "twitter.com/Alexander_Avina">@Alexander_Avina</a>, and listen to the episode we did with him on <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/intelligence-briefing-the-beautiful-game-w-alexander-avin"> The Beautiful Game</a>.</p> <p>You can support Guerrilla History by joining us at <a href= "patreon.com/guerrillahistory">patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a>, where you will also get bonus content!</p>]]></content:encoded>

      <title>Haiti and Western Intervention w/ Pascal Robert - Dispatch</title>
      <itunes:title>Haiti and Western Intervention w/ Pascal Robert - Dispatch</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 11 Nov 2022 08:46:10 +0000</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[29d7b122-6259-4a01-bb0a-737afdde8ebd]]></guid>
      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/haiti-and-western-intervention-w-pascal-robert-dispatch]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<p>In this Dispatch episode, we provide a grounding on the history of Western intervention in Haiti in order to analyze the current situation taking place there, and the prospects for even expanded intervention.  For this, we bring on Pascal Robert, who's writing on Haiti has been very useful in shedding light on a locality that the Western media tends to ignore unless convenient for them.  W're also joined by our friend James Ray as a guest host for this episode.  Enjoy, and share!</p> <p>Pascal Robert is a writer, political commentator, contributor to <a href="https://www.blackagendareport.com/">Black Agenda Report</a> (if you're not already reading BAR, you should start right now!) and Newsweek, and is cohost of the <a href= "https://www.thisisrevolutionpodcast.com/">This Is Revolution Podcast</a>.  He can be followed on twitter <a href= "twitter.com/probert06">@probert06</a></p> <p>James Ray is a political commentator and a friend of the show. You can follow him on Twitter <a href= "twitter.com/GoodVibePolitik">@GoodVibePolitik</a> and on TikTok <a href= "https://www.tiktok.com/@jamesgetspolitical?lang=en">@JamesGetsPolitical</a></p> <p><span style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content:</span> <a style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;" href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a><span style="font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> </span></p> <p>We also have a new (free!) <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.substack.com/p/guerrilla-history-newsletter-1"> newsletter</a> you can sign up for!</p>]]></description>
      
      <content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>In this Dispatch episode, we provide a grounding on the history of Western intervention in Haiti in order to analyze the current situation taking place there, and the prospects for even expanded intervention. For this, we bring on Pascal Robert, who's writing on Haiti has been very useful in shedding light on a locality that the Western media tends to ignore unless convenient for them. W're also joined by our friend James Ray as a guest host for this episode.     <item>
      <title>Bring Anti-Imperialism to Young Comrades + Learn from the Global South w/ The Cadre Journal</title>
      <itunes:title>Bring Anti-Imperialism to Young Comrades + Learn from the Global South w/ The Cadre Journal</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 04 Nov 2022 11:50:18 +0000</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[aed03851-3935-40c7-9659-7c282fe8371b]]></guid>
      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/bring-anti-imperialism-to-young-comrades-learn-from-the-global-south-w-the-cadre-journal]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<p>A great conversation with three young comrades from <a href= "https://thecadrejournal.org/">The Cadre Journal</a>!  A fairly wide ranging conversation focused on why it's critical to push anti-imperialism for the youth, and why it's important that we learn from the Global South, its revolutionaries and theorists.  </p> <p>The Cadre Journal is a student-run podcast and journal on Marxism, Anti-Imperialism, and Communism.  You can follow them on twitter <a href= "twitter.com/thecadrejournal">@thecadrejournal</a>.  </p> <p>Here's Joseph's article <a href= "https://mronline.org/2022/07/07/a-prologue-to-the-swazi-revolution-one-year-in-the-making/"> A Prologue to the Swazi Revolution - One Year in the Making</a>.</p> <p>Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a> </p> <p>We also have a new (free!) <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.substack.com/p/guerrilla-history-newsletter-1"> newsletter</a> you can sign up for!</p>]]></description>
      
      <content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>A great conversation with three young comrades from <a href= "https://thecadrejournal.org/">The Cadre Journal</a>! A fairly wide ranging conversation focused on why it's critical to push anti-imperialism for the youth, and why it's important that we learn from the Global South, its revolutionaries and theorists. </p> <p>The Cadre Journal is a student-run podcast and journal on Marxism, Anti-Imperialism, and Communism. You can follow them on twitter <a href= "twitter.com/thecadrejournal">@thecadrejournal</a>. </p> <p>Here's Joseph's article <a href= "https://mronline.org/2022/07/07/a-prologue-to-the-swazi-revolution-one-year-in-the-making/"> A Prologue to the Swazi Revolution - One Year in the Making</a>.</p> <p>Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a> </p> <p>We also have a new (free!) <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.substack.com/p/guerrilla-history-newsletter-1"> newsletter</a> you can sign up for!</p>]]></content:encoded>

    <item>
      <title>The Rise of Fascism, Bolsonaro, &amp; the Brazilian Elections w/ Michael Fox - Dispatch</title>
      <itunes:title>The Rise of Fascism, Bolsonaro, &amp;amp; the Brazilian Elections w/ Michael Fox - Dispatch</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 21 Oct 2022 10:14:52 +0000</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[a84cf637-abbc-4cdb-a39f-259f49353270]]></guid>
      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/the-rise-of-fascism-bolsonaro-the-brazilian-elections-w-michael-fox-dispatch]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<p>In this outstanding conversation, we talk with journalist Michael Fox about the rise of Fascism in Brazil, Bolsonaro, the impending runoff elections, the rise of Evangelicalism, the role of the US in these processes, and much more!  We make sure to give plenty of historical background on these current events, so whether you're listening for the history or for analysis of the present, we know you'll enjoy this conversation.  We are also lucky to be joined by our friend and comrade Professor Stuart Davis, a researcher of and specialist in comparative media systems in Brazil, as a guest host.  You can hear more from Stuart on our Sanctions As War introduction episode, where he was our guest alongside Immanuel Ness.</p> <p>Michael Fox is a Brazil-based journalist, contributor to The World, former Editor of NACLA, and the host of the podcast series <a href="https://therealnews.com/brazil-on-fire">Brazil on Fire</a>, a collaboration between NACLA and The Real News Network. Michael can be followed on Twitter <a href= "twitter.com/mfox_us">@mfox_us</a></p> <p><span style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> Stuart Davis i</span><span style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;">s an Assistant Professor of Communication Studies at Baruch College, the City University of New York he focuses on digital media advocacy, protest politics, and digital media and public health, particularly in the Latin American context</span></p> <p>Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a> </p> <p>We also have a new (free!) <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.substack.com/p/guerrilla-history-newsletter-1"> newsletter</a> you can sign up for!</p>]]></description>
      
      <content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>In this outstanding conversation, we talk with journalist Michael Fox about the rise of Fascism in Brazil, Bolsonaro, the impending runoff elections, the rise of Evangelicalism, the role of the US in these processes, and much more! We make sure to give plenty of historical background on these current events, so whether you're listening for the history or for analysis of the present, we know you'll enjoy this conversation. Michael can be followed on Twitter <a href= "twitter.com/mfox_us">@mfox_us</a></p> <p> Stuart Davis is an Assistant Professor of Communication Studies at Baruch College, the City University of New York he focuses on digital media advocacy, protest politics, and digital media and public health, particularly in the Latin American context</p> <p>Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a> </p> <p>We also have a new (free!) <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.substack.com/p/guerrilla-history-newsletter-1"> newsletter</a> you can sign up for!</p>]]></content:encoded>

      <pubDate>Fri, 14 Oct 2022 09:56:30 +0000</pubDate>

      <description><![CDATA[<p>This episode of Guerrilla History is a continuation of our Sanctions As War miniseries.  In this fascinating episode, we have a discussion with Professor Muhammad Sahimi on the history and the impacts of sanctions on Iran, which is both an immensely enlightening and heartbreaking conversation.  This episode is particularly timely given the current situation in Iran, which the last question of the interview addresses.  Be sure to also stay turned for more installments of our Sanctions As War series!</p> <div class="page" title="Page 12"> <div class="layoutArea"> <div class="column"> <div class="page" title="Page 14"> <div class="layoutArea"> <div class="column"> <p>Muhammad Sahimi is a Professor at the University of Southern California, where he analyses Iran's political development, its nuclear program, and its foreign policy. From 2008 to 2012 he was the lead political analyst at E0*/Frontline/Tehran Bureau website.</p> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> </div> <p><span style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content:</span> <a style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;" href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a><span style="font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> </span></p> <p>We also have a (free!) <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.substack.com/p/guerrilla-history-newsletter-1"> newsletter</a> you can sign up for, a great resource for political education!</p>]]></description>

This episode is particularly timely given the current situation in Iran, which the last question of the interview addresses. Be sure to also stay turned for more installments of our Sanctions As War series!</p> <p>Muhammad Sahimi is a Professor at the University of Southern California, where he analyses Iran's political development, its nuclear program, and its foreign policy.       <title>Sanctions As Siege Warfare w/ Manu Karuka</title>
      <itunes:title>Sanctions As Siege Warfare w/ Manu Karuka</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 07 Oct 2022 12:35:34 +0000</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[7cbccaeb-f256-4920-9086-36dc52cd29bc]]></guid>
      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/sanctions-as-siege-warfare-w-manu-karuka]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<p>This episode of Guerrilla History is a continuation of our Sanctions As War miniseries (check out our earlier episodes from the series if you've not already!).  In this episode, we lay out some very interesting historical and analytical parallels between sieges throughout history and modern sanctions regimes.  A fascinating conversation with a great scholar and committed anti-imperialist, you don't want to miss this!  Be sure to also stay turned for more installments of our Sanctions As War series!</p> <div class="page" title="Page 12"> <div class="layoutArea"> <div class="column"> <p>Manu Karuka <span style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> is Assistant Professor of American Studies affiliated faculty in Women's, Gender, and Sexuality Studies at Barnard College. He is author of <em>Empire's Tracks: Indigenous Nations, Chinese Workers, and the Transcontinental Railroad</em> (University of California Press, 2019).</span></p> </div> </div> </div> <p><span style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content:</span> <a style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;" href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a><span style="font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> </span></p> <p>We also have a (free!) <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.substack.com/p/guerrilla-history-newsletter-1"> newsletter</a> you can sign up for, a great resource for political education!</p>]]></description>

A fascinating conversation with a great scholar and committed anti-imperialist, you don't want to miss this!     <item>
      <title>Why Political Education &amp; Historical Knowledge is KEY for Activism/Organizing - Panel Part 1</title>
      <itunes:title>Why Political Education &amp;amp; Historical Knowledge is KEY for Activism/Organizing - Panel Part 1</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 23 Sep 2022 10:24:19 +0000</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[0cd2f21f-d75a-4c85-9dea-b19d329bb318]]></guid>
      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/why-political-education-historical-knowledge-is-key-for-activismorganizing-panel-part-1]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<p>For this Intelligence Briefing, we gathered a panel of great activists and organizers for a discussion on why political education is crucial to building our movements.  This is part one of the conversation, the panel discussion.  Part two, the Q&A segment, will come out next week.  To follow each of the panelists on Twitter, just click on the link after their name:</p> <p>James: <a href="http://twitter.com/GoodVibePolitik" target= "_blank" rel="noopener">@GoodVibePolitik</a>, Ilima: <a href= "http://twitter.com/ItsIlima" target="_blank" rel= "noopener">@ItsIlima</a>, Isa: <a href= "http://twitter.com/endsanctions" target="_blank" rel= "noopener">@endsanctions</a>, Matt: <a href= "http://twitter.com/MattxRed" target="_blank" rel= "noopener">@MattxRed</a>, Mikey: <a href= "http://twitter.com/karaokecomputer" target="_blank" rel= "noopener">@karaokecomputer</a>, Mirah: <a href= "http://twitter.com/snackvampire" target="_blank"       <title>Sanctions &amp; Nation-Breaking Yugoslavia w/ Gregory Elich - Sanctions As War</title>
      <itunes:title>Sanctions &amp;amp; Nation-Breaking Yugoslavia w/ Gregory Elich - Sanctions As War</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 16 Sep 2022 07:15:03 +0000</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[b41a8a3b-f850-4762-abae-3dffd367a67f]]></guid>
      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/sanctions-nation-breaking-yugoslavia-w-gregory-elich-sanctions-as-war]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<p>This episode of Guerrilla History is a continuation of our Sanctions As War miniseries (check out the intro episode if you've not already!), and is our first case study of the series.  In this episode, we hear the simultaneously heartbreaking and infuriating story of the sanctions on Yugoslavia from Gregory Elich.  Gregory, in addition to being a committed anti-imperialist and keen analyst of world events, was on the ground in Yugoslavia to investigate NATO war crimes, and this is truly an excellent conversation!  Stay tuned for upcoming episodes of the series as well!</p> <div class="page" title="Page 12"> <div class="layoutArea"> <div class="column"> <p>Gregory Elich is a Korea Policy Institute associate and a board member of the Jasenovac Research Institute. He is a member of the Solidarity Committee for Democracy and Peace in Korea and the Task Force to Stop CIJJD in Korea and Militarism in Asia and the Pacific. In 1999, he joined a delegation visiting Yugoslavia to investigate NATO war crimes. His website is <a href= "https://gregoryelich.org">https://gregoryelich.org</a>, and you can follow him on twitter <a href= "twitter.com/GregoryElich">@GregoryElich</a></p> </div> </div> </div> <p><span style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content:</span> <a style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;" href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a><span style="font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> </span></p> <p>We also have a (free!) <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.substack.com/p/guerrilla-history-newsletter-1"> newsletter</a> you can sign up for, a great resource for political education!</p>]]></description>
      
      <content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>This episode of Guerrilla History is a continuation of our Sanctions As War miniseries (check out the intro episode if you've not already!), and is our first case study of the series. In this episode, we hear the simultaneously heartbreaking and infuriating story of the sanctions on Yugoslavia from Gregory Elich.     <item>
      <title>Sanctions As War w/ Immanuel Ness &amp; Stuart Davis</title>
      <itunes:title>Sanctions As War w/ Immanuel Ness &amp;amp; Stuart Davis</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 12 Aug 2022 10:37:38 +0000</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[4eb2031e-39f2-420b-8f2f-b4d4a617a03a]]></guid>
      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/sanctions-as-war-w-immanuel-ness-stuart-davis]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<p>This episode of Guerrilla History is the introduction to a mini-series we are running for the next couple of months.  The topic is Sanctions As War, based off of the book of the same name edited by Professors Immanuel Ness and Stuart Davis.  Subsequent episodes will be focused on case studies of countries that have faced sanctions, and this intro will lay some of the theoretical groundwork necessary for us to build a narrative around!  And who better to get us underway in this series than Manny and Stuart themselves?  The book should be available for preorder from Haymarket very soon!</p> <p>Immanuel Ness <span style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> is a Professor of Political Science at Brooklyn College, City University of New York and Visiting Professor of Sociology at University of Johannesburg.  He is a multiple-time returning guest on Guerrilla History (so be sure to check out his previous appearances), and he can be found on Twitter <a href= "twitter.com/ImmanuelNess">@ImmanuelNess</a>.</span></p> <p><span style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> Stuart Davis i</span><span style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;">s an Assistant Professor of Communication Studies at Baruch College, the City University of New York he focuses on digital media advocacy, protest politics, and digital media and public health, particularly in the Latin American context.</span></p> <p><span style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content:</span> <a style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;" href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a><span style="font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;"> </span></p> <p>We also have a new (free!) <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.substack.com/p/guerrilla-history-newsletter-1"> newsletter</a> you can sign up for!</p>]]></description>
      
      <content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>This episode of Guerrilla History is the introduction to a mini-series we are running for the next couple of months. The topic is Sanctions As War, based off of the book of the same name edited by Professors Immanuel Ness and Stuart Davis. Subsequent episodes will be focused on case studies of countries that have faced sanctions, and this intro will lay some of the theoretical groundwork necessary for us to build a narrative around! And who better to get us underway in this series than Manny and Stuart themselves? The book should be available for preorder from Haymarket very soon!</p> <p>Immanuel Ness is a Professor of Political Science at Brooklyn College, City University of New York and Visiting Professor of Sociology at University of Johannesburg. He is a multiple-time returning guest on Guerrilla History (so be sure to check out his previous appearances), and he can be found on Twitter <a href= "twitter.com/ImmanuelNess">@ImmanuelNess</a>.</p> <p> Stuart Davis is an Assistant Professor of Communication Studies at Baruch College, the City University of New York he focuses on digital media advocacy, protest politics, and digital media and public health, particularly in the Latin American context.</p> <p> Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a style= "font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Open Sans', 'Helvetica Neue', sans-serif;" href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a> </p> <p>We also have a new (free!) <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.substack.com/p/guerrilla-history-newsletter-1"> newsletter</a> you can sign up for!</p>]]></content:encoded>

      <title>The Economics of Imperialism and Inflation w/ Richard Wolff</title>

      <pubDate>Fri, 29 Jul 2022 08:24:14 +0000</pubDate>

      <description><![CDATA[<p>In this useful episode, we talk with Professor Richard Wolff about the economics of both imperialism and inflation - two major issues facing nearly everyone today, but that we often don't look at the economic drivers or mechanisms of.  An incredibly fun conversation with someone we've wanted to bring on the show for quite some time!</p> <p>Richard Wolff is a Professor Emeritus of Economics at UMass-Amherst and a Visiting Professor at The New School.  He is also the host of <a href= "https://economicupdate.libsyn.com/">Economic Update</a> and the founder of <a href="https://www.democracyatwork.info/">Democracy At Work</a>.  You can follow him on Twitter <a href= "twitter.com/profwolff">@profwolff</a>.</p> <p>Help support the show by signing up to our patreon, where you also will get bonus content: <a href= "https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory">https://www.patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a> </p> <p>We also have a new (free!) <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.substack.com/p/guerrilla-history-newsletter-1"> newsletter</a> you can sign up for!</p>]]></description>

      <pubDate>Fri, 22 Jul 2022 09:12:32 +0000</pubDate>

      <description><![CDATA[<p>Guerrilla History "From the Archives" is a new series of episodes, consisting of previously patreon-exclusive episodes that we are unlocking for the general public after one year.  This From the Archives episode was originally released on Patreon on January 29, 2021, and is about the (at the time) recently released, ahistorical 1776 Report by the sham 1776 Commission.  Join us as we rant about this report and talk about its potential impact.  The report itself can be viewed <a href= "https://trumpwhitehouse.archives.gov/wp-content/uploads/2021/01/The-Presidents-Advisory-1776-Commission-Final-Report.pdf"> here.</a></p> <p>You can support Guerrilla History by joining us at <a href= "patreon.com/guerrillahistory">patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a>, where you will also get bonus content!</p>]]></description>

    <item>
      <title>Coups, Oil, and Oil Nationalization: Supplement w/ Alexander Aviña &amp; Brandon Wolfe-Hunnicutt</title>
      <itunes:title>Coups, Oil, and Oil Nationalization: Supplement w/ Alexander Aviña &amp;amp; Brandon Wolfe-Hunnicutt</itunes:title>
      <pubDate>Fri, 15 Jul 2022 20:30:07 +0000</pubDate>
      <guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[753c0250-218e-4925-a524-7e023add6e8b]]></guid>
      <link><![CDATA[https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/coups-oil-and-oil-nationalization-supplement-w-alexander-avia-brandon-wolfe-hunnicutt]]></link>
      <description><![CDATA[<p>This supplemental episode is the recording of a Twitter Space we just recorded with our friends, Professors Alexander Aviña and Brandon Wolfe-Hunnicutt.  What was originally supposed to be a pretty informal meeting became a nearly 1 hour and 40 minute discussion of coups, oil, and oil nationalization!  Enjoy!</p> <p>Alexander Aviña is historian at Arizona State University, and is author of the book Specters of Revolution:  Peasant Guerrilla in the Cold War Mexican Countryside (Oxford University Press, 2014, <a href= "https://alexanderavina.com/specters-of-revolution/">https://alexanderavina.com/specters-of-revolution/</a> ).  Listen to the episode we did with him on Cold War Latin America here: <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/alex-avia">https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/alex-avia</a> </p> <p>Brandon Wolfe-Hunnicutt is a historian at California State University, Stanislas.  You can (and should!) get <em>The Paranoid Style in American Diplomacy: Oil and Arab Nationalism in Iraq</em> from Stanford University Press <a href= "https://www.sup.org/books/title/?id=26330">https://www.sup.org/books/title/?id=26330</a> .  Listen to the episode we did with him on Coups, Oil, the CIA, and Arab Nationalism here: <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/coups-oil-the-cia-and-arab-nationalism-in-iraq-w-brandon-wolfe-hunnicutt"> https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/coups-oil-the-cia-and-arab-nationalism-in-iraq-w-brandon-wolfe-hunnicutt</a> </p> <p>You can support Guerrilla History by joining us at <a href= "patreon.com/guerrillahistory">patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a>, where you will also get bonus content!</p>]]></description>
      
      <content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>This supplemental episode is the recording of a Twitter Space we just recorded with our friends, Professors Alexander Aviña and Brandon Wolfe-Hunnicutt. What was originally supposed to be a pretty informal meeting became a nearly 1 hour and 40 minute discussion of coups, oil, and oil nationalization! Enjoy!</p> <p>Alexander Aviña is historian at Arizona State University, and is author of the book Specters of Revolution: Peasant Guerrilla in the Cold War Mexican Countryside (Oxford University Press, 2014, <a href= "https://alexanderavina.com/specters-of-revolution/">https://alexanderavina.com/specters-of-revolution/</a> ). You can (and should!) get <em>The Paranoid Style in American Diplomacy: Oil and Arab Nationalism in Iraq</em> from Stanford University Press <a href= "https://www.sup.org/books/title/?id=26330">https://www.sup.org/books/title/?id=26330</a> . Listen to the episode we did with him on Coups, Oil, the CIA, and Arab Nationalism here: <a href= "https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/coups-oil-the-cia-and-arab-nationalism-in-iraq-w-brandon-wolfe-hunnicutt"> https://guerrillahistory.libsyn.com/coups-oil-the-cia-and-arab-nationalism-in-iraq-w-brandon-wolfe-hunnicutt</a> </p> <p>You can support Guerrilla History by joining us at <a href= "patreon.com/guerrillahistory">patreon.com/guerrillahistory</a>, where you will also get bonus content!</p>]]></content:encoded>
